Many beers have come and gone through my digestive tract since then, but Im still willing to back Anchor Steam.  Gorgeous and smooth as butter, this brew disappears with alarming speed from my pint glass.  Not a perfect lager, but nice on an above 80 degree Spring day.
The rich amber color and thick head, invite one to a deliciously flavored beer. This is one I would definitely have again.
Thick, off white head. Light, hoppy aroma. Semi-transparent copper in appearance. Taste is bitter watery with a hint of malt. Somewhat fizzy. Was too plain for my taste, but a decent brew.

Bottle. Copper clear, thick offwhite head. Smells of flowers and malts. Taste is quite malty, much caramel and some fruity flavours too. Finish is with good hoppy bitterness, some citrus zests there. Good beer that actually defines a style.

A clear copper pour with a frothy, off-white head.  The aroma is bready with some caramel.  The medium body has an oily texture with lively carbonation.  The taste is slightly sweet in the beginning, but the finish is mildly bitter.

On draft at the Anchor tasting room after the tour. This one pours a hazy golden amber color and topped by a small head of off white foam that settles quickly and leaves small spots of lacing behind. The aroma is fairly mild with notes of grassy hops, caramel malts, clean grains, and a touch of yeast. The flavor follows and shows a little more life than the aroma with the grassy hops, grains, and caramel malts balanced nicely with the house yeast thats adds a touch of dryness. Medium bodied and almost creamy with balanced carbonation that leads to a clean, crisp finish. This is a nice little session ale, but definitely cool to drink it at the brewery with so much history behind the beer.
Pours amber with a white head. Aroma is caramel, fruity notes and grassy hop. Flavour is caramel, fruity notes, light bitter and light pine hop.

12 oz bottle from Mainbrew - Copper color.  Not much in the way of aroma.  Not a ton of hops.  Solid beer, but not too exciting.  If I found it somewhere there wasnt a lot of options, Id probably drink more than a few.  But, living in a city with nearly 40 microbreweries, I dont see the point.
12oz pour and not a fan. sorry but this is just an average type beer with a mild malty sweetness and little action going on.
On tap.  Poured a light amber color with a small head.  It had a nice meaty texture with a little bite on the tongue from the carbonation.  Little hops. Very drinkable.

UPDATED: FEB 18, 2016 355ml. Pours golden-amber in colour with decent head. The nose is malty with a little bit of elusive sweetness. Tastes of pale malt, maybe muesli and bitter malty finish. The palate is good - decent structure and creamy with a clean finish. The sum of the parts doesnt add up to much but the overall experience is enjoyable.
Nice fresh ale. Some malts and fruity notes in taste. Enjoyable bitterness at the end.

355ml bottle.
Pours a pale amber, slightly hazy, white head.
Clean, malty nose, hops, caramel, yeast.
Dry, medium bodied, medium bitterness, lively CO2.
Clean, malty taste, caramel, hops, yeast.

Draught.  Pours clear orange with a small cream-colored head.  Aromas of sweet malt, toffee, and mild grassy hops.  The flavor followed closely, with sweet caramel, fruit, and mild hops.  Smooth and easy-drinking, nearly creamy.  Pretty good. [646]

SCHIUMA:
Presente ma non copiosa, media finezza e non duratura, color biancastro
COLORE:
aranciato tendente al marrone chiaro; opaca ma senza residui
INTENSITA / FINEZZA:
non molto intensa al naso, dominano le note di malto con un fondo leggeremente fruttato
AROMI:
caramello, nocciola da una parte, erbaceo e floreale dallaltra anche se in misura minore
GUSTO:
un dolce leggero, fra cui si riconoscono come allolfatto note di caramello, nocciola, pane
RETROGUSTO:
rimane  spostato sui malti, ma compare un amaro equilibrato con note fruttate (frutta bianca)
CORPO:
corpo medio, piacevole in bocca
birra facilmente godibile a pasto, ben equilibrata con il giusto tono di amaro. Personalmente ricorda una altbier tedesca, nellaspetto e nel carattere maltato non ingombrante.

Poured with a copper color and an off-white, lacing head. Caramel, straw, hops, hints of vanilla in the not very complex aroma. Still, its just right. Medium dense, highly carbonated. Honey sweet aftertaste. Easy to drink, enjoyed it.

Bottle. Clear deep golden with a thick beige head. Aroma of caramel malt with a light herbal hop. Flavor is slightly sweet malt with a light bitterness to allow it to finish clean. Medium body with average carbonation and a crisp mouth feel. Nice easy drinking beer.

Poured into my Anchor Steam shaker glass. Clear amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is mostly malt and maybe some yeast. Flavor is bready and malty. Overall a decent beer, however I enjoy Anchor Steams other offerings.

Poured into an Anchor Steam pint glass.  Clear amber with a light tan head.  Aroma is light maltiness.  Flavor is very bready and malty.  Very slight hop bitterness on the finish.  Palate is medium bodied with good carbonation. Overall a good mild ale.  Think pale ale with more flavor.

UPDATED: MAY 16, 2011 12oz bottle. Thin medium fading white head. Very pleasant malty smell. Pale orange-clear appearance. Easy to drink, subtle and refreshing flavor. Lively carbonation, maybe too much. Kind of a metallic aroma maybe, not too much there.  Nice aftertaste.

Bottle. Pours copper/amber, cream-colored head. Aroma of bread, herbs, and a bit of caramel. Light sweetness in taste followed by medium hop bitterness. Medium body with lively carbonation. Finish is pretty short. Overall this is a good all-around beer. It fits in with any season, good flavor, drink one or drink many.

Bottle @ Hi-Dive Denver. Reddish amber appearance with an off white head. Amber, creamy malty, hoppy nose. Nutty amber malty flavor with some hoppy bitterness. Creamy mouthfeel. A very easy drinking beer and a great session beer. This beer is the defining California Common.
Clear amber with a lasting white head. Aroma is sweet, malty and very fruity. Flavor is medium sweet and moderate bitter. Light bitter and dry finish. High carbonation. 280311
This beer tastes and smells like a lager. Appearance is filtered and amber in color. Taste is a mix of malts and hops followed by a sweet hoppy finish.

On tap at Rogers in Rockaway with my little brother John after the Furthur Show. Clear amber color, not much of a head. Starts out with some sweet malty notes, caramel, and then finishes nice and bitter. Easy drinking, body is light to medium, and well balanced.

UPDATED: JAN 8, 2015 Tried this on tap at Woodys Pizza in Folly Beach.  Pours a clear amber  with a quickly diminishing head. Not much aroma to speak of- may have been a bit flat? Goes down smooth- really easy to drink.   None of the extreme hoppiness I have been into lately.  The finish is a bit dry with a smooth mouthfeel. Has decent flavor.   Nice combination with a slice of pizza.   Decent, nothing outstanding.

Pours a Rich Copper/Amber.Generous white head. Smells of Slight citrus more so Earthy & Malty. Hints of caramel here,soft carbonation. Bitter beginning smooth ending. A clean refreshing beer,one could drink many....
Very bitter finish with hops. Not much of a head. I liked the bottle more than anything. It was ok.
Copper color in the glass. Cereal grain aroma. Nice hop profile on the palate. Easy drinking.

This is a very clear amber beer with a thick foamy white head.  There is an earthy smell to this better that smells more bitter than it tastes. The finish is mildly bitter and dry with a smooth mouthfeel.  There is a decent flavorfulness to this beer.  Carbonation is moderate.
Pours a clear copper color.  Aroma of grain, grass, citrus.  Flavor is citrus, grass and toasted grain.  Good session beer.
Bottle. Brown golden color. Nice head. Smells of citrus, hat and oce,. Taste is crisp with hops. Almost like a pilsner but not quite. Very good drinable beer. Id have this again and again
A bit dry for my taste. Not a ton of aroma. Taste is balanced between wonder bread and dead flowers. Dont see what the big deal is.

35cl bottle from a beer retailer. It pours an unclear deep amber liquid with a foamy and consistent beige head; a little lacing. The aroma is almost entirely malty: sweet, with caramel; it resembles a belgian double. There is also a hint of yeast, and almost no hops presence. It tastes likewise, very very malty, with a good deal of sweetness. Low on bitterness, it is softly carbonated, full-bodied and finishes dry, leaving a pleasant sweet malty aftertaste with some herbal hops. A good crafted beer. Theyre not trying to be radical here, just trying to make a stable and good tasting brew. Nice presentation (bottle and crown cap), as always with Anchor BC.

Sample from a 12 oz. bottle (thanks Wade). Pours a clear brown with ample head. The aroma is musty earth, pine sap, and coffee. The flavor is bitter and lightly balanced with malts. The palate is heavy and a little astringent. Overall, bitter and boring.

Bottle: Light amber coloured and a bit hazy, small off-white layer; moderate caramelly-bready nose with a slight hoppy and fruity background; moderate sweet-bitter flavour, light to medium bodied; more bitterness in the malty-fruity finish, followed by a hoppy "tail". Pleasant, indeed....
Deep orange fizzy body with off-white head. Yeasty, grassy aroma with caramel. Full mouthfeel, plenty carbonation. Nice bitter flavour, lasting finish.
Very impressed... lovely balanced beer with rich caramel malt body cut by fine, intergrated hop bitterness and some USA hop raspyness.

On tap: Golden pour with a full finger solid head. Head dissipates fast leaving solid rings with every sip. Malty caramel aroma with hints of citrussy hops. Lots of body with low carbonation. Significant residual sweetness balanced well with hop bitterness. Balanced hop & malt finish.

Served on tap at the SFO airport. The appearance is a medium gold hue to an amber  with a slight chill haze. The aromas are medium light bodied malts and some English hop notes. The flavors are a slightly drying English hop with a good dose of pale malts. The mouth is highly carbonated and medium bodied. A tasty beer but I find the drying effect counter-refreshing.
Not what I expected a little disappointing, it was a quite malt and grainy, it tasted unfinished or something like it just was a full bodied beer, prob won;t have it again

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2011 One of my favourite regular beers. Its very refreshing, with a bitter hoppy aroma, a beautiful bewitching amber colour and a deep full malty taste with a subtlety of caramel on the finish. Very unique tasting easy drinking beer.

On tap, Old Mill Tavern, Chester NJ.  Beer pours smooth brown, with a lively white head.  Aroma is slightly hoppy, more toasted; attack is smooth and nutty with hop overtones, not much.  Finish is smooth and clean.  Great session beer.  Neat that is a lager yeast, brewed at ale temperatures, since SanFran did not have refrigeration or ice when Anchor Brewing Co. began.

On tap at the Admirals Club Lounge in the Dallas-FW Airport. It pours amber with a foamy white head and fairly high carbonation. The nose is toast, bread, caramel and citrus fruits. The taste is toast, wood, caramel, some date, metal and lemon, with a dry, almost burnt finish. Its clearly better than average, but still pretty boring.
UPDATED: AUG 16, 2011 A lovely, clean and crisp beer. Citrus, shortbread, dry biscuit. Fantastically refreshing
one of the most refreshing beers made, so light and delicate, not cheap and crappy though, i really like this beer

Bottle. Light Amber color with full, slightly off white head. Citrus and resin hop aroma. Flavor is medium sweet with good bitterness to balance. Crisp and slightly astringent on the palate. A nice refreshing ale.
Bottle. Yellow-brown colour. Somewhat fruity aroma. Strong bitterness in the taste. A decent beer.

I really enjoyed this highly drinkable beer. It has a nice Amber color, a medium body, a fruity aroma and a fruity and mildly bitter taste. That said, its flavoring was not too complex, which is why this is not one of my favorite beer styles.

I can tell you one thing about this beer: it has a really active and busy head.  Kind of an off-white color, but incredibly frothy.  An amazing head.  This is so airy, probably the most airy head I have ever seen in my life.  I think I see why call this "steam beer".  Body looks thin, a clear, glowing orange-amber color.  Not alot of carbonation in the glass for all the head.  Aroma is of a decent, malty lager with earthy, almost woody undertones.  The frothy head makes drinking (or smelling) this quite interesting.  Flavor is great!  Nothing like a lager, really... well, sort of.  It almost has the mouth feel of a lager, but its thicker, more malty, and less bitter.  Incredibly smooth and tasty.  Although its on the thicker end of the lager spectrum, it still has a very thin experience and is really sessionable and easy to drink.  A hint of sweetness, light caramel.  Overall, a very tasty, very easy to drink beer.  Really, quite great.

bottle.  pours a brilliant orange hue with a 1 finger frothy white head - which retains itself at a quarter inch.  light orange hop nose with some grassy notes.  medium body with some spicy bitterness up front, citrus notes throughout, smooth soft sides and nice carbonation.  some caramel malt mixes in well with the citrus bitterness.  finishes well with a nice bitterness followed by the malts.
It is a classic beer. Clear, clean and crisp with a nice fresh malt profile and a touch of hops.

Bottle.
Amber/ruby with a bit of off white head. Aroma is on the mild side, some malt, caramel, light fruit, some bready notes. Taste is light to medium bodied, more bready malt, faint bitterness on the back. Easy drinking, not a bad session beer.

Pours a clear, darkish orange with a thick, creamy white head. Good aroma. Floral but yeasty and light, with some subtle orange. Hoppy and clean, with a crisp fizzy mouthfeel and some unique sour notes. The warm, fruity hops stay around for a while. Not half bad, much more than just a good session beer.

At first taste this beer may seem somewhat unremarkable, but give it a minute to settle in. This is a typical american style beer, but with more (and better) flavor and a nice aroma. You feel like you can taste the hardwork that went into brewing it, and it tastes good. It wont blow your mind, but it is a great beer and likely to be a crowd favorite no matter where you are.

when tasting this and comparing it to all the mass produced pilsners, you can understand why this is so different. First, the color is a cloudy copper with a creamy white head. And theres actually some flavor to it! Maltiness with some bread notes and a hint of sour in the finish. Perhaps not a world-class beer, but it is certainly an American classic and gets bonus points for the history and revolution it helped to spawn.

Pours beautiful clear copper amber with a huge beige creamy head leaving nice lace. Aroma is malty, hoppy, citric orange, sweet and hay. Crispy hoppy mouthfeel. Medium body. Fruity, bread, hoppy, piny and malty very nice flavor. Very drinkable. Sourish fruity palate. Finishes very nice with a longlived tart hoppy aftertaste.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2013 Aroma is similar to a pale lager with some golden ale characteristics.  The flavor is malts, light citrus and ale fruitiness into the finish.  Ive seen this beer on the cover of books before, it may not be the greatest out there but as far as craft beer, it will always have its place and a much better place that would be.

Pretty dark orange pour, and nice little head on this baby.  Moderate hops and and bitterness flavor that I enjoy.  Extremely drinkable, as I could have easily drank the entire six pack before my dirty wife stole a bottle.  Six-pack was 11 bucks, so I probably wont buy it again unless it is on sale.  Pretty good beer though.
UPDATED: APR 30, 2012 Bottled. Pours copper with a big white head. Smells hoppy. Tastes grassy hoppy with a clear bitter finish.
Flaske 12 oz. lys amber hælde med et hvidt hoved. Aromaen og smag af malt, korn og noter af noget tørret frugt. Let tør mundfornemmelse og en smule bitterhed i afslutningen
Good beer - grassy hops with a bitter finish, some malt, nicely drinkable. Available in bottles at Prince Regent on Marylebone High St.
A nice beer, with a one-finger head. Dark brown, almost orange, in color. The taste is an interesting assortment of flavors. Will definitely try this again.

0.355l bottle @ Henrik, Bergen. Pours a orange body with a nice big head. A little anonymous nose with hints of yeast, spices and grassy hops. Medium-bodied and lively carbonated. A bit thin perhaps, but still proper and nice. Bitter hoppy ending.
Anchor steam is an excellent medium bodied beer. Anchor steam is crisply carbonated and has a medium-low hopiness.

Anchor Steam is a nice medium amber color - even a little tint of orange. The beer pours with a fluffy one finger head with a very long retention that leaves some impressive sticky lacing on the glass.

The aroma is of malted barley with some slight hop notes. There is not a lot of complexity to the aroma and I cant tell if I am "forcing" a smell but there may be hints of some fruits and other grains I cant identify.

The taste is similar to the aroma consisting mostly of malted barley with the hops taking a stronger presence in comparison. The taste is a little sweet with the fruit notes and a bit of nuttiness coming through. A very enjoyable flavor that is not too heavy. This could easily be a session beer.

The beer is moderately carbonated and the moutfeel is tingly but smooth. Light to medium body.

A very pleasant beer and I would recommend it when you arent looking to find something new and crazy but just want a straight up beer with a little class.
overall a great beer! Warm amber beer with a great body.  Full of flavor and rich in taste.

Clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma of caramel, biscuit, herbal hops. Taste is somewhat sweet with a pleasant hop character. Medium body, moderate carbonation, and a slightly creamy mouthfeel. Nice beer.
Amber beer with a fine white head. Smells malty. Nice sweet malty flavour as well with a bit of citrus. Good taste.
bottle from Bierzwerg. Clear amber colour, off-white head. Malty base, shy hoppy flavours with a spicy background and a shy resiny-herbal touch. A classic beer, well crafted and well balanced.

bottle from bierzwerg!
The beer in the glass is reminiscent of a smoked beer, the foam is powerful, medium pores and keeps up for a long time. Starts very strange, but interesting. Strong spicy, malty and well-pleasing, the taste is fruity and sweet. To the middle part takes the bitterness out significantly. Interesting beer!!

12 ounce bottle.  Pours a slightly cloudy orange/gold.  Large foamy biege head.  Aroma of sweet malt and grain.  Taste is mostly sweet with some caramel, citrus and a touch of hops.  Unique.  Very sessionable.  Enjoyed the style.

1pt 6fl oz bottle poured into a pint glass.  Sparkling amber with ample creamy white head.  Aroma is floral hops.  Flavor is quite hoppy, very much like an IPA.  Finish is lasting bitter and slightly metallic.  Interesting brew.

A=Light orange/amber with good head, lasting several minutes, leaving a amount of good sticky lacing.

S&T=Malted barley, some grains/fruit,maybe some nuts with a slight hop note/character in the background.

M=Light to medium bodied, medium carbonation.

Easy to drink a lot of, not bloating, very smooth and pleasant. I like it. An excellent fallback/session brew, or if youre just looking for something more casual/refined.

Looking forward to having again sometime.
Beautiful amber color, pretty thick head. Smells strongly of grass, lightly of citrus.  Taste is pretty bitter, more than I recall it tasting.

12 oz. bottle in a shaker.  Yellowish amber pour with moderate head.  Not sure if I dont like the style or if its just this one, but I was not a big fan.  Different flavor than I have had in a beer.

Light, clear, amber pour with a yellowish, stiff head which leaves a coarse lace. Smooth, no hop bite or bitterness, except for some low-level pine hops towards the finish. Medium-light body is sucrose sweet with some toast and a hint of almond. Finish is quick and a bit watery. Sessionable, but not sure I would or could - prefer Anchors Liberty Ale.

Draft pour in San Francisco. Virtually no head on this pour. Sweet aroma, yeasty. Very interesting. Flavor is sweet but no bitterness to balance. Virtually undetectable hops and seems watery in the mouth. Found it to be a very "approachable craft" beer. I can see why its well liked.
Bottle 33 cl. Poured amber colour with fast disappearing head. Aroma is nutty and hoppy. Flavour is hops mostly, quite mild though.
A aroma of sweet bread, or earthy yeast. Golden amber with a unique foam. Nice light sweetness, medium bitterness, and a little salty. Medium body, oily feel. Pretty good overall.
Same bottle as pictured. Pours dark brown with medium head. Kind of light with watery, slightly hoppy finish. Not bad. Would have again.
A beer I didnt like for the first time I tasted it.  Amber in color with good balance of hops and malts. Not very bitter.

Anchor Steam beer has a thick, cream-colored, frothy head and a clear, amber appearance, with high carbonation.  Nice lacing is left behind.  The aroma is pretty neutral, but one can sniff out a spicy hop note.  Taste is a mild, beer flavor, with floral hop undertones.  Mouth-feel is light and watery, and Anchor Steam finishes refreshing and not dry, like American-style lagers.  Overall, this is a very good beer, and I highly recommend it.

RJT
amber pour with a medium head.  Some lacing.  Flavor is mostly grain, a little malt, medium bitter finish.  Just another decent beer.

Bottle pours amber with a creamy white head.  Aroma shows notes of bread, toffee, floral hops and a touch of nuts.  Flavor shows the same.  Overall body is moderate, creamy soft, and finishes with balanced bitterness.
355ml bottle.  Pours golden with a large head.  Aroma is some fruity malt and bread.  Bready malt start and fruity, medium bitter finish.
Decent beer.  Dark caramel color similar to an amber ale.  Subtle hop taste with an roasted malty finish.

Notes from Friday, August 6, 2010
12 oz. bottle from HyVee Marion

Ar: A bit of malt, caramel, and grassy hops.  Nothing too complex, but appealing nonetheless.
Ap: Pours a light, slightly opaque amber with a 3/4" head that recedes quickly.
F: Flavor mirrors the aroma.  Light hop bitterness on the finish.
P: Medium body with effervescent bubbles.

O: My first beer of this style, and its okay.  I guess its one of those we all ought to try though.
Beautiful amber color. Nice balance of hops and malt - crisp and not too bitter. Ive never had a steam beer before so this was a nice surprise.

A beautiful pint of beer.  Subtle head and a rich color, nice lacing on the glass.  Taste is very pleasant with a nice balance of hops and malt.  The yeast makes this a real treat - lager yeast at ale temps makes it crisp but bold.

Bottle:
Small white vast foamy head, disappears quick.
Amber orange colored beer.
Smell is a fine mix of malts, hops, spices.
Well balanced mix of hops, citrus, bitter, malts, spices and some hints of fruit.
Mid carbo, medium body and a fine mouthfeel.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: UPDATED: NOV 29, 2010 Draft at Town Hall Tap. Poured into a pint glass a clear copper color with a slight 1 finger head of white. Very clean aroma with minimal notes of malt and grain. Slight cereal notes. Very clean flavor as well. Very easy drinking. Slight sweet start that last throughout. Minimal bitterness.

A nice deep amber color That starts with a nice foamy head about one fingers worth. Has a little or no aroma that I could detect. It does have bitter beginning but then finishes smooth. Judging from Anchor Brewing Liberty Ale, which I really like a lot, I was a bit let down by this one. Its still pretty good and I would never turn one away.

Other than the historical significance for the Craft industry, I was not too impressed w this brew. Aroma of mild bittering hops, taste is bland without much character. Straightforward and unremarkable session beer
Aroma is lager yeast, hops, some small caramel notes and wet moss. Taste is clear, some caramel, some spices, earth and bitter finnish of british/german hop character.

G: Poured into a pint glass.

A: Dark and amber with a white head and good lacing.

S: Malt definitely comes through more than the hops. There is some fruitiness here, but it mostly sticks to the style that its made famous.

T: In addition to what was in the nose, some bready flavors.

M: Good creaminess and medium body. Moderate carbonation.

D: All around, this is a great example of the style, and the definition of a good sessionable beer.

Pours clear amber
Nice aroma, mostly malt 
Mostly malt in the taste, hard to pick up other tones.  Not bad just nothing outstanding.  On the east coast very easy find better for less $

UPDATED: APR 6, 2012 Pours clear, rich amber red with a large white head that fades quick enough for you to drink but still lasts long enough. Smells a little yeasty, and of hops and malts. Tastes kinda sweet, but not really malty. and not very bitter or hoppy, but is definitely satisfying. On the heavier side of light-bodied with a creamy, almost slick texture and mild mouth carbonation Steam finishes a little dry and lasts a good amount. A nice lager/ale mix.
Bottle. Pours Amber with a white head. Aroma is sweet biscuit,  toast and a little caramel. Flavour is very malty toast and a little bitterness at the end.

Pours a copper colour, with off tan to beige long lasting head. Very clear.
Nice lacing in the glass.

Aroma is bready with some nice heavy citrusy hops.

Mothfeel is very light, moderate to light carbonation and finishes of rather bitter. Hoppy yet very drinkable and as refreshing as this high IBU beer gets. Hops have dominant citrus and also some noticable peppers.
Malt in the aftertaste.
Bottle from Systembolaget. Aroma is somewhat sweet and a bit roasted. Pours a dark amber colour with a nice white head. Taste is a little sour with some bitterness, very pleasant beer overall.
The aroma is grainy and spicy. There isnt too much to the taste, mostly just malty, and it is somewhat thick. Leaves a bitter after taste.

Le liquide a une robe cuivrée pâle et sa mousse est fugace.  Les arômes et les saveurs sont faits principalement de malt légèrement caramélisé et de houblons verts et fruités.  En bouche, le liquide a un corps moyen-faible avec une effervescence active et une texture douce.  La finale est maltée avec une embrassade de notes amères moyennement longues.

Bottle. Pale amber with a large white head. Aroma: fruitier lager, grass, nuts. Taste: fruit, grassy hops, bready malt, some acidity, some spices, medium bitter aftertaste. Medium full, fizzy mouthfeel.

classically delicious. old reliable still pulls through with great spice notes and a full wet mouth feel that cant be beat.
nicely but lightly carbonated and a good overall classic taste and refreshment make this a top pick.
2010 - 11 - 01 355 ml, nice bottle. dark golden colour. white fading head. nice full taste, hint of chocolate.

Poured from 12oz bottle into Pint Glass, pours a deep amber with little head.  Solid flavor, some dark malts, nice an wet to the mouth. Nice sessionable beer, I prefer Anchor Porter from this brewery though.

bottle.  Pours a clear golden amber with frothy off white head.  Aroma of biscuit, bubblegum, toast, light caramel.  Medium bodied but with a kind of creamy consistency, very quaffable.  Flavor is malty, toast and slight caramel.  This isnt a "big" beer by any means but it hasnt become an american classic for no reason.  Its a great session or keg beer.
A amber beer with a medium white head. Aroma is malty and slightly fruity, flowery hops notes. Taste is also malty, crystal malt. Nice bitter finish. Godd beer.
Bottle. Clear copper body with a thin head with some lacing. Aroma is banana, clove, maybe coriander, and citrus. Flavor is the same plus some malt. Not great but acceptable.
355 ml bottle. Clear Dark amber with very small off-white head. Flavour is malt, caramel, fruit, nuts, dry and a little bitter.
19th February 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Moderate carbonation. Clean start, very slight fruit. Dark and slightly bitter finish.
Bottle. Clear deep golden with a big off white head. The aroma is flowery, caramel and light yeaty with some citrus notes. The flavour is citric hops, light yeast and caramel. Refreshing.

UPDATED: JUL 1, 2011 Anchor Steam Beer pitkästä aikaa lasissa ja täten uudelleenarvioinnissa. Väriltään se on kullan värinen, jossei jopa hieman oranssinen. Vaahto taasen on valkoista. Tuoksultaan olut on hedelmäinen ja makean maltainen, hieman karamellinen. Maussa tulee esiin hieman humalointia ja sen tuomaa katkeruutta. Hedelmäisyyttäkin on. Tämä osoittautuu myös hieman paahtuneeksi ja tunkkaiseksi. Samat pisteet kuin n. 9kk sitten, mutta osa-alueittain erilaiset pisteet.
UPDATED: OCT 14, 2010 I try so hard to enjoy this one, but once I started with Anchor Porter, everything else seems inferior.
Bottle: Pours a clear amber, medium off-white head with good lacing. Aroma of malt and mild earthy hops.  Flavor of mild caramel with minimal bitterness, a good mild session beer.

12 oz bottle, poured at home. Pours a clear orange amber -- head is white and pretty thick right off the back, but disappears relatively quickly. Aroma is a light caramel and honeysuckle. Taste is similar -- caramel, honey, some grassy hops, a light bitterness. Theres a metallic taste to it -- something kind of cheap and macro-esque -- which leaves this beer firmly in the "OK for a session on a warm day," but ultimately boring.
Bottle from Systembolaget. This is a good one to pop when coming home from work on Friday afternoon, when you really just want a cold one. Not too complex, but not completely watered down either.

Got a golden colour with a low foam.

On the nose there is a slight maltdominated aroma, with a funky smell with bread and salt meat.

For the taste its rich with a mild bitternes, a hint of burnt malt but more towards caramelle malt. Yummy!

A new style of beer for me, hope I will drink many more!

pours a clear gold with a thick white head that hangs and laces. The beer is weak on the nose but I think Im picking up some spicy, earthy types of hops along with a caramel backbone.  balanced.  Medium-light body with a hopp bitter dry finish, also a bit thin on the finish.  Getting malt sweetness on the tongue first followed by the bitterness.  Muted spicy and earthy hops.  Bitterness lingers through the finish and then some.  A classic yes, all that great no.

pours golden brown in colour with little head.  Notes are nutty malts with a slight hint of peach or something fruity. on the palate it is medium bodied, some sourness and a slight malted note. not half as bad as i thought it would be. good session beer.
Bottle. Copper color, medium sized head. Fruit and malt aroma with some hoppiness. Sweet citric malty flavor with hoppy finish. Fruit and hops in aftertaste. 4.9% alcohol.
UPDATED: APR 13, 2011 RR: Bottle.  Hazy pale color, low head, nice caramel and hop taste with hints of a bittersweet palate. Fruity aroma and good body

355 ml bottle @ home. Rated @ 26.6.2010.
Pours an amber colour with a large white head. Malty aroma with a hint of citrus. Flavour of nuts, caramel malts and cardboard. Medium bodied with a slightly bitter finish. Average.
Great beer. has a lot of character in the appearance, palate and aroma. The taste is great with a little bitterness at the end.

22 oz Bomber bottle. Nice dirty blond/copper in the glass, light carbonation but just enough to keep it crisp. I get a metallic and earthy, hop smell. I only get that in the aroma. The tastes is a nice balance of Malt and hops.  Not to bitter and its not sugary or sweet. It left noticeable lacing as a drank it down. A crisp beer that was refreshing.  I will explore the style of California Common some more in the near future because of this brew.

(2008)The steam curiosity finally forced me to take the plunge and order on of these brews recently. I cant really say I experienced a "steam enlightenment", but the flavor was smooth and enjoyable. Id probably order this brew again.

Pours a dark brown color with a thick white frothy head. It smells like a boring lager to be honest. Thankfully it tastes much better, theres a nice balance here between the light hops, malts, caramel, and other flavors like grass and corn that you would normally associate with a lager. Its very drinkable and Im really glad I picked it up for this hot summer day. Overall its not really a breakthrough beer but its tasty and easy to drink and Id get it again in a heartbeat.
Hazy amber beer with fine head.Bittersweet taste.I like the smell of this beer, malt ,caramel and bread.A good beer

Pours amber-red with a medium, off-white head. Malty aroma with some earthy hops and some yeast.Caramel, Toffee, Citrus is all the flavours I could find here with a little hoppy finish. Medium body with a little carbonation. Not bad

Tap at Beer, Bourbon and BBQ Festival in NYC. Pours amber-red with a medium, off-white head. Malty aroma with some fine, earthy hops. Flavor holds some bready sweetness, balanced by citrus and pine hops. Medium in body with average carbonation. Finishes with a delicate balance and some lingering bitterness. Very nice.
Pours a medium to rusty golden color, nose is grainy with a hint of mildew, taste is dry, grainy, slight biscuity bready character, hint of floral finish.

Bottle: Pours a Nice Golden color, with a frothy white head at the top. The Head doesnt seem to want to dissipate here, nice carbonation as well. My first "California Common" brew, and its definately a little different than anything Ive had before. A little toasted malt, a little earthiness, a little nuttiness, coupled with a touch of citrus, a touch of breadiness. It seems that its all very mild overall, but combined its a unique mix that creates something that is very different overall. Nice Brew
A good beer from Anchor, a runner up to my favorite of theirs  Liberty Ale.

Bottle.  Poured a clear golden-copper color with a thick, dense beige head that slowly receded while large spots of lacing clung to the side of the glass.  Aroma of light toasted malts, some soft caramel, and nuts along with a light floral hoppiness paired with a hint of citrus (orange).  Smooth, sweet entry leads directly into a moderate toasted maltiness with some light bready characteristics peaking through before a light sweet caramel flavor is offset by a lightly bitter, dry hoppiness that lingers softly into the finish where a tad more caramel shares the spotlight with some soft fruity undertones.  Moderate carbonation and average mouth feel that ends cleanly.  Overall, a pleasant, simple beer that was nice to drink on a warm day.  Certainly my favorite representation of the style thus far.
This is the beer that started the craft brew revolution.  Smooth and mildly malty.
12 oz. bottle.  Pours with a thick, white, foamy head.  Amber color with a fair amount of carbonation.  A slight hint of malts with a bitter finish.
Amber with a great, foamy head.  Aroma is like bread with some dark syrup mixed in.  Taste is slightly hoppy/bitter with toast in there too.  Its a pretty good beer - I had forgotten how good it is.
It seemed to have a hint of citrus up front with a kick of bitterness at the end. Not my favorite, but not bad either.
A malty beer thats actually pretty good for summer drinking.  Loved the aroma and taste.

I hadnt had an Anchor Steam since visiting SanFransisco about ten years ago.  Perhaps my bottle was aged but the beer had a skunky aroma.  The beer had a great appearance, a nice amber color, clear costitution with a nice frothy white foam.  Perhaps also because of its age, or not, it was slightly bitter with a light body and oily feel, average carbonation, and finished with an astringent tatse.  I seemed to remember it as a more special beer than it was this time.
Not a bad brew at all. Fairly forgettable. There is a very bizarre off flavor that I cant explain.

Pours orange... foamy head, not QUITE white. Aroma is a bit leafy, with some weak citrus. Slight peanuts taste (something of a feature with steam beers?). Medium body, average carbonation. A good product, to be drink in most occasions. Just dont expect a masterpiece.
A great thirst quencher all around. Subtle hop notes off the top with an easy, medium body. Smoothe finish. Very good summer sipper, or gulper :)

Pours a clear copper orange; soapy head.  Weak orange citrus aroma and some coriander mixed in.  Good straight forward malt flavor with some trailing light citrus, almost like the white pith of an orange.  Overall, its good and easy drinking; enjoyable.

I can find nothing special about this beer.  Nice aroma and and pour.  Something to be desired on the palate and finish.  Slight hop, light carbonation, but really lacking in the finish - very dry.  Awesome bottle though.

A - Slight caramel and hay
A - Amber with a thick white head
T - Sweet with nice controlled bitterness
P - Light carbonation with medium body
O - A nice beer, somewhat similar to a bitter

Amber tinted orange pour.  Clear with a thick fluffy light tan head.  Light caramel malt aroma with hints of yeast.  Nutty malt flavor.  Dry with hints of caramel.  Moderate bitter finish.  Overall a pleasant and easy to drink beer.

Pours a nice deep copper with an off white head.  Pretty beer.  Tasty - nothing jumps out and grabs you but the whole thing works well.  Crisp, clean,  good balance of bitterness and body  Faint floral maybe herbal note.  Even not being much of a lager fan, this one always wins me over.
Two finger white head thats mostly lasting decent lacing, pours a golden color, malty with a slightly bitter hops finish, ok nothing special

The flavour has some toffee notes,carmel even a little metallic taste. There seems to be a nice balance between the malt and the hops. The aroma for the beer has some biscuit notes and some sweetness. As well a little grassy thrown in the mix Pours a light amber color with an nice creamy off white head. There is a small amount of lacing present. The finish has a little bitterness from some citrus hops but nothing that tends to linger around. To be honest this beer reminds me of Samuel Adams Lager. This is a nice smooth drinking beer. I look forward to drinking more of these in the future.

Served on tap at the Plano Gingerman.

The beer pours and orange-amber color with a white head. The aroma is grassy hops with some grapes and caramel malt. The flavor is toffee, grassy hops, grain and some metallic notes. Medium mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Good for the style, but this is a style I am not much of a fan of.
Appearance:  medium amber.  Aroma:  wood, mint, floral. Taste:  malty, burnt caramel underneath.  Finish:  medium, crisp and bitter.  Notes:  Meh.

Pours a amber carmel color with a off white head which fades to deccent lacing.  aroma is of sweet malts, yeast, and some floral hops.  flavor is of sweet malts, some floral pine and grapefruit hops, and some carmel.  has a medium-light body wiith a slighty watery mouhfeel, and a bitter, short finnish.  overall, a deccent beer that is drinkable and thus makes a  good session beer.

Pours golden brown, medium white head that diminishes quickly with heavy lacing.  Mild, sweet malt aroma.  Taste is light malty sweetness with a fairly strong bitter finish that lingers, and a very slight floral notes.  Light body, pretty low carbonation.  Good summer session beer.

12 oz bottle.
A deep amber color, pours a foamy head. Nice aroma - very interesting.

From bottle. Poured red/amber clear. Very large, foamy head. Not much aroma for me. Foam subsided in short order. Crisp, clean taste. Bitterness almost tastes like hops in a very light bread. Interesting, as I felt I could smell bread, but the aroma isnt strong at all, and I may imagine it. Looks and smells very much like any average beer. 

But the taste exceeds the appearance, very drinkable and I will have again!

Appearance: Poured a medium caramel with a substantial 2-3 finger light cream head which dissipated fairly quickly to about 1 finger leaving minimal lacing.

Smell: Hints of bitter citrus with sweet malt. Very nice combination.

Taste: Nice bite at the beginning fading into citrus. A very nice bitterness builds up to the finish. Bitter aftertaste that isnt overpowering. Very enjoyable.

Mouthfeel: Medium-bodied with a bite. Your mouth feels coated with it even after swallowing. Mouth waters a bit for more. Not too heavy nor too light; just about right.

Drinkability: Goes down exceptionally smooth and leaves you wanting more. Definitely not too heavy to enjoy several in a sitting. Very drinkable.

Overall: Id rate Anchor Steam as a very solid beer. Great flavor and high drinkability make this one I would recommend and will definitely continue to purchase. Glad I found this one about 8 months ago. Highly recommended.
Nice appearance, interesting taste with the carbonation.  Definitely would try again!
Clear, amber beer.   Very frothy, large head.   Mild flavor, blend of hops.  Very drinkable  Not heavy.

This poured s somewhat dark amber color with an off white head. Aroma was somewhat toasted, mild vinous character as well. Flavor was medium bodied toasted malts, and some caramel in their too. Fairly bland but nothing offensive

355 ml bottle, Alko. Poured dark amber color, frothy white head. Aroma is maly and slightly fruity. Flavor is malty and fruity hoppy, with a hint of caramel. Ends harsh and quite bitter. Enjoyable, as have the other Anchor beers I have tried this far been.
Sweet in scent with a touch of light yeast.  Slightly sweet flavor that ends in a light, refreshing bitterness.  Commonly available in most places near the Bay Area that is always a safe bet.
330ml bottle. Amber colour, small white head. Citrus aroma with rye. Very smooth mouthfeel. All around smooth flavour too. some citrus and hint of banana. Sourish end. Needs more character.

Poured a clear reddish amber with a stable off-white head.  Aroma is slightly fruity with pale malts.  Taste is sweet and malty.  Finish is nutty and slightly bitter.  Very smooth through with a little fruit flavor.  Very good!

Poured from a brown bottle with no freshness date on it. Color is a nice light orange/straw. Head is just a slight off white that keeps for a while. Nice lacing observed.

Smells very subtle, but of hints of honey. Taste is very clean. Not much going on, but very wonderful. I would note the small taste of fruit in this. Very good carbonation.

Overall, this is quite the beer. I have never had a steam beer, but I do like it. I am more of a dark beer drinker, but I could see this being a nice session beer.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 09-20-2008 01:02:33

Bought in a six pack across the street from my San Francisco Hotel. Smells hoppy and grainy - and it tastes just the same. Smooth oaty, grainy beginning followed by a medium bitter finish. 
Still a good beer though even though I do not like Bitter finishes. Definitely will be finishing this six pack tonight.
Bottle. Pours clear amber with off-white head. Taste is mildly bitter with bit of tartness. Palate is soft, creamy. Aromas have rich maltyness, grass, nuts.

A clear deep amber body below a medium-high head of two inches, slighly off-white in the tulip.  The aroma is malty sweet, with notes of prune and spice, some toasty breadiness also evident.  A fairly lightweight body, with medium carbonation and a firm hop bite.  The flavor is sweet, with some toasted biscuit, and the hop bitterness cutting through it all.  Very drinkable and delicious.

Bottle. Pours a light amber/orange color, with a big frothy off white head. Aroma is very mild, with some caramel malt and grains. Flavor is mostly caramel malt, along with some bread and grains. Also a slight amount of hops and citrus. The body is medium with a dry and crisp mouthfeel. Overall a pretty refreshing lager, that is worth checking out!

Draught.  pours a nice amber color with a two finger white head.  aroma of caramel and malts.  taste: is a nice refreshing beer with a creamy caramel malty flavor with a nice crisp finish with a bitterness of the hops.

Pours golden / bronze. Nice lasting offwhite head. Aroma is sweet malt, caramel, hops. Taste is hops. sweet malty caramel. Palate is medium body, smooth and creamy, nice carbonation. Finishes sweet malt and caramel balanced by slightly bitter hops. Goes down smooth and easy. A very good and tasty brew.

I cant remember the last time I had one of these, its been years, well before I got on this site.  

Stuff has a ton of flavor, way more hop than I remember.  Its a big, full bodied beer, with a good bit of malt.  Really sits pretty heavy, but has a nice balanced, if bold flavor to it.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2016 Every time I have one I forget how much I like it and forget it is as hoppy as it is.  I think the craft beer movement owes some thanks to Anchor Steam, it was out there long before micro brews were readily available. Good Stuff.  Serving: Tap and Bottle

Originally rated August 2004. Had myself two Anchor Brewery beers tonight. The first one, being this Steam, poured a deep amber colour with a small head and not much lacing. It had a slight fruity and malty aroma. Flavours started smooth and then, a mild bitterness kicked in. Also had hints of nuts. This brew is their most popular. I then tested their second most popular: Liberty Ale, which I much prefered. This one was a good session beer, but not overly impressed.
Bottle 35,5 cl. Pours amber with a small white head and a malty aroma. The taste is not to sweet with notes of malts, fresh fruits, toffee and a bitter hoppy finish. Nice!

Delicious brew.  I first encountered Steam Beer in the page of Frank Norriss McTeague, and despite the fact that the book ends with two men handcuffed together and ripping each other apart in the middle of the desert, I still wanted to try steam Beer.  Aroma is bitter hops and almost earthen.  Color is a pale amber with a nice little head.  Taste is grass and maybe a little licorice.  Palate is light and dry.  Great, classic brew.
12oz bottle.  A nice beer with a good texture.  Slightly creamy.  Definitely worth trying, but not the best beer out there by far.

Bottle. Pours a deep copper orange colour with a nice off-white head. Fruity aroma of peach, apricot and mandarin with notes of caramel malt. Flavour is of  fruit, caramel, and vanilla. Some nutty characteristic comes through in the flavour as well. Smooth mouthfeel with some bitterness in the background. Finishes quite dry and is refreshing to drink.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2010 bottle. pours tan in colour with an average off white head. quite a sweetness to it, berries and apricot are what i detected. toffee malts in the background and a good carbonation. nice beer.
somethings going on here, but Im not sure I like the early hoppiness in the nose combined with the warmer taste and woody/nutty end -
Coppery Color with a thin head. Caramel dominates the aroma with a bit of hops. The first steam beer i have tried and it was a positive experience.
Enjoyed on draft at Moodys Pub in Chicago.  Ive had this before, and it tasted much more bitter than what I remember.  Aroma seemed non-apparent, taste had a nice malt/hop balance.  Its OK.

355 ml bottle. 4.8%. Finland.
Clear copper colour with small to average white head.
Mild fruity sweet aroma with grainy malty tones.
Sweetish grainy malty and cereal flavour with bitter hoppy notes.
Shortish bitter aftertaste. Easy and simple brew.
Pours cloudy orange-brown cider color with very little head. Smells of apples, pears, bread, and some malt. Quite bitter, with a good bit of carbonation. Taste is quite hoppy, with some caramel.
Aroma is cream ale and a hint of fruit. Flavors are creamy and sweet toffee, light caramel, vanilla, and prickly hops. Smooth and round mouthfeel. Well balanced and good.
Bottle. Amber colour with a lasting medium-sized white head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel. The flavour is sweet malt, grassy hops and caramel. Slightly bitter finish, light to medium-bodied.

Tan-bronze, thin cream ring for a head. Nose of toast, light cream, and a bit of grainy corn. Heavy caramel malt in the flavor, light corn and some soap. Quite drinkable, the carbonated body keeps this lively without muting the flavors. This is because they are straightforward, which leads to some grainy boredom.

Copperbrown beer with medium and beige head. Cereals, some berry-like sweetness and fruits, overally quite fresh aroma. Flavour is malty, toffee, biscuits and slightly musty aftertaste. Medium bodied with nice carbonation. Balanced but also too simple beer and overally not very refreshning.
Amber color, big white creamy head. Aroma is rather malty, with hints of caramel. The hops are gentle, but give a necessary edge to the brew. Body is quite light.

Bottle, 330ml. Pours a clear, orange/amber colour with a magnificent, fluffy, offwhite head, looks kinda like an IPA, but clearer. Aroma is pretty floral, with some nice toasted malt character. Body is pretty robust, and complex, nice. Taste is predominantly caramel and hops. Nice bitterness in the finish. Very IPA-ish, very nice!
UPDATED: MAY 29, 2010 Amber color, beautiful, slowly-fading head that trailed intricate lacing. The taste was unremarkable, though. Inoffensive enough, probably suitable to longer sessions.

Pours a golden amber. Big fluffy head that slowly fades. Aroma is  malt yeast sweet. Flavor is balanced with both weak notes of malt and hop. Finish is more malt that hop. Short after taste. Not offensive, no real character. Just okay..

Pours an impressive sight: clear, amber body crowned with a majestic, creamy head that seems to last forever. Nose is mellow light malts and a sting of grassy hops. Taste is smooth and mild like an ale, with hints of both fruity and grassy hops tucked into a well-laid sweet malt foundation. Low carbonation, but not flat in any way. Anchor Steam Beer is indeed a very tasty lager beer.
Bottled. Amber with small head. The aroma is malt and citrus. Flavor is also citrus acidic with Lighter malt. A quite nice afternoon brew!
Delicious hoppy and light as a feather. dryish after. A bit faint . just have to look carefully.

Creamy, frothy, two-fingered, milkshake type of a head that had tremendous lacing and really hung around of the glass.  I smelled sweet caramel immediately and got a slight hint of some floral hops with backgrounds of an earthy/herbal aroma.  I tasted the sweet caramel first and also got a splash of pine.  Nice bitter aftertaste that really stuck around on the tongue.  Medium/chewy mouthfeel that was smooth and really coated the palate.  I really like this beer.  Its very nice!!!  This is one of my favorites for sure.  Another beer that I could drink during any season.

12 Oz.   Pous a deep amber color with medium that resides quickly.  Aroma is grainy with the slightest notes of darker malts.  Flavor is similar with a nice crisp hop bitterness and light malt sweetness.  Very easing drinking and light bodied.  Definitely grows on you,  the flavors seem to emerge more after a little while.

Oddly enough, I dont remember ever trying Anchor Steam prior to today!  Squatty 12oz. bottle pours a clear amber-brown with a nice bubbly off-white head that leaves nice drippy lacing.  Aroma is grainy with a touch of caramel.  Flavors match, showcasing light floral hops, raw grain, some spices unidentifiable to my weak palate, and zingy hops.  Nice, clean beer.
Your standard amber colored pour. Nose and taste was slightly smoked malts, some light citrus. Rated 11/22/2000
Bottle a amber colored beer with white head aroma malts hop fruits and spices taste fruits malts spices and a hoppy finish

I was a bit disappointed with this one. It looked great from the pour, a nice clean amber color, medium sized white head, no retention, barely any lacing. apples and bread evident from the get-go for the smell, with subtle hints of grass. light oily body, little carbonation. slight taste of caramel and fruits, but for the most part, pretty boring. Finished it in a few minutes. Will I drink it again? maybe for a cookout.

amber, white head.
Aroma, malty, grainy, dry fruits, apple nose.
Flavors, grainy and malty with a light bitter finish. Light palate, pale malts, some spiced hops, dry mouthfeel. Not my style.

Pours a dark amber colour, slightly hazy with a big frothy tan head that dissipates. The aroma is honey-like, somewhat fruity (banana) with earthy scents and it has a noticeable yeast smell as well. The taste is nice, a little malty and spicy and the finish is fairly bitter although the aftertaste lingers a bit to long. Overall a fairly nice beer.

355ml bottle.  Pours a clear copper colour with almost white head that laces quickly. Slightly sweet, non-descript nose. A malty punch up front that levels out with a nice hint of bitterness and a good lingering finish. Off the beaten path just enough to be interesting.

On tap at PFChangs.  Very clear amber.  Light white head.  Decent lacing.  Earthy hop scent and flavor.  Slight caramel/honey sweetness.  Very smooth.  Nice finish.  Not extraordinary, but a very solid beer.

12oz bottle from the state liquor store 
Appearance: Crystal clear amber with a nice frothy white head and some lacing 
Aroma: Banana, spices and yeast 
Taste: Yeast, grainy with some hops in the finish 
This is a decent beer. Nothing special, but not bad.

(draught at Meddlesome Moth) cloudy deep orange pour, great creamy head and excellent lacing. Nose of cereal grain, earth and honey. Taste of cereal grains, honey, an light earth. Light to medium creamy body. Verg drinkable.

Poured from bottle. Nose has fruit, cereal, and spice -- an almost winey odor to it with faint savory undertones. Pours a rich gold-brown with a moussy, long-lasting head. The flavor is rich and complex, with roast and spice predominating; hops bitterness clears out the finish beautifully. A classic American beer. I really hope the buyout doesnt screw it up.

Pours copper with a creamy head thats tall but goes away fast.  Smells kinda hoppy and grassy. Not very strong.  The taste is not bad at all. Balanced to a little on the hoppy side. Has a little bit of a strange metallic taste.  Very bright and carbonated in the mouth. A little slick on the finish.

Pretty darn drinkable. It does however leave a little of that odd metallic aftertaste in my mouth and a bit of that slickness on my tounge.
Clear amber with a small white head.  Not much carbonation in this bottle.  Moderate amount of hop bitterness.  Nice clean finish.  An excellent summer brew to cool down with.

Had from six-pack from BevMo.  Pours a beautiful copper color with slight head, slight lacing, and good carbonation.  Aroma is malty - hints of toast and caramel.  Good balance of malts and hops with a little more of a lean towards malts.  Finishes dry and sweet, very nice.

Bottle @ Pauls Club in Madison - Pours light amber with a small white head. Smells nutty with some lightly sweet malt and grassy hops. Sweet and caramelly in the mouth, with a bit of syrupy molasses, nuttiness, and dry, grassy hops on the finish. Light and pretty carbonated. A very interesting beer that Id like to have again, even though I wasnt really impressed by it.
Bottle. Malt and weak hops in aroma. Amber colour with soft beige head. Nice flavour of malt, caramel og hops bitterness. Nothing extraordinary.
Pours a nice amber color.  Reminds me of some of the brown ales Ive tried.  Somewhat bitter.  Good beer.

Carmel and malt nose, brownish red, balance of carmel and malts with a earthy hop profile.  Oily texture with med carbonation and slight bitter finish.  The lager yeast produces interseting off flavors when fermented at ale temps that make keep drinking this one.  A solid bar beer.

A- Transparent Golden amber body with minimal white head. Head fades rather quickly. Leaves behind little lacing in the glass.

S- Somewhat of a dry fruity nose with accents of hops. Caramel malt in the background.

T- Dry fruits and some spicy hops with a lager yeast backbone. Finish is a balance of caramel malt and bitter hops. Sweet caramel malt lingers.

P- High carbonation and thin lager body. Goes down smooth.

O- This is a pretty drinkable brew-but nothing special. It was interesting to try this steam beer. Definately worth a try.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 07-19-2007 20:22:20
This beer is not as good as I think the ratings are. It tastes like a pilsner but it is a little bit more bitter and metallic tasting. The Anchor Bock style was much better.

Sparkling amber color with an egg shell colored head and lacing create the appearance. A sweet morning fresh flower bouquet, touches of fruit, and fresh cut hay make up the nose. This is a medium bodied brew with a nice mixture of hop, malt, crisp, and clean. A solid every day, every mood beer.

12 oz bottle into English pint. Ive always loved the shape of Anchors bottles. Very "Ahoy, matey!" mariner-like. Very malty nose. Smells like caramel. Pours amber gold with a little head and just decent lacework. Tastes like an amber to me, no different. Definitely a quality amber, but just an amber nonetheless. Highly carbonated. Finishes with a grainy aftertaste. I think this beers reputation as the impetus for Americas craft beer revolution far exceeds the actual taste of the beer. Overrated (but I bow down before you, Mr. Maytag, for taking beer to the next level here in the U.S. Without your drive, we might all still be drinking mass produced pale lagers.).
really nice subtle honey flavour was the standout that really stuck with me. quite a subtle and complex flavour. highly enjoyable
Nice lively complex taste. Pours a medium light yellow with a white head. Smooth and delicious!

Amber colored brew with no aroma noticeable. Served in pint glass, decent white head formation which gradually fades away. Crisp/refreshing taste with some sweet malts and a slight hint of caramel. Smooth and easy to drink, but it is a bland beer overall.
orangish pour with a medium head that quickly dissipates.  a bit of citrus, malty feel.  some noble hops.  a good all around session beer.

Not sure what expectations I should have of this due to the style but this is the most known of the style. A pint of this from on tap did hit the spot. Orange color with a light head. Noble hop  aroma and a light sweet malt taste. Even kilter beer.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours clear orange, light white head and good lacing.  Aroma of banana, honey, light roasted nuts and almost a noble hops aroma.  Very light sweetness followed by a great hop bitter flavor.  Light body, but the finish is a little too bitter.

Bottle. Pours dark orange with a fluffy white resilient head. Grainy aroma with some citrus. Earthy flavours with orange zest-like lingering bitterness. Semi-Dry Finish. Had to try it once i guess. The beer delivered, however did not impress too much.

Amber-orange color, reminds me a lot of the beer "palm". Small head, disappears to quick also. Aroma some kind of sour, fruity, honey. Bitter-sour taste, bread, some fruits, citrus, very bitter aftertaste, bread, earth. I think its a bit overrated.

Bottle. Clear orangey amber with a fluffy white head that doesnt last too long. Grainy, malty aroma with hints of citrusy hops. Flavour is very similar but with a stronger hop presence, with notes of orange, lemon and pine. Light mouthfeel with high carbonation and a long bitter finish. Good warm weather session beer, easy to drink but not particularly outstanding.

Style #63.  I cant believe I went so long without rating this brew!  Orange with white foam and lace.  Nose is light vegetable and yeast.  Light citrus.  Taste is again light citrus and yeast.  Bitter and bland finish.  Better than Bud, I guess.
Bottle at home.  Pours a slight orange-red with a thick white head.  Smells very faintly of apple and malt.  Tastes slightly sweet.  Medium body with a thin palate and average carbonation.

bottle, pours dark orange with a tall frothy off white head.  Aroma is cream soda, alcohol, banana, and hay.  Flavor is rich and biscuity lots of nice bread and grass malts.  The finish is lightly bitter with more of the malts and light metallic notes.  Thin hop resin finish on the back end.  Solid everyday drinker.
Aroma of biscuit and some hops. Medium carbonation. Really refreshing and flavorful beer. A fantastic session brew.

12 oz bottle from the LCBO, served in a lager glass. Pours a sparkling clear amber-orange with a tall frothy tan head. Good head retention and reasonable lacing. Aroma is caramel malts and floral/herbal hops with a hint of earth. Flavour is sweet throughout with notes of honey and nutty/grainy malts. Hops provide adequate balance without being overpowering. Finish is moderate and hoppy. On the palate, medium in body with a watery texture and lively carbonation.  Overall, this beer feels a bit confused: it has both lager and ale qualities and seems to be aiming simultaneously for clean-and-refreshing and deep-and-sophisticated. It never really attains either. 2010-03-18

Bottle. Amber, creamy off-white head. High bead. Mild aroma of fruity malt with a little resin and citrus. Plain sweet and earthy malts with a drying spicy hop finish. Perhaps my lack of nostalgia for this beer is an issue here. Its drinkable.

Bottle.

A - Light orange/amber color. Decent sized white frothy head that quickly disappears.

Sl - Fairly light, with scents of floral hops and some light citrus. Also a bit of malt and bread.

T - Hops and malts are pretty well balanced with hops slightly edging out the malts. The hops provide a floral and earthy flavor. Also some zesty lemony flavor. Very slight saltiness as well. Pretty clean flavored beer.

M - Smooth and pretty light bodied. Finishes fairly dry.

D - Easy to drink, with good clean flavors. Would make a pretty good session beer, although it is hurt a bit in that department by the dryness (may need to have a more juicy/thirst quenching beer every now and then).

Notes: Nothing outstanding about this beer but it is a solid everyday type of beer.
Gold amber pour with slight head. Smells like a basic lager. Not much flavor. This is a bit overrated in my opinion.

Thick, vanilla colored head; deep gold color; feels crisp in the mouth, reminiscent of a how a good mass-produced American lager tastes on a hot summer day; hint of creamy taste; subtle flavor, not complex, but not dull.;

Dark orange color, small, frothy white head; aroma doesnt give much, but faint scents of floral hops and honey sweetness; light-medium body, aggressive carbonation; flavor is fairly malty sweet with some stuffy hoppiness - and I mean it really: calling this "fresh" without being sarcastic would be simply being stupid. Again, reality is no match for the legend.

Excellent hazy dark orange look. Shows a nice head that takes its time going away. The light seems to hit it juuust right. No lace. 

Gives off a well-balanced pub ale smell. Has a great combination of the dry English malt and some flowery hops. Also has that trademarked smoky (steamy) aroma, like a BBQed beer. 

The flavor is of a terrifically balanced pub ale taste, matching the parallel smells listed above. It does have an additional roasted malt, and more of that smokyness. Biscuity but has a *tiny* bitter finish. 

Its slightly thick-feeling but smooth. No bite whatsoever, and thicker than you would think. Its a substantial ale but with a flowery -- and smoky -- depth. Very very good.

Bottle.

Amber with a medium white head.

Malty and fruity aroma with hops. Taste of citrus, malt and some caramel. Medium body. A good beer although far from amazing.

First Micro I Ever Tasted--Summer 1984.

Anchor Brewing Company	Steam Beer--1999 12 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  (4.0 / 5.0)  Golden Ale--Clear rich amber color.  Light malt hop floral front.  Rich flavorful malty body with delicate light fruit biscuit flavor.  Finishes smooth with tint of chalky malt residue.  Nice lace. ESB flavor.  Sampled 12/23/1999.

Anchor Brewing Company	Steam Beer--1999 22 oz. Bottle.  5.00% ABV.  (4.5 / 5.0)  Golden Ale--Bright clear reddish golden body.  Nice light chewy hop front and caramel nut malt body. Very clean and flavorful.  Finishes with a tingle and leaves a rich lacy head.  Unique.  Sampled 3/3/1999.

Anchor Brewing Company--Anchor Steam Beer--2002 12 oz. Bottle.  4.50% ABV.  (4.25 / 5.0)  Steam Beer--Clear rich thin pretty amber color.  Lacy light head.  Tight nice floral hop malt front.  Crisp smooth tangy biscuit caramel light toast sweet body.  Clean tangy mild biscuit hop citrus end.  My First Micro!  Sampled 1/10/2003.
bott. decisamente povera di aromi.debole anche nel gusto rimane solo una nota erbacea e amarognola.
12 oz. pour from bottle.  Spice and light smoke on the nose.  Very nice balance of maltiness and hops.  Smooth lager finish.  Decent stuff.

Pours a beautiful clear copper color with a fine off white head. The aroma is very different with fruit, bread and bubblegum. The flavor is very nice. Crisp, refreshing, yet flavorful. It stars out cidery with fruit and bubblegum, and then settles in with a hoppy bitterness and finishes on a bready note. This is a very original beer and a classic.

Intriguing. An amber ale with white medium head. Aroma is malty and fruity clearly american hops. Something herby. Strong bitterness taste but some sweet malt to balance it. Not so long mouthfeel and again bitter finish. Nice and very drinkable.

Bottle. Copper/amber, Fresh, bready, cereal grains with moderate bitterness. Finish is dry, bitter, clean. Refreshing yet substantial, easy to drink. Medium body, balanced. Easy to see why this one made it mainstream. Solid brew.
Nice clear appearance, amber red. Pretty calm taste. Thin slick texture. Its pretty good... Ill definitely choose it again.
Amber with small head. Light aroma and taste from hops. Body light, texture thin. lively carb. Not much to whissle about.

Bottle poured into shaker. Appearance is a clear copper brown with a finger of off-white head that manages to lace well. The aroma is a simple, no-frills, sweet breadiness that is neither exciting nor bad. The tongue accentuates the caramel flavor but also identifies a lemony flavor from the hops. Finish is subtly bitter. Theres nothing great about this beer, but also nothing objectively wrong with it.

Ive had this beer about 9 different times and each time have had a different drinking experience.  What Ive discovered is that if you get this beer fresh, its incredible.  If its been sitting on a shelf for a few months its just average.  Had it once at Dive Bar in NYC and it was a buttery, fruity, smooth pint of liquid amazingness. Other times...not so much

bottle from IPB 
Appearance : Clear amber with medium head. Extensive lacing, short head retention.

Aroma : Sweet malt. Some hops. Notes of butterscotch. Some grain. Some citrus-y hints.

Taste : Caramel, malt, grain, alcohol. Citrusy

Finish : Sweet and malty. Some hops and light bitterness. Citrusy

Overall : Not bad. Very drinkable.

Pours a light copper color, clear and sparkling with a creamy off-white head that clings to glass. The nose is subtle - bread and caramel. The palate is light and smooth, softly carbonated with a short finish. The taste starts lightly sweet and finishes dry and earthy. Overall, the beer is subtle and understated. Drinkable.

12oz Bottle: Pours dark orange, very light streams of carbonation, slightly off-white head about 1/2-inch thick on top. Very sweet, malty aroma  of caramel, oranges. The sip is a surprise, a great body with a strong malty flavour providing apricots and a nice, sharp hop bite chaser. Its refreshing and just lightly complex, no wonder this ones a classic.

Bottle. I liked the body of this beer. Solid and rich on the palate. Creamy head, pleasant pour. It was bold in its hopp character, both in taste and aroma. Hoppy flavor to start, which mellowed as it lingered into malty caramel and coffee flavors, then ended with a bitter, yet smooth finish. Solid beer, but not one I would miss if I never had again.

12oz bottle from Whole Foods.  Pours a clear, amber body with a quickly receding, fizzy tan head.  Nose is lightly malty and some corn.   Flavor is light sweetness and slightly bitter.  Mild lingering bitter finish.  Medium body.

UPDATED: FEB 14, 2010 Bottle.  California common or California boring?  Nothings wrong but nothings great in there.  Enjoyable, surely better than any industrial american beer but for a craft beer, it is quite bland.  Body and maltiness are OK but my tastebuds were expecting more hops and even with my brains concentration, they could barely find any...  5-4-4-3-11  ADDED:  Another day, another beer...  Or perception?  No, its a good, very aptly and subtlely hopped.  I think I had my first after some kick-ass IPA.  Ill know better now...  This Steam is really smooth.  Thats this beers personnality.  If you want something heavier or hoppier, get something else: this is a classic.

355ml bottle. Porterhouse, Dublin
Amber body, white foam.
Malty aroma, very caramelly.
Thick texture, moderate carbonation and body.
Lots more caramel on the body, quite clean finish if not a bit on the sweet side.
Interesting sort of beer, very malty not unlike an Oktoberfestbier, yet has the phenolic undertones of an ale.

Nice amber beer with quite a bit of yeast on the nose and palate. Grass hops.  Bred and hay malt. Light bitterness which is noticed in the finish.  Fairly light bodied with lively carbonation.  Really drinkeable.

Pours a deep amber color with a beige head. Biscuity, malty, caramel, nut, apricot, and spice in the nose. The taste is nutty, followed by light fruits, hops, citrus, and grass. Decent lacing, thin, and smooth palate.

Hazel brown pour with small head.
Aroma of old beer, sugar, burned caramel, watery and slightly fowl.
Watery, sugary flavour, malts and faint hops. Seems old and dead.

Bottle at home, thanks dEnk! Pours a beautiful clear orange color with a this white head that quickly dissipates. Aroma is sweet malts, sugar and some artificial fruits. Flavor is watery bitter, a bit like a pub ale. Bitter finish. Not really my thing.

Bottle. I havent had this in a long time. Floral, malty aroma. Spicy and crisp, malty, sweet, warming. Very carbonated. Refreshing more than tasty maybe. Still, an old favorite with a lot of good memories.

Pours clear light-amber, with a medium beige head, fine and lasting lacing.  Aromas of biscuit, caramel, apricot, nuts and grass.  Light body, creamy, crisp and smooth.  Nutty caramel flavor, lightly sweet, with fruity and biscuit notes, medium bitter earthy finish.  Like a hopped-up cross between a Marzen and an Amber Ale.  Very well balanced and drinkable.
Pours amber with a light frothy head.  Really carbonated and refreshing however could use more flavor in my opinion.  Enjoyed a sixer over the weekend during ski weekend in Killington, VT

This is an oldie but greatie in my book.  Fell in love with this on recommendation by Leafs93.  May have been my first micro/craft.  This beer is my favorite after a long day of yardwork.  Has a great hoppy aroma.  Pours an amber orange haze.  Medium to light body.  Little lacing.  Bitter, cream caramel taste.  Its funny, I used to think this beer was extremely bitter before  venturing into some of higher IBU IPAs.  Love this beer.
fluffy, steady head over a clear golden brew. Flavor starts out dirty, but smooths into a maltier lager flavor. Not unlike Yuengling. Bottle at Zekes Roadhouse, Miami Beach.

Pours clear dark amber with a nice frothy head and some moderate lacing.  Aroma is a bit skunky but theres nice amounts of sugar and yeast there too.  Mouthfeel is very pleasing... creamy almost,  and the taste complex.  Subtly fruity malt flavor opening up to a grapefruity hoppyness finishing dry and tart.  Very enjoyable beer that walks the line between casual and alluring and keeps me coming back.

Bottle. Pours a dark, clear orange with a finger of tan head. Aroma is fairly straightforward, mostly caramely, bock like malts, some earthy and grassy hops. Well balanced, a bit on the sweet side, could have used more hops to freshen it up just a little bit. Body is light, sparkly carb. Decent.

Pours an amber/orange-ish body with a frothy beige head. Fairly strongly carbonated. Some nice fruity malts on the nose, with hints of apple, orange, and caramel. A little floral. The taste is also very malty, fairly fruity and a bit grainy. The finish is a little bitter and dry, with some lingering caramel notes. There is a noticeable sweetness overall. 
Nice and crisp on the palate and very drinkable.
Overall, Anchor Steam is an interesting beer that tastes very natural to me and has its own character. Not one of my all-time favourites, but definitely a worthy beer that I respect, nonetheless.

23-JAN-2010, bottle @home, from Systembolaget.
Beautifull orange-golden with thick off-white head.
Sweet charamel nose. Some fruitiness on the taste, and the charamel. Mostly to the lighter malty side. Not much hop bitterness. High carboantion, crisp taste. OK.

If youve been following my beer reviews for a while you know Ive attempted to coin phrases and adages when it comes to beer-critiquing. Another one Id like to start is, "Just because its a novelty or unique beer or has a reputation doesnt necessarily mean its outstanding."

To back up that claim Id point to Anchor Steam Beer. This is a beer known for its unique brewing process which is a bit difficult to describe. Its a long, but fascinating story and Id recommend looking up its history. Its also important to note that the brewery has trademarked the title "steam beer" and all others brewed in style must be referred to as "California Common." As for the beer itself, Id definitely have to say its good, but considering just how well known it is for its original style I was expecting something world class. However, Ill settle for a solid performer any day.

APPEARANCE AND AROMA

Ive never been a fan of inverted funnel-shaped bottles like Anchor Steam uses. However, I was surprised it produced such a smooth pour with almost no kickback. The body is a clear shade of amber bordering on bright orange. Its mostly clear but a tiny bit hazy. Not surprisingly, there is plenty of carbonation noticeable which lasts throughout the life of the beer (this condition is partly responsible for the beer garnering the "steam" nickname).

The head is a thick, two-finger layer of off-white foam which outlasts the liquid and leaves some lacing on the glass. The aroma is surprisingly mild with a mostly generic, slightly grainy scent. I also noticed a sweetness to the nose, but it was faint as well.

TASTE

I didnt know what to expect from Anchor Steam Beer. I knew it had a reputation for being uniquely brewed and I assumed its taste was just as unique. After my first swig I found myself befuddled at how familiar the palate actually seemed.

The best way to describe the taste would be something similar to an authentic niche German lager like a Vienna or Marzen. There is a slight caramel sweetness to the palate, but at the same time a noticeable dry texture. Its followed by a fairly crisp palate not unlike most American lagers, but without the intense taste of grain or adjuncts. Overall, the taste is sweet but mild. I didnt notice much hop bite or bitterness, but I did enjoy the sweet, malty flavors.

DRINKABILITY

I would consider Anchor Steam to be a little above average when it comes to its drinkability. The mouthfeel is a little thin and watery but the crispness also makes its presence known. It finishes smooth, but not entirely. Considering its mostly sweet and fairly mild palate Id certainly label it drinker-friendly.

WEIGHT

Weighing in at 4.9% ABV, this is a rather light to average beer as far as density. It didnt seem all that heavy in the drinking process, nor did it fill me up quickly or thoroughly afterwards. I think it lends itself to meal-pairing or sessioning but probably wouldnt work as a party beverage.

FINAL THOUGHTS

Im always happy to try beers known for any unusual or original qualities they may have. In the case of Anchor Steam Beer Im genuinely glad I tried it and would say that I liked it, but I was expecting something a little more impressive. But at the end of the day its still a good beer and thats what matters, right?

NOTE: Watch the video version of this review at:

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QviLfqUGqdI
bottle - nice hay and grass aroma. Flavour has also grass and some hops notes.

This would qualify as my first non-macro beer.  It holds a lot of great memories that come back everytime I drink one. Had my first Anchor at 17 at Peculiar Pub in NYC, I have loved it ever since. My first legal case of beer was Anchor Steam and I could not believe the cost!! The beer pours  a deep amber.   The aroma consists of caramel, fruit and hops. Taste is caramel, hops and a hint of raisin. The body is thin and the taste ends up bitter.  A great beer that holds great memories.

UPDATED: FEB 22, 2010 Bottle.  Like this more on the second try.  Poured a clear gold with a fluffy, rather lasting white head.  Has a sweet and bready aroma with a little bit whiff of grassy hops.  Flavor is very malty and bready with a little bit of floweriness, earth, and lemon from the hops.  Has a lot of carbonation.  Rather thin.  I like this more than most mainstream lagers.  Definitely goes great with food.
Pleasant, mildly hopped aroma.  Pours light copper w/ some chill haze.  Flavorful garden-variety ale with a lingering finish.  Pretty good.  A good "starter beer" for craft beer newbies.

Bought in Amsterdam. Amber color with a nice and persistent foam,  aroma is malty, some spicy notes. Flavor is quite sweet and dry combination but refreshing. very drinkable. Mouthfeel keeps some sweet and dry long sensation.

Serving: 12 oz. bottle.
This beer starts off looking great.  A deep amber color with a  pillowy off-white head of foam sitting on top.  The head has no problem maintaining itself.  The nose tells me some effort went into making this brew.  Perhaps some noble hops are at work here.  A little grassy with notes of hay and some toasted malt.  The flavor is quite refreshing with a great malt and hop balance.  The taste follows the nose, particularly on the grassy side.  The mouthfeel is on the medium side, but very crisp.  The finish is bitter, but it doesnt linger on the tongue too long.  Overall this is a well made and highly sessionable brew.  Perfect for just about anytime, but very rewarding after a day of hard labor.  Drink up!

12 oz bottle pours dark amber with a good amount of off white head into a lager glass.  Cheap lager aroma but some breadiness and floral sweetness save it.
