Grassy and citruisy hop profile with some lemon tartness, breadiness, mild malts.  Unfortunately it holds a cheap lager aftertaste.  High carbonation, light bodied and a fuzzy mouthfeel.  Refreshing, but the carbonation sits in your guy to much to be sessionable.

Color is a deep woody one, a mix of red and brown.  The aroma has a lot of spice to it as well as some hops.  Taste was pretty good.  The spices were there, as well as some hop and malt characteristics.  I was surprised that this was only 4.9% ABV as it tasted stronger than that.  Good beer if you need something to wake you up but not get you too loose.

nice two finger foamy head with floral aroma and a golden bright body.  Taste is a little sweet with mild hops, some citrus but mostly malt and grass.  Overall, a delicious beer that performs well in every area.

Light amber colour, big dirty white head, lacing.

A: Toffee, honey, grass. straw, malt sweetness.

T: Much more bitterness than in the aroma, fruity, yet with a lagerlike quality and a malty backbone, a bit thin and chemical finish. 

M: Average, small bubbles, not so much carbonation

T: like the bite but the rest is a bit thin and there is some funky metallic notes in there as well.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2010 Bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with creamy, sea foam head. Aroma is malt and barley. Taste begins with intense carbonation and malt sweetness followed by barley and bitterness. It finishes dry and crisp with a faint malt aftertaste. Overall flavor is simple and refreshing. One of my all-time favorite session beers.

Pours copper color with a thin head. Head becomes a film within minutes. Rich aromas of malts and lightly floral hops. Sweet and sticky caramel notes as well. Copper flavor. Some malt. Light bitterness to balance it out. Over all not bad. Ill take the liberty ale over this every time.
This amber beer had a solid aroma of malt and tasted a bit bitter. Smooth swallow despite the bitter taste, not bad - not great.

Refrigerated bottle.  Kind of inbetween an ale and a lager or maybe just a light ale taste.  The taste has some floral characteristics.  A good amount of hops in the finish.  All in all I dont really like it.
Another classic that holds up over the years. Unique in its style, to be sure, but a good flavor and aroma, and as refreshing as they come.

Great session beer.  Poured pale yellow/orange with a thin white head.  Aroma of grain, hops, malts.  Taste is hoppy, citrus, grainy, and a little chocolate/caramel malt in there.  Smooth and bitter on the end but pleasing.

Pours a clear golden color with a nice and thick head.  Aroma is of malts, grain, hops, some caramel, and honey.  Flavor is of malts, hops, rye, and some slight citrus.  Leaves a bitter aftertaste in the end.  Overall this is a descent brew.  More of a session style in my opinion.

12 oz. bottle in lager glass.  This beer grows on you.  Initial aroma is malty and slightly caramel.  Nice amber color with a creamy, but short lived head.   Nice roasted flavor.  A little thin, but with a very nice quick bitter finish that makes it slightly arid.
Pours amber and clear with a average off white head aromas are basic malts,hopsand cramel taste is of the same with a slightly bitter dry finish this just doesnt live up to all the hype

12 oz bottle from TC Craft.  Pours with a straw color and a nice foamy head.  Aroma and taste are quite a bit like a normal macro-brew but with a little bit more body and flavor.  Slight hops presence both in the flavor and in the finish.  Admittedly, Im not too familiar with the "California Common" style of beer so its tough for me to know what theyre trying to do but its a decent beer.

Bottle pours a see through yellow with a small white head.  Aroma is lightly sweet, malty, and a hint of spice.  Taste is sweet and crisp with a slightly bitter and spicy finish.  Very smooth and easy to drink.
12oz. bottle, pours a murky gold with a medium white head. Aroma is mostly yeast, and some hops. Smooth buttery mouthful - flavour is caramel malt, yeast, with a nice bitter aftertaste. Great beer.

(br-btl or-lbl with anchor, "San Francisco since 1896, 5%)

lct-cpr, thin-wh-head, ^eff, med-full-body, ^smooth, ^co2.

sweet-malt fruity-hop aroma.

§sweet-malt §fruity T1, sweet-malt spicey-hop fruity-hop T2, bready pretzel-crust T3.

^drinkable session especially with food.

Anchor Steam is elusive to rate, simply because its not particularly a bad beer, it only bottoms out in mediocrity. The carbonation pops and buzzes in the glass, and gives the flavor a fizzy and light consistency. The taste is bitter and yet curiously blank. Id site the amber color and the archaic looking label as the most noteworthy aspects of this underwhelming brew.

UPDATED: JUN 9, 2010 (12 ounce bottle - pint glass)  Pours a translucent yellow liquid with frothy white head that leads to little lacing.  Aroma is fruity.  Taste is mostly fruity.  Has a roasted malt quality that is balanced with an assertive hop characteristic, but is overall sweet.  Lively carbonation and a pleasurable bitter aftertaste.

Draft at Arlins in Cincinnati.  Pours orange-gold with a creamy off-white head.  Light aroma of pale malts, hops, vegetal notes, and hints of fruit and caramel, especially late.  Flavor of malts, citrus, hops, bread, yeast, and caramel.  Very malty and bready mouthfeel.  Medium-bodied.  Not a bad beer, but nothing really stands out here.

pours out murky clear gold with a nice lumpy white head that was very frothy.  the body is a clear white zinfandel in color with bubbles rising up in the center of the glass.  the aromas are very moldy with notes of yeast, and hops.  there is some malt and sweet spices also present.  it is almost medium bodied and has a nice bubbly mouth feel as it rolls over the tongue.  it is a little grassy and floral but still pretty balanced.  the flavors all meld together and is almost like a "bright lager".  very nice and refreshing beer. pairs well with fried poultry and other breaded meats that arent too strong in flavor.

Bottle from Systembolaget.  Reddish brown beer with very small white head. Sweet taste is caramelly malty and the taste continues the same with nice hoppyness. Medium body. Not a bad beer but the style is not one of my favourites.
Amber colour with a nice but thin head, malt aroma, caramel malt taste, liked it was like a good English beer.

Aroma is very yeasty with a slight fruityness.  OK Amber color with almost no head.  The flavor reminds me of a good Michelob.  The aftertaste is influenced by the alcohol taste.  Decent bitterness in the taste but could have benefited from more hops.

This is a really good, simple beer. Pours dark yellow with plenty of head and lacing. Tastes like butter. Literally. I could drink a six pack of this and not get bored with it. A staple in my fridge, and Im surprised I havent rated it yet.

2007-02-10, one of many of this lovely wee bottle, Göteborg
AP: amber body, creamy low head. AP/F: butterscotch, smokey and nice fruits. Long after bitterness
This is a wonderful beer has a very roasty taste to the palette with a caramel aroma, the hops flow just right and it doesnt have a very harsh afterbite like some beers. Overall a great beer

Its aroma is of very subtle roasty malt. Solid copper in appearance with a quickly disappating head. Taste is of caramel malt, followed by a very dry finish. Not too much going on at all. Not bad but not enough flavor for me.
boring - like a slightly better pale lager - peppery, very carbonated, slight hoppiness

Pours a nice, bright copper with a thick slow falling head. Nose is, well, kind of uninteresting and a little light. Taste is initially a biscuity caramel malt, then overcome with a slightly sour, yet dry bitterness that shows fall harvest spices (cinnamon, nutmeg, et al) as it warms. Very drinkable, and a hallmark of the style for sure, but not very interesting.

33cl bottle, as pictured. 

Pours a nice, slightly hazy copper with a formidable, frothy off-white head with great retention and plenty of lacing.

Aroma of toffee and hops, with some unidentifiable spices in there too. Wee note of vanilla.

Floral notes dominate the taste at first, something very un-lager-like. Theres aniseed, too, some light malt, a resinous note - with herbal, dry hops in the middle and finish. After taste is bitter, but very moderately so.

Unusual mix of flavours of blond and darker beers. Bitterness makes it very refreshing, though there is indeed a somewhat metallic note in the after taste as you keep drinking. To avoid it, youll have to keep the time between individual sips short - which is fine by me. ;=)

Well-balanced, stimulating beer, a cut above most blondes, kind of unique. Will test and re-rate again later.

12 oz. bottle from Total Wine in Chesapeake.  Pours dark orange with a huge, fluffy off-white head.  Very much a lagerish aroma of sweet caramel malt and some other vegetal aromas.  Metallic flavor, some sweetness, and hint of tomato juice.  I respect Anchor and its history but I really dont care for this beer much at all.  As I have stated before, lagers are not my style.  I know this isnt technically listed as a lager but its damn close, and close enough that I hope someone that is being introduced to craft brewing wouldnt mistake as something that is representative of how great craft beer can be.

12 oz. bottle.  Minimal head,  Amber, clear in appearance.  Very little aroma, (a little single malt?) with some hops.  Very British in taste.  Not what I was expecting from Anchor, but good.  Compared to Liberty Ale, this is slightly disappointing.

Brown bottle, 1 pint 6 ounces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie, savoured on November 15 2009; eye: polished copper, clear, no effervescence, beige head that falls and turns into a tiny ring, no lacing; nose: resinous hops, malt, light fruity, light citrusy, caramel, grain; mouth: resinous hops, malt, light citrusy, light orange, dry finale in hops with presence of malt, nice bitterness, slightly sweet, surprising astringency, medium body, slick, rather carbonated; overall: fine

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 1 pinte 6 onces, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 15 novembre 2009; il : cuivre poli, claire, pas deffervescence, mousse beige qui tombe et se transforme en un petit anneau, pas de dentelle; nez : houblon résineux, malt, léger fruité, léger citrique, caramel, grain; bouche : houblon résineux, malt, léger citrique, léger orange, finale sèche en houblon avec présence de malt, bonne amertume, très légèrement sucrée, surprenante astringence, corps moyen, coulante, plutôt carbonatée; en résumé : bien
Bottle. 12 oz. Pours clear amber/orange with a modest white head. Aroma of hops, citrus, hay, wheat, and hints of banana and vanilla. Medium bodied with a light, easy finish. Good brew.
Rich amber color with creamy head.  Very smooth taste and I would recommend it to anyone
Bottle. Dont understand what makes this beer stand out. Tastes like any other premium lager to me. Anyway. It still has a good taste and I would recommend it to anyone who has not drank it before.
Bottle. Grainy, fruity aromas, hint of honey. Taste is malty sweet, quite refreshing. Medium carbonation provides for good mouthfeel.

Given a higher overall impression for the uniqueness of the style.  Poured off red/orange and smelled of hops, with the sour tastes very upfront.  Although fairly balanced, it leaves much to be desired is not what I look for in a beer.

Im not a huge fan of the California Common Beer category or "Steam beer" category.  I find the body to be thin and slightly overcarbonated, with a sour and slightly blackberry, slight mint, and bitter currant hop flavor (notably from Northern Brewer hops).  The esters although they are vital to the classification of this beer just dont do it for me.  Ive had to drink 3 6-packs to try to understand what it is that people see in this beer, and I still dont really care for it.  Its definitely brewed to correct style, but Ive come to realize that I really do not enjoy the California Common style.  I found the same sour hop characteristics in their Porter yet enjoyed it even less.

Bottle - A good, but not great beer.  Looks and tastes similar to a lager, but has a tad bit less bitterness and more sweetness.  There werent any noticeable flavors in this one, the aroma was hoppy and the dark amber brown color was nice.  The head was a little too frothy and made the first few sips full of head with little beer.  Again, good but not great.

Sorry San Francisco, Im afraid I just dont get it.  Pours honey brown with a clingy white head.  Aromas of candy sugar and not much else.  Tastes of bubblegum, clove, and malts with a bit of a lactic funky finish.  Not something Id want to have often.

Pours golden amber with creamy head.  Aroma like robust like lager, but sweetness.  Like caramel roasted notes.  Clean and crisp flavor with hops to match.  Ive heard so much about this one, but it doesnt quite live up the hype.  Nonetheless very good.

Poured from bottle into Summit Pint glass.

Clear amber with relatively thin head but expansive lacing.

Aroma of caramel, biscuit, toast and some earthiness.

Earthy, toasty malt that has a semi-sweet caramel middle before ending with a strong earthy bitterness that is almost too much for this particular beer. Somehow it doesnt come together as well as it should in terms of malts vs. hops.

Moderately high carbonation (almost fizzy), medium body, dry finish.

Obviously a very important beer in craft beer history that is quite good but is ultimately more relevant for its history. Nice to have every once in a while.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2009 On tap at Roxys (Clematis Street, West Palm Beach, FL): Creamy aroma and body, bitter finish. Pine hops, honey, citrus malts, liquid bread, ripened fruit, cinnamon, and some cardamom. Drinkability: Pretty Good. Rebuy: Yeah. #156 on 25102009, DG.
amber color, spicy malty aroma, medium malt flavor, some citrus, honey, lightly bitter finish.

12oz bottle. Amber hue with a small, short lived head. Aroma is sweet malt, ripe fruit with some nice hops presence. Medium body with piny hops fill the mouth with nice balance of fruit and biscuit malt. Long, dry, hoppy finish. Very interesting brew.
clear golden/bronzy/yellowy like colour, fair head. nose is simple, nose is good, bready and citrusy. taste is similar, goes down incredibly smooth. could drink for hours.

Pours amber brown with scents of the sea and sweet undertones of san fransisco.  An american icon of beers that just catches the mouth and eye and brings joy.  What a story and what a beer.  This beer was first given to me as a gift and didnt enjoy too gbraetly.. Had again every year since then atleast 2 times a year and it really grows on you.

Sitting down with an Anchor iSteam s like Jimmy Stewart at Christmas time. A welcome old friend. Considering its overpowering presence in the Bay Area I may have had more of these than any other craft brew.

An old favorite, love the bottle and label too.  Pour is clear light brown; white head. Aroma is malty, light caramel, nice hop presence, and a little bread.  Flavor is refreshing; lightly malty with nice dry hop finish.  Great stuff, great brewery.

UPDATED: OCT 22, 2009 Pours a clear amber color that is slightly on the orange side.Has a light aroma to it. You have to dig your nose into it a little.However its aroma reminds me of good bread with a little citrus.The taste was real balanced.Most of all very drinkable.Overall a good beer I would buy again.
Brilliant bronze color, settles out in a nutty lacing that slighty fades into the glass.  It is a malty beverage, leaving a bite of hops on the finish.
Draft as part of my 99 beer club. Not a fan. Pours a clear amber. Toasted corn and honey? High carbonation. Kind of bland, did nothing for me.

Bottle from Regional. Pours a nice deep amber, off white head.
A quite interesting nose, biscuity malt with undertones of fruity esters. 
A pleasant biscuity malt initially, with a nice subtle bitterness which mingles with a subtle fruit nicely. Finish is slightly dry, biscuity.
A very nice lager, more complex than usual  when warmed to ale temps.
Amber pour with an off white head. MIld aroma. Thin body with a weak malty start and very mello, dry, balanced hops finish. Very good.
This is the best beer that I ever have tasted, should be served cold and the taste is excellent, could not be better.

Bottle
This is generally a winner. Mild hops, medium malt. A bit light overall. A bit watery actually. Id prefer a more malt finish. Something to beef up the flavor profile a bit. A good overall beer.
Pours a beautiful orange with little head.  Has a clean, crisp smell.  Has a light citrus note with no aftertaste.

Translucent amber with generous white head. Nose is hop citrus (lemon), and very metallic. Overall, a malt focus on the palate, with caramel, very smooth body, and the hops have a dry, grass/earth character that is what reminds me of this beer every time. Finish is dry, crisp, refreshing. Drinkability is over the top!

BOTTLE. Subtle, nice, inoffensive in every way.
Ssort of like that girl you have pleasant memories of, but dont remember her name. Bud drinkers will likely be impressed that a beer as inoffensive as their usual brew can actually have some flavor. BUY AGAIN? Nah. But wouldnt refuse one at a party.

Pours hazy amber thin white head low retention. Aroma is slightly floral, but pretty weak. Flavour isVery smooth, malty, dry and slightly hoppy. Pretty subtle but very nice. It is not very exciting but still very good. Im drinking it for the style point and as "uncommon" as this style of beer is in Alberta it sure isnt something to get very excited about.
A golden brown beer with little head. A mild malt aroma. The taste is mild with a small taste of hops at the end. This would be a good starter beer for someone getting into craft from macros.

A refreshing, light ale. Pours mid-copper with a moderate head. Has some crystal malt aroma and light hop aroma. Pretty light on the palate, ntohing special really. For some reason I wasa expecting a bit more fromt his beer, seeing as it has such high status in the USA.
US trip Aug/Sept 2009 - Pint, clean aroma, some light malt notes, refreshing beer if slightly insipid
There was something really off about this for me.  Too metallic in the aftertaste.  Unimpressed.

12 oz bottle.  Pours lightish orange amber with a large white head and strong head retention.  Sweet biscuit and bread aroma with honey hints.  Caramel flavor with biscuit, a honey sweetness, and some iron.  Not too exciting, but nicer than I was expecting.

Bottle. Pours crystal clear red, with a thin off-white head, poor lacing. Nose is soft hops, mild malt and citrus, a lovely honey character. Flavor is peppery hops, soft flower petals, firm but simple malt. Tasty but a shade dull.

It took me a while to find this beer and was a bit dissapointed. dark bronze appearence with a vanishing head. smells slightly hopy a bit sweet and malty with a high fizz. nothing really different or special about the beer.

Lighter copper colour with a fluffy white head. The aroma (as well as the beer overall) actually reminds me more of some strong polish beers I had, quite woody and whiskyish with evident spicy, herbal hops. The flavour is characterised by a creamy caramel maltiness and a spiciness of anise and bark, funnily almost "warming". Leaves an overall hoppy aftertaste with a medium bitterness. A little too light and a little too much carbonation on the palate. Quite interesting and well crafted, just not my type of beer.

Poured from a 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

The color is a brownish amber with a thin white head. No lacing

The smell is sweet, somewhat sugary flavor. Also has a bit of a grainy or bread feel.

The taste is a bit malty as first some dry hop flavor. There is some earthy feel to this beer as well, some floral hops and slight fruitiness as well.

This is one pleasant beer. Crisp and clean, with a light drinkable feel and no aftertaste detectable. A great year round beer.

UPDATED: OCT 4, 2009 Nice dark color with a decent, lasting white head. Bitter and hoppy with a dry finish. Had some other tastes in there I cant quite describe. Very balanced. I had this when warm and it was still pretty good. A good beer.
Clear deep amber color with a creamy head and a sweet malt aroma. Wheat flavor that was a little nutty and had a bit of honey as well as a pleasant hop bitterness.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2015 12 oz. bottle from Bottled; re-rate from years ago. Aroma: Toasty, butterscotch glazed bread; almost reminds me of an Americanized maibock, but with toned down alcohol. Bitterness is light, and there are some light fruity esters (maybe raisin) present. Appearance: Dark copper color with solid carbonation holding up a sticky tan head, which fades into a patched skin. Flavor: Butterscotch is met with a surprising (compared to the nose) bitterness up front; the finish leaves a little lingering sweetness and toast notes. Palate: Medium body, creamy texture, average carbonation, lingering finish. Overall: Really, this still holds up. Its different enough to be interesting, and flavorful enough to be satisfying.

UPDATED: DEC 6, 2016 Pours a clear tawny with a medium head, off-white head that doesnt retain very well. Has a lager type aroma with pale malt and English or German hops. The flavor is nice and crisp, with a well balanced mix of malt and hops. Medium bodied with a lightly bitter finish and tingling carbonation. Not mind blowing, but decent.

Poured from a 12 oz bottle.  Pours a copper color with a big, white foamy head.  The head disppears quickly, but it leaves light to moderate lacing.  This beer has a nice aroma; nice blend of malts and hops.  This is a very handsome beer, as it pours well and looks nice in your glass.  The flavor is much like the aroma; a nice blend of malts and hops.  This beer has a medium body, and is nicly carbonated.  Somewhat dry, but very nice overall.  Somewhat difficult to find for me, and a bit pricey at $9.99 per six pack, but worth it every once in a while.

Drank this in a bar in San Francisco. I heard a lot about this beer and I was a little disappointed. Amber/gold, hazy, small head. At first fruity but the bitterness sets in quickly. Dry aftertaste. Too dry in my opinion.
Pours light amber gold with a big white head.  Aroma is light bready pale malts.  Flavor is light, with dry pale malts and a little bit of grass.  Not bad, but not that great.

tap: BVs: had this before, never truly appreciated it... pours a honey/ brown/ copper leaving a very thin head layer.  The nose is light, some malts and sugars.  The palate is thin... just enough hops and malts to keep you interested, but not enough to give full body.  Light, sweet, perfect with a burger.
UPDATED: JUL 31, 2010 Copper pour with white head. Malt smell with hops. Flavor is malt and hops with a little bitterness to it. Not too bad, but not great. "

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2010 Have had this from the bottle and on tap a few times.  Big barley malt flavor; quite rich and pretty tasty!
Re-rate 10/10/10.  Sweet caramel apple aroma that hints on yeasty.  Sweet burnt caramel apple flavor that finishes with just enough dry kick to ask for another sip.

Appearance is a copper color with medium head, good retention and lacing. Carbonation looks high and pretty.

Smell is oddly weak, I get a light fruity scent, too light to pinpoint. This gets a bit better as the drink warms, but never shows any strong characteristics.

Taste is interesting with a (very light) minty hop flavor. Hops become more pronounced in the aftertaste, but by no means is this a hop bomb. Very balanced.

Mouthfeel is good with a medium body and carbonation.

Id absolutely buy this again, this is a great session beer.
33cL bottle. Pours amber with decent head. Bread yeast aroma, nice body. Nice hops, could drink for long periods. Classic americana.

Light copper color with a medium off white head. Very sweet caramel aroma and flavor with hints of grains and hops. Has a very rich and malty body with a slightly bitter finish. Overall an impressive brew.

It poured a hazy amber liquid with a thick medium sized foam with some craters. It left just a little bit of lacing though.

It had a fresh smell of pine needles and citrus. 

It had a medium body with some citrus but also a bit bland. It felt stingy in my mouth. IT feels like its lacking something. It got some bitterness but not in a hoppy kind of way, more like overboiled tea. An ok beer.
Tap. Copper pour with attractive head. Bready nose. Flavors of biscuit, sourdough, orange peel, and sea salt. Mild assertive hop  finish. Great session brew.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2014 Rerate for @coopwinespirits February Discovery bag - More hop profile than I remember last time. 7-4-7-4-15

Bottle. 4.9%. Clear copper pour with a moderate white foam, medium retention, some lacing on side of glass. Aroma is light, citrusy, grainy. Taste is quite smooth, toffee sweetness and barley and grains, light hops. Finish is surprisingly bitter tasting given the sweet aroma, but smooth enough to have you reaching for another.  7-4-7-3-14
12oz bottle. Pours a nice clear copper. Carbonation bubbles last for a long time. Malty flavor with a nice bitterness. Very pleasant, drinkable beer.

An interesting beer, Ive only ever had it in bottle form but always an enjoyable pour. pours a very clear golden color with romas hinting of citrusy hops, a bit of malt body that produces a very quaffable beer.
Extremely full body and flavor that lasts on your taste buds.  I was first introduced to this beer on a trip to San Francisco and have been a fan ever since.

On tap at Zacharys in Tucson. Pours a relatively clear amber with significant amounts of very fine white head.  Aroma is of citrus and a little hops.  Flavor is rather similar, and the aftertaste is pleasantly of toffee or caramel.

A: Poured with an average-sized, white head that diminished fairly quickly to a thin lace. Some slight lacing on the side of the glass. Body is a very nice copper color, and slightly hazy.

S: Interesting... seems to be some caramel in there, along with some citrus (orange? lemon?)... light hops in the aroma as well. Quite pleasant.

T: Definitely as interesting as the smell... not quite like anything Ive had before. Again, the caramel comes out at first, but then it finishes slightly bitter and dry. I can still detect the citrus in there as well, and maybe some herbs/spices.

M: Medium-bodied and thin-textured, but still some slight creaminess coming in as well. Good carbonation.

D: I could have several of these... they go down quite easy, but still really wake you up with their unique taste. Wish this was more readily available around here!
29.06.2007, 0,355l Bottle. Amber colour. Aroma is malty. There is a nice bitterness in this beer.

Bottle. Pours crystal clear amber coloured with a big fluffy egg white head that leaves nice lacings on my glass. Beautiful. Aromas of caramel, spicy hops, fruit and cereal. Malty flavour with a nice amount of hops. Notes of grass, caramel and bitter orange peel. Really easy drinkable and smooth.
Aroma is of hop with a lot of head.  Taste is very hoppy with bitterness.  Very smooth and balanced.  I would drink this beer anytime.

Pours pure copper with standard white head. Aroma is light and includes malt, and honestly, I cant get much else. Thats not to say the malt is strong. Flavor is grainy, some malt, some hops at the end. Crisp and carbonated. Its odd to think since its a staple, but this is actually one of my least favorites from Anchor.

(bottle). Clear, light amber color. Medium off white head which is mostly diminishing. Rich malty aroma. Light malty flavor with a very light bitterness. Avg duration. Smooth finish which is slightly dry. Thin texture. Soft carbonation. Fair lacing.

Pours a very nice Frothy Head with an Amber/Copper. Aroma is fruity and hoppy. The Flavour has a metalicy watered down flavour but a great roasted malt finish. Medium to Thin body/mouthfeel but a delightfull balance of biter hop to malt sweetness make it a good choice for sipping or to have with food.

12oz bottle.  Pronounced and lasting bitter finish.  Nearly round flavor, it comes across a little top heavy, maybe not enough malt to provide a solid base for the hops.  The aroma is mostly malt and the flavor is mostly hops.  Would like more proper hop flavor and not only bitterness.  The malt flavor is a delicious vanilla cookie with a caramel center, the bitter hits the back of my mouth with some aggression (theres even some tingling on the roof of my mouth).  The flavor is becoming more balanced as I work through the glass.  Yay beer!

Uno dei classici della Anchor, finalmente assaggiato, ha un carattere molto simpatico, estremamente beverina e con un bellamaro tuttavia non sacrifica complessità allaltare del qul. Cè scritto che riprende una tradizione birraria antiqua, però allo stesso tempo dice letichetta "The brewing methods of those days are a mystery"..tuttavia non importa, probabilmente è meglio che rimangano un mistero, perché questa birra è buona così comè fatta oggi, ed è meglio conservare le cose buone. La tipica cosa che non mi stuferei mai di bere, soprattutto con questo caldo enorme

Bottle. Copper color with dense white head and ample effervescence. Aroma of grain, light malt and spice. Sweetgrass predominates in flavor with a barely-there fruity backbone and very light spice, little bitterness. Finish and mouthfeel are crisp and clean. I wasnt overly impressed with the flavor and aroma of this one but I would drink it over most lagers any day. Looking forward to a second tasting to boost my perception.

Pours pure copper with standard white head. Aroma is light and includes malt, and honestly, I cant get much else. Thats not to say the malt is strong. Flavor is grainy, some malt, some hops at the end. Crisp and carbonated. Its odd to think since its a staple, but this is actually one of my least favorites from Anchor.

Ive been saving this once since last fall, since I picked it up at a 7-11 in San Francisco,  and it tasted a helluva a lot better than the first time I had it (1976!).  Maybe my tastes have changed (for the better)...  This one comes with a sweet label, pouring a nice, rich copper colour, and it is well carbonated.  The head is on the small side, being a foamy tan.  The aroma is lightly malted.  Taste is again lightly malted, being crisp and clean.  I also liked the mouthfeel and aftertaste.  If only this stuff was more easily come by where I live...
Poured medium amber @ brewery, malty, grainy, caramel, hops, little corn, little friuity.
355ml bottle from the LCBO.  Pours a dark red with a white head.  Pleasant bready aroma, and a very malt forward flavour.

Bottled.
Amber with white head. Aroma of hop spices and lots of red berries and fruit. Flavor is malt, fruit and some caramel

I had a six pack of these one night, and a few hours later they were all gone! Was it the half-decent aroma, the just-allright pour? Theres a nice dark maltiness going on here, and its eminently drinkable stuff. Perhaps -too- drinkable..... where did they all go?

22 oz bottle, as Fourth of July 2009 drew to a close.  Pours reddish amber with a good sized, long lasting white head.  Taste is understated, with notes of malt, caramel, and hops.  This is my first try of a California Common, and the unique brewing technique is really evident.  There are subtle ale-like notes but its smooth enough to drink even in the heat, when you might normally want something lighter.  Good stuff.

Bottle, 355ml - Clear copper amber colored beer with a small off white head. Aroma is very sweet with notes of ripe fruits and spices. Flavor is spicy with malty notes and hints of corn, spices and caramel. Pretty good, but I havent really had any other California commons to compare it with.

Had it on tap in San Fran, really a treat.  Its a rich, tasty, dark beer.  Tastes very malty with a strong taste of caramel and some bitterness too.  Its nothing groundbreaking, but its very drinkable and very tasty.
This beer has a fruity malty aroma. Flavor of caramel, malt and brown sugar. Well balanced with a nice bitterness.
Red orange in color... Brown sugar and caramel aroma... Caramel malty flavor with a nice pale ale finish... Great beer... Always enjoyed this beer....

UPDATED: SEP 8, 2009 Pours amber with a nice but small dissipating head. Aroma is weak but pleasant, smells like a decent lager. Smooth and sparkling carbonation, fairly refreshing, could definitely gulp. Nice aftertaste which subsides into a slight bitterness. Decent flavours up front, good, not great.

Got this beer solely to rate the style.  I actually had this before with JRedmond, remembered I hated it but thought Id give it another shot.   Well, not a whole lot has changed.  Notes of corn and malt.  Thin palate.  Disappointing.

Bottle. Hazy orange brown in color, foamy white head. Fairly mild aroma, mild grassy hops, light malts. Not much carbonation, overall thin mouthfeel, relatively thin on flavor too. some bitter hops up front that linger throughout, also mild yeast, very mild malts. Drinkable, but not interesting.

35.5cl bottle from Systembolaget. Best before 2011-04-01. It poured a golden colour with a medium big white foamy head that settled down slowly in the glass. Aroma is grassy with some notes of malts and grain. The flavour is somewhat bitter, but not as bitter as most lagers. Flavour is grassy, notes of malts and hops. It has a short aftertaste. Overall a bit bland beer, but definately drinkable and it gets an extra point i appearance because I think the bottle looks cool.
Pours clear gold with a thin white head. Smells grassy with some roast malt. Taste is like corn and is pretty regular. Pretty nice body but taste is lacking.

Although this beer is just average overall, and Ive had numerous times over the years, it has become special to me due to my visit to the brewery in 07.  The tour, the copious amounts of free samples and the city itself has lifted this beer up in my book.  The beer is amber in color and very well balanced with some smooth malt and a crisp finish.  There really isnt much else to say about the beer, other than it is a good one.  A beginners beer.

12oz bottle from San Antonio Market (San Ann, FL). Pours a dark amber color with a thin white head. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of grain, light fruit, light chocolate, caramel, and some hints of floral hops. Flavor is sweet and malty with notes of wheat, grass, banana, spice, some hints of caramel, chocolate and floral hops. Generally medium body with a somewhat quick finish.

Bottle:  poured dark amber with a very nice medium head.  Smeeled of malt with sour notes.  Flavor was unremarkable except for a few of notes and a strong flavorless bitterness I didnt care for.  That said it wasnt all bad... just not a good drinker for me.

Anchor Steam is a crystal clear amber beer with a nice, dense, splotchy, off-white head that has great retention and leaves great lacing on the glass.  It has a malty, grainy aroma with spicy, fruity, wooden hops in the nose.  As it warms, the fruity, estery tones come out more.  Its not quite banana-- more like apple.  It has a smooth medium body with a crisp finish.  Its not sweet or dry.  It tastes a little spicy, with notes of bread, grass, clove and lemon rind.  Its perfectly balanced.  The bitterness is just enough to keep me thirsty for more.  This is pretty much a perfect session ale.

Almost orange beer with a quickly-dead foamy head.
The smells is very interesting with notes of cardamom, chocolate, strawberries and even some mandarin. Slightly alcoholic.
Bitter-sour with a fresh watery feel and lots of hops. Some spices.
First sip I thought Oh shit, here we go with another seriously sour ale, but no, the sourness dies away leaving a refreshing watery feel.
Bottle. Pours a clear amber with an off-white head. Aroma had some malts but somewhat nondescript. Flavor is nice with a nice start of malts and some hops later on. Very smooth as well.
Looks, smells and tastes pretty ordinary. Fizzy, bit of a bitter aftertaste. I seem to recall liking this more in the past.
Great summer day beer.  Whenever Im drinking Anchor Steam I never have just one.  But, for sitting down at the end of the day for a tall flavorful beer this isnt my first choice.
Deep orange-amber pour with a thinning white head, aroma is slightly malty, great mouthfeel and well balanced with hops and malt, finishes moderately dry... a very balanced and enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2015 Bottle from Systembolaget.
Pours sligtly hazy amber with a rich head.
Light malt aroma with a hint of sourness.
Refreshing and light malty taste.

This is a lovely refreshing style of beer and also my first time trying it. Relatively straightforward, but with enough subtlety and decent production to boost it head and shoulders above regular beers. Nice dirty blond/copper in the glass, not exactly lazy carbonation but just enough to keep it crisp and creamy at the same time. It has an immediate crisp attack which is fresh and tasty, taking you into malts, a touch of biscuit and then comes right at the end a lovely dry, floral hop finish which leaves you wanting more. Also it has a nice bit of length to the finish, which is slightly reminiscent of tea. Good effort. Look forward to trying the Liberty Ale!

bottle, pours a golden caramel color, no head, light carbonation. Slight toffee aroma.l Light mouth feel , metallic, caramel flavor. not enough body and depth of character for my taste, but I can see this as a very good easy drinking beer.

UPDATED: AUG 22, 2009 Pours a nice amber color with little white head not much aroma light malt taste with a very slight hop bite at the end its a decent brew very sessionable cant go wrong with this one
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2014 Bottle. This is definitely a great beer that you can just drink all day(drinkability with taste) especially during the summer.
A copper beer with a small off-white head. Bready and yeasty smelling. Fairly bland lager taste, a bit sweet with no hoppiness. Watery mouthfeel. Pretty boring beer, but Im not a lager guy.

on tap at metzlers in denton tx.  poured a gold with a nice white head.  aroma of malt, citrus, and some orange. flavor was the same with some bitter thrown in. body was medium with medium carbonation. not that bad at all.
Pours golden orange. Sweet malt, citrus nose. Flavor is malt forward, some citrus hops. Can kill a 6 of this easy.
Pours a fading off-white head with a golden orange body.  Smells of corn and caramel.  Tastes the same.  Slight bitterness on the finish.

UPDATED: MAY 26, 2009 Bottle. Clear golden with a thick foamy off-white head with great retention and good lacing.  Aroma is barley sugar, and a hint of herbal hops. Flavor is malt, some sugar and herbal hops with a long bitter finish. Medium body with a slightly creamy mouthfeel.
Bottle. Poured a copper color with a creamy off-white head. Aromas of caramel and floral. The flavor is much the same. Medium body that is sweet up front and slightly bitter in the end.
Thick creamy head. Banana aroma with a hint of spice and caramel. Vanilla/creaming soda notes. Hint of caramel, and a firmly bitter finish. Quite subdued - not sure this one travelled too well.

Bottle from World Market... Pours a dark golden with a thin white head..Smell is pretty faint just a little sweetness is all I can pick up...Flavor is somewhat bitter, again cant really pick up much. Kinda finishes like a german lager or a hefe.  Would drink this over a macro any day of the week and twice on sunday.

12 oz. bottle. Poured a beautiful deep amber with a small white head which lasted the duration of the drink. Very little aroma - almost nonexistent. Non-complex to say the least. Flavors of bitter fruits and hops; feel of malt. Very dry and not all that sweet. Flavor similarly non-complex. For a similar but superior beer I would go with Duvel Golden Ale. Anchor Steam is all around a decent brew with nothing offensive other than its uninterestingness. On the other hand, the label and bottle is beautiful.

Bouteille de 12 oz. Arômes de céréales, légère touche de houblon. Robe cuivrée claire, peu de mousse. Assez mince en bouche, un filet de caramel est accompagné par de discrets esters fruités et mène à une finale sèche et légèrement amère de houblon citronné. Très bien équilibrée et désaltérante.

Pours crystal amber with a marshmallow like head. Has a subdued hop nose and a dry hoppy taste with a crisp somewhat citrus like finish coupled with an unctuous residue. This beer is very crisp and refreshing, but not overly complex.
330ml bottle. Pours a light red brown with off-white head. Hoppy nose. Good hop taste and a nice biter finish. Nice beer allround.

As a California Common, this brew is a bit uncommon in the rest of the USA. Pours a clear amber with no head and little to no lacing. The taste is unique with refreshingly light fruit and malts. A pretty good beer, and one of the best that i had in this style. Though easily not the best from Anchor. LC
Bought as a novelty - its not too bad. Nothing very special, either.  Slightly malty, smooth and sessionable. Pretty neat for a novelty.

Overall Impression: 
Very drinkable amber beer with a slight orange taste
Pretty good overall beer has good body and good taste, good aroma. Good quality too
pours golden with a little head.  tastes of bitter malts. nothing special. poured out of bottle

She shines like polished copper in the clear California skies, glinting and sparkling with flashes of amber and orange playing tricks with my eyes. A puffy white head floats lazily atop her crown as if a cloud had fallen from the sky to perch quite happily there. Like a gentle summer breeze, her nose embraces me with fresh lemon and sweet honey warmed by the sun. Fresh dough, cereal grains, and malt keep her full-bodied and strong while maple, cinnamon, and summer fruits such as peaches and melons liven things up a bit. As tantalizing as her nose is, tis her brew that I savor the most and my first quaff is bright lemon juice and savory peaches and melon drenched in honey. A faint presence of bitter grapefruit and dry grass lingers in the back of her palate while a frothy mouthfeel makes way for a bready fullness of warm white bread and cereal grains. A growing bitter presence in her finish does not detract from her overall palate of peach skins, melon, and honey. Instead, their balance is perfect, and each refreshing quaff leads easily into the next until there is nothing left to savor but our treasured memories.


I could drink Anchor Steam any day, every day. It is easy to see how the thirsty hunters of gold quenched their hopes and dreams with this golden elixir that sparkled in the light of hope and promise. Anchor Steam Beer is a great doorway beer for the new and curious beer adventurer, and always a great fall-back for the tried and tested beer gourmand.
bottle.  pours amber with some head.  medium carbonation.  slightly malty, earthy bitterness.
An amber beer with a fine head. The aroma is slightly malty and the flavor is slightly acidic with a soft malty tone...it is what it is...
12 oz. bottle (2008). Classic beer in a classic style. Amber w/ a decent head. Nutty flavor w/ a peaty hops profile. Subdued finish. Nothing special, but a classic.
Have had bottles but lately its been on draft. Brown in color with an off white head. Aroma is sweet and taste has a slightly metalic odd bitterness. Not all bad, pretty drinkable.

Bottle, Rehills, Newcastle. A traditional tasting bitter, with a pleasant tanginess. Mine was well chilled, but still had bags of flavour.Good hoppy bitterness, slightly citric and put me in mind of a proper English bitter........

1 Pint, 6 oz. bottle, thanks Roei and Natalie. Medium sized fluffy dense lasting head. Clear rusty orange colour. aromas of peach, grapefruit and flowery notes. Strong subtle bitterness acompanied by notes of sweet grapefruit and orange marmalade. Aftertaste short and unimpressive, light to medium body.
Feels very much like a pale ale but with a strong hoppy flavours and aromas, and a strong hoppy lager bitterness.

12 oz bottle. Ive had this one many times, but never rated.  Simple light aroma but  appetizing. Notes of spicy, herbal grass, light citrus, a pilsner-like yeastiness, some caramels and pale grains as well.  Poured a decent creamy, milky white head, decent retention and almost no lacing, light but not watery looking, mild carbonation, and golden amber in color.  This beer overall has a good uniqueness too it, though theres really not that much going on, just different than other beers.  Quite crisp, not overly carbonated, light-medium feel.  Fairly bitter with some light herbal and slightly spicy lager grass, then more a minor citrus zest in the finish.  Some type of gourd fruit is in there as well, caramels, and light pale grain.  Overall, a good beer without much flaw, it just isnt that special.  It will continue to be one of my first recommendations to my non-beer nerd friends who are looking to try something a little different at a bar.
Bottle.  Light pumpkin brown pour and a nice malt aroma.  Flavor was oats, some citrus and finished smooth and light.  Been a while since Ive had this, I forgot how good this stuff is.

UPDATED: APR 10, 2010 Pours a clear brown with a thick white head. It has a sweet, malty aroma. The taste is of sweet, mildly roasted malt that finishes dry and slightly hoppy. It has a moderately thin mouthfeel and is fairly heady. Overall, its a good beer, but still a bit bland for my liking.
light sweetness, lightly sour, medium bitterness, light body, thin feel, flat,
Copper pour with medium white head.  floral bitter aroma and flavor. Solid finish.
Bottle Pour.Amber/copper color with a good white head.A nice floral and spice aroma.Taste was moderately hoppy with a roasted malt finish.Good beer.
Pours decent copper colour, with a good white head.  Taste is a fairly sugary sweet start, moderate ammount of malt and a mild hoppiness.  A little metallic in the finish.  Enjoyable beer though.
Pours clear copper with a fluffy tan head. Sweet and slightly sour malt aroma. Similar flavor, but with a toasty sort of finish. Not bad, but didnt do too much for me either.

(bottle) pours a clear bronze colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of bread, sweet spices, caramel and floral hops. flavour is the same, with a bitter, fruity hoppy finish. medium body with high carbonation.
Nice amber color. Big thick head. Taste was bitter, but also citrusy. Very good beer overall.

Bottle pours reddish-amber with thick, creamy head and thick lacing. Aromas of caramel and brown sugar with light hop balance. Flavor has a crisp, hoppy start with a long malty finish of bread and roasted malt.

Pours amber with large white head and nice lacing. Flowery and spicy hops dominates the aroma but some citrus notes are present as well. Flavor a bit unbalanced towards the bitter side with spicy hop flavor and a long lasting bitter aftertaste.

Pours an off-orange color and a decent head forming.  Smells of hops and light malts.  The flavor is mostly bitter with not much else coming through.  Theres not much of a quality hoppy character, just bitter.
Standard amber beer. Funny aftertaste. Id have to try it again to get a better impression of it.
nice amber color with pleasant aroma.strong flavor, citrusey and toasty. not great aftertaste. overall decent beer.

nose of light, floral perfumed hops.  flavor is well bittered, lightly skunky and a touch sour -- all of which lead to (ironically) great refreshment.  body is well carbed and dark gold.  mouthfeel is slick and a bit prolonged but ends nicely dry.  as tasting continues, a well developed malt note becomes apparent.

Pours a slightly hazy orange with a big white head. Aroma is hoppy, with caramel and apple. Tastes like a chalky apple and caramel. Some mineral in the finish of this beer from the high alpha hops. Mouth feel is pleasant and so is the beer. Very malty, almost chewy. Decent.

slightly hazy gold, big fluffy off white head, lots of lace.  mild malt in the nose.  mild flavor of slightly musty malt, sweet tones, finishing milfly bitter.  medium body, bitter finish.  the mild, mild aroma is deceptive of the pretty impressive bitter finish. 6 pack from liquor depot in monee.

12oz bottle pours an amber liquid with white head which gradually diminished. The aroma is of malt and hops but rather subtle. Taste is bitter, some malt. Drinkable but too bitter for me. I had this beer years ago, and somehow my expectations were that it was better before.
Pours a dark reddish color, with a faint nose. Light hops grass and malt . Taste is about the same, but a bit overcarbonated, with a somewhat bitter end. I seem to remember this beer being better.

Pours a five finger white head that fades very slowly, leaving a good lace. Crystal clear amber color. Light-medium carbonation and medium bodied. Slight hoppy nose. Flavor is more hops than malt but has some sweetness. Smooth. Light bitter finish. $2.15 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, Ma.
12 oz bottle. Pours a one finger, off white head with a slightly hazy golden brown color. Smells of hops and malts. Fizzy mouthfeel, with a crisp and refreshing taste with a lightly hoppy bitter end.

Props to the concept and  stuff.A decent beer when all the fireworks and applause dies down. Not wild.The malt does taste steamed .Like someone steamed the malt with an iron.Biscuty ,caramel and dustiness.To me this is like a decent UK bottled beer.Where is the American accent ?Sorta too mellow and rigid or something.
First of all, the copper color is very nice and it maintains a frothy head. It tastes a like a pale ale, but with a  bit more malt backbone. I think its a bit too sweet for my taste

A real looker this one. A strong, wholesome brown. Cute little bottle and label too.  
Very sweet on the nose with twitches of acidity and some thick frutiness. Something to compare it to would be a lightly toasted hot cross bun with slatherings of unsalted butter. In the mouth it is heavily mangoed but keeps a crispness aided by its spikey carbonaton. It holds some lovely caramel and toffee flavours though it comes off a little too sweet to be perfect. An interesting and drinkable beer with good malt characters.
Pours a caramel color with a small off white head.  Aroma is caramel, malt, bread, hops and spices. Flavor is spices, hops, crisp and clean and crisp with a bitter finish.
Wow, I thought with all the accolades I have heard ( and price) this would be better.  Good, decent beer with nice copper color.  Was it worth the 10 bucks I paid for a 6=pack....NO!
Pours amber with a thick, creamy white head. Aroma of light malt and bread. Light bodied with a good balance of hops and malt. Very crisp and refreshing. Very clean finish. Extremely drinkable.

First off, beautiful color.  Pours golden-copper with a thin-to-medium head.  Nice floral, hoppy, and citrus component on the nose.  Finish is long with hops and malt.  This is very good beer, but nothing really distinguishes it as unique or special.  I can drink these all day, but it would get pretty boring.

bottle. when poured it had a good amber color to it and quite a head, though the head quickly disappeared. lots of carbonation. wasnt sure what to think of the first taste, though after a bit it seemed a bit too bitter, a bit like an IPA. I will say it tasted better after warming up to room temp, all in all a decent brew i will be trying more from this brewer
Draught. Look: Amber with creamy white head. Smell: Nothing special. Mostly malt. Taste: Refreshing. Malty with a touch of citrus hops. Overall: Nice beer but the beer is not as good as the legend.
Bootle. Apperance; Amber with a small light brown head. Not to much aroma and flavor, some malt.

On tap at In de Wildeman. Clear light amber colour, creamy light orange head. Aroma of caramel/toffee, biscuit and a little hops. Flavour is toffee, malts, with a dry bitter finish. Mouthfeel is prickly, adds to the bitterness, but also gives it a certain sharpness. Medium bodied.
This is what a smooth crisp beer should be, this is what Coors and Bud should take a queue from.  I could drink these all day long, crisp, refreshing, interesting flavor, great session beer.
bottle..amber.small cream head..flavour is strong throughout..nice fun beer thanks to anchor

[Look]: Amber copper color with a nice creamy head. 
[Smell]: Very malty in the nose, hint of earthly and grassy. 
[Taste]: Tons of wonderful flavor to my palate!!  Toasted bread, caramel sweetness, mild bitterness, hint of citrus and earthliness.  Very creamy mouthfeel.  Finish off very smooth bitter and sweet.   
[Overall]: One of my all time favorite beer!!
Not my fav but ok.  Kinda boring.  Good beer to start off the night or to get someone away from Bud.  Try it see what you think.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2011 Dont remember much about this one...only that I didnt enjoy elements of the taste.  Perhaps that tells you all you need to know. 2.0
RE-RATE 3/24/11 Bottle from World Market.  This beer pours a very clear bright orange color with a lovely foamy head.  The head sits calmly upon the beer and doesnt dissipate quickly at all.  Lots of carbonation bubbles are rising from the bottom.  Looks appealing.

The aroma is heavy on the grains with some light fruit esters and a touch of hopped bitterness.  Smells fairly smooth however.

The flavor is very dry upfront, with bitter grains and a slight touch of fruit.  Slight banana esters.  This is very dry and grainy.  Bitter flavor and bitter finish with some tastes of copper.
Fairly malty beer....aroma is mainly caramel and toffee. Flavor is very similar, with some hints of hops and a bitter finish. Not to bad, but nothing great.

This beer was a wonderful surprise to me.  Nice sweet aroma from an amber colored pour.  The taste has one of the best transitions between an initial sweet maltiness and a well-balanced hoppy finish.  Great brew.
Cloudy amber pour with a minimal off-white head. Spicy aroma and a little malt and some hops. Flavor is a little spicy, but watery. Not my favorite, but OK.

Poured brown and clear. Moderate head. Smelled and tasted of rather boring malt. Thin body. All around boring, but quaffable. Id take it over most anything served in average restaurants, but overall just not worth going nuts about.

Bottle. 100508 at Cardinal Stavanger.
Pours very eager from the bottle, deep golden with a big white head. Aroma of raisins and yeasts. More mild soft taste of caramel. Hoppy end.
Bottle. Pours a light amber color, little white head. Nice light malt aroma, with bigger hop and citrus notes.  Taste is light, not a very big body, a little thin.  Nice matly and hop balance though.

In the 60s and 70s this was definitely the best California beer and among the best in the US.  Weve come a long way baby.  Amber with off-white head.  Has a nutty taste with some citrus.  Does not finish as well as the top beers do today, but still plenty good enough to drink.  Better on tap in my opinion.  And it can bring back the memories.
smells like malts, tastes very balanced in a different way than american ales. different hop flavor more bitter than hoppy. better drank very cold.

Pours a perfect amber with a tall pillowey beige head that has great retention. Aroma is caramel, biscuit, blood orange, planty hops. Flavor is biscuity, a little caramel, floral hops, a hint of bitter lime, grainy malt and some bitter hops with a sort of dry biscuity flavor at the finish. A fairly simply but highly enjoyable beer.

UPDATED: MAR 6, 2009 On tap at overpriced bar at San Francisco Airport.  Pours dark amber with a decent off-white head.  Sweet, malty aroma that gives a pretty good idea of the taste.  Biscuity malts, a little bit nutty, like oatmeal cookies.  Mild bitter finish.
Bottle.  Amber color with off whitish head. Aroma: Floral, malty. Flavor:  Decent flavor but a little too much bitter for my taste
Draft and bootle. Multiple tastings.  I have always been a fan of Anchor Steam.  One of the better lighter beers out there. Nice color, hint of citrus and good hoppiness.
Pour is a clear copper with a thin white, quickly dissipating head. Easy drinking. Malty with a dry finish. Simple and good.

355ml bottle from the LCBO
Pours a nice coppery amber with a good sized wite head some lacing
The arom is sweet caramal malts
The taste is earthy malt with a dry bitter finish
Pretty good

Pours a root beer color with a copper hue, an off white head with lots of lacing and carb action.
A sweet malt smell with a mild citrus hops aroma.
The medium bodied sweet malt taste is smooth with some mild hop esters and soft carbonation.
Very drinkable as a session beer.

Bottle at Old Chicago in Peoria, IL.  Poured into pint glass.  Amber color, tight head.  Very malty and a tad touch of nuttiness as well.  Ill be getting a sixer of this very very soon.  A more thorough re-rate will follow.
BOTTLE: copper pour with a large white head. Armoa is earthy and citrus, taste is malt and biscuit with some carbonation. Pretty good.
Lemony lighter beer, an amber that is a bit malty and hopped, comes across as a citrus earth palate, but an above par light beer, better than a simple lager.

(Bottle from Tescos, Diss) Appears dark orange/amber with a a good white head. Smells light fruit, citrus and earthy. Tastes hop-heavy with a bitter lemony finish. Sweet caramel evident in taste just before the bitterness kicks in, just enough sweetness to balance the bitterness out. Pretty good, really refreshing and brilliantly bitter for such a relaxing end of the day beer. Can see these becoming a great substitute for regular lager.
Deep amber colour, very thin head. Aroma of malt and hops smells syrupy. Unusual flavour has some hops.
Bottle in SF.  Most probably your first steam beer.  Pours a golden copped body with a white head.  Light citrus and floral notes, sweet with a thin malt body.  Nice bitter finish.  Good brew.

Pours a copper color with a thin white head.  Smells of biscuit, citrus and hops.  Taste is bready with some bitterness - lots of carbonation.. a little too much for my taste.  Decent beer but I prefer their Liberty Ale over this one.
Golden orange color with a small white head. Aroma is of malt and caramel. Taste is of sweet malts, light hops, and biscuit.High carbonation.
great aroma of malts with bitter finish!!!! i did not get a good look at the color.
Aroma is slightly doughy.  The taste is interesting, it starts sweet and ends bitter.  Pretty good beer.
smells like malt and toffee. it pours a very nice red-orange with a lasting head, it tastes like rich malt and toffee and is fairly dry. pretty nice, reminds me of paulaner salvator.

Been around for awhile, one of the more famous micros out there because of its history, but not one of my favs. relies on its bitterness for its taste, but doesnt back it up with a nice flavor. forgettable

Bottle. Pours a deep honey, with a decent bubbly and creamy head. Earthy malt and hop aroma. Grassy hops and malts dominate the taste. A slightly bitter finish. Not bad, though it may just not be my kind of beer.
Drank in a glass out of the bottle at OReillys. Good beer, not great. Nice bite, good hops, and nice color.

Bottle. Pours a crystal clear orange with a thin and brief, light brown, fizzy head. Leaves minimal lace. Aroma is mostly sweet malts with lots of caramel. Somewhat fruity, candy sugar, and a faint flowery hop spice. Flavor is a bit nutty and sweet dough initially, but quickly balances into a medium, but pronounced bitterness. Some sweet citrus flavors and a lingering bitter spice. Very unique hop rounding gives it a real rocky/hard body. Crispy seems like a good word. Almost feels like I can breathe out a little smoke after a sip even though there is no smokiness to it at all. Palate is medium to full and a good amount of carbonation. Very cloying and dry in the finish as well. Overall, I agree that its a bit overrated, but still a nice drinking beer with a good amount of enjoyable bitterness.
Amber color, lots of carbonation. Not too heavy but not too weak. Wish it was hoppier.

Apple dough nose.  Burnt gold, clear, frothy head.  Cotton candy malt sweet, balanced by solid bitterness.  Big carbonation, medium body, crisp bitter finish. Great beer, with clean elements of Pilsner and the flavor and depth of ales.
Amber pour with an off white head.  Aroma of sweet malts and some orange.  Flavor was mostly malts with some citrus at the finish.  Light body.

Had in a bottle at Bottlescrew Bills, Calgary, AB. Aroma of malts and citrus. A great taste of malts, graininess and sweetness. I find a slight alcoholly taste left in my mouth which perseveres. Otherwise, this is a good american beer.
A clear amber colored beer, with a bog beige head. The aroma is malty and spicey with caramel. The taste is dry and bitter with fresh fruits. The aftertaste is bitter as well.
pours  light amber with a little beige head. Very little malty aroma.  Flavor of sweet malt, breadiness, with a light bit of hops.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear amber with an average beige head that last throughout. Minimal lacing. Sweet, malty aroma with citrus hops. Taste is initially very sweet malt with a finish that is slightly sweet yet somewhat bitter. Medium body, nicely carbonated.
Tap at Johnnie’s in Highland Park.  The classic.  Smells like cereal, tastes refreshing but with a grainy heaviness, like ground rocks milling about in the beverage.
Poured a clear amber, minimal carbonatin, no head. Tasty bitter, slightly malty in the finish. Good beer.
Bottle. Pours a dark amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is breadlike with slightly malty.  Flavor is malty with a hoppy finish.  Pretty easy to drink.  Not bad.

Pours a nice amber color with and off-white 2 finger head. Good lacing. Pretty interesting brew, leaves a bitterness on the back of my mouth, which normally turns me off to a beer, but its not off putting to me in this one. This has a unique flavor. Has an earthy flavor to it with light citrus notes. but due to the bitterness, i probably couldnt drink more than 2 of these in a setting.

Pours a deep amber with huge, creamy head. Aroma is sweet and malty. Taste is fruity and mildly bitter. Not bad but not my cup of tea. Will not have again unless      the alternative is a cheap lager. C

Poured from bottle. Nice dark golden color. Nice head when poured but disappeared kind of quickly. Strong malt aroma and taste. I personally did not find it that complex tasting. A little bit bitter. Very nice appearance, but it seemed to lack something overall.

12 oz bottle. A pleasant surprise at a small liquor store. And a new style for my stats.Dark amber color with a decent head.Roasted malts, fruits and some smoke in the aroma. Roasted malt taste with some hops. Rather refreshing and enjoyable.

On tap at the BJs Restaurant and Brewhouse in Torrance, CA. Aroma is lisghtly spicy, hoppy with some maltiness in there. An amber color that is crystal clear and very little head. Flavor is toasty, biscuity and balanced with hop bitterness. Some woody, spicy notes from the hops. Balanced and a dry finish. Very drinkable. Complexity comes out when it warms a little.

12oz bottle.  Pours amber with a medium white head. Corny, bready aroma with a fair amount of malt  Taste is toasted malt with a dusty floral hops and a hint of citrus. Very creamy mouthfeel with a bitter finish. Light to medium body.
Malty, some hops in there, medium carbonation. Bit watery, but not bad as a pint.

Good old anchor steam, how have I not rated this one yet.  Malt and mild lager notes are upfront.   Suggests something good coming but never fully delivers.  Has notes of better beers, but is good in its own right.   My main complaint on everything Anchor does is that there is too much residual sugar for my tastes.  The mix in 25% wort and ferment that final amount under pressure to carbonate it before bottleing it, and it always seems to me like it should be less than that to make all their beers dryer.  Anywho, its famous and good for what it is.

UPDATED: MAY 13, 2009 I am not the biggest fan of California Commons, but this is reasonable stuff if not too exciting. Copper-brown color.  Very smooth and malty with muted hops. I do not know how some people pick out 10 different flavors in this beer - I do not find it that complex.  Very drinkable though.
Pours hazy orange-amber with little head. Strong malt with a hint of citrus and corn. This is a sort of beefed up American Ale with notes of Milwaukee. Not bad but not my favorite. Something lacks.
12oz bottle.  clear amber-copper color with a medium off-white head.  malt and honey sweet aroma.  quick dry taste with a rye vibe to it.  light tingly carbonation.  good thirst quencher. K7

San Franciscos Anchor Steam Beer possesses a medium amber hue with a dry but slightly citrus influenced flavor. Not very hoppy or bitter. This lager could serve as a  good alternative to a Sam Adams or Yuengling. An above average, but uninteresting brew.

On tap among a plethora of boring beers at at Croxley Rockville Centre.  Amber with lasting head and lace.  Mild caramel aroma.  Very milld toasty caramel with grassy bittereness.  Light watery body and medium carbo. Not sure of this cuts it anymore.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2008 golden brown color, highly carbonated, big great flavor that sais BEER.  some nuttyness, some hoppyness, overall great balance.  generous medium mouthfeel, with a moderate hoppy finish that lingers.  I will definitly be enjoying this beer again in the future.

Bottle Stirchley Wines Birmingham. This was probably the first US beer I tasted from a smaller brewery back in the early 90s. Slightly hazy amber colour with a medium off white head. Aroma was nothing to shout about. Muted dusty malt and hop.
Lack of real body. Bready flavour with caramel malt and corn notes. Not the greatest beer from the Anchor stable but passable.
Aroma of dough, very malty aroma... The richness of the aroma does not translate into rich taste.... Slighty hoppy, mostly malty.... Smooth, but i just dont understand the hype...
I enjoyed this beer very much.  Being from the east coast i had never even heared of the steam brewing process.  sadly the beer had old tatse which i chalk up to the store

355 ml bottle.  Pours a clear deep orange gold with a moderate but disappearing slightly off white head.  Light malty aroma with a hint of hoppiness.  Light toasty maltiness in the taste with a vague fruitishness and slight hoppy bitterness.  Light to medium body, buttery finish.  Solid though not overwhelming beer.

UPDATED: OCT 24, 2011 Re-rate 10/22/11: Bottle sample at a tasting at Dancing Camel. Thanks Dagan. Clear amber with a stable white head. Aroma of malt and fruits. Sweetish flavor with some malt and a finish with mild hoppy bitterness. Medium-bodied. Not so fresh. 5/3/6/3/12=2.9 (not calculated)

(10/26/08) Bottle sampled on the streets of Brooklyn. Slightly hazy amber with a big beige head. Aroma is rather malty with bready notes, light fruity hints and some hoppiness. Sweetish malty flavor flavor with light fruitiness, bread and a rather bitter finish with hops. Medium-bodied with a smooth mouthfeel. A nice easy-drinking beer. 6/4/7/4/13=3.4
Amber color with a thin white head that doesn’t last. it is sweet, malty, and citrusy. Nice summer beer.
Pours hazy amber color with a thin off-white head. Malty aroma with hints of citrus and honey. Dry fruity flavor with citrusy hops and yeast.

I remember this made a big impression on me when I first had it.  There was an interesting and unique sweet edge to it.  But that SF classic may have been a better beer than this one was.  Nice label and pour, but it looks better than it tastes.  It goes down like a decent lager or marzen.  But where is the subtle sweeetness I remember, and that my own homebrewed steam beer had?  There is a light hint of lemon and mild hops.  This can now go into the sad category of overrated classics.

Good brew.  Golden amber pour with thick, creamy white head.  Aroma is nicely balanced of biscuity malts and fruity, citrusy hops.  Flavor some of the same and great amount of bitterness.  Underrated big time.
bottle. does not have a real distinct aroma. pours a dark golden yellow with little head. bit of a tart, meatallic flavor. Easy to drink, but a very bland flavot. disappointig.

Bottled. Pours a clear copper body with a thin head with some lacing. Nose is banana, clove, maybe coriander, licorice, and citrus. Flavor is the same plus some sweet biscuit malt. A little too bitter and unbalanced. Not great but acceptable.

12 oz bottle. Poured a hazy copper color. Nose was light, with some noticeable malt flavoring. I think I need to re rate this when I get a fresher one, because this is one of those beers that is much better fresh, and does not improve with age.I remember this being a very nice malty beer, with some light hop flavor, but this staler one did not do it justice.

Bottle, bbe 12/08. Amber, small pale head.  Little honey, fruits and maltiness on the nose. Mildly hopped, dry fruity flavor, malts and little yeast. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Easy drinking and somewhat fruity, but didn’t feel very fresh.

Caramel colored pour with a long lasting head and sporadic lacing. The flavor leaves a lager-like aftertaste and has some mild but lingering hops in the body. Not bad but not near as great as its reputation.

On tap-Flying Saucer Cordova.
A nice deep amber pour.  A well hopped brew with a very satisfying mouthfeel/palate.

Not a bad beer, for a classic.  Pours a golden copper with a bubbly white head.  Has a strong aroma of roasted malt with flavor of hops and a bit of water.  Slightly lagery in the finish.  Respectable beer.

Poured gold with a nice head.  The aroma was very pleasant hops.  The beer was very clean, a good balance of hoppiness and it was definately a very drinkable beer.  This is a classic that would make a great session beer.

UPDATED: MAY 8, 2011 Pours golden with thick off-white lingering head.  Aroma of hops and a hint of citrus. Love the taste...hoppy yet refreshing; creamy and smooth yet complex taste.  Medium mouthfeel.  This is one of my favorites.
A nice crisp and clean tasting beer. Lightly malty, perfumy, citrus, with a clean, almost dry finish.

Big offwhite lasting head leaves coarse lacing. Reddish amber body. Roasty caramelly aroma with perfumy notes. Dry-sweet dense caramelly malty roasty taste with fruity notes. Sharpish mouthfeel, dense palate. Dry fruity spicy aftertaste with notes of harmonically mixed toffee and grapefruit. Nice, but not major. (0.355l bottle, Systembolaget, Charlottenberg.)
Pours a light amber color with a thin white head.  Aroma isn’t strong and doesn’t offer much.  Taste is honestly similar to Keystone.  Nothing special here.
Bottle.  Poured a clear amber/gold color with a creamy off white head.  Aroma of caramel malt and some slight hops.  Flavor of herbal hops and a clean mild bitter finish.

5/25/08: 12 oz
Aromas of light carmelly malt, herby hops
Amber color, some haze, off white head that persists
Light malt flavor, herby hop flavor, moderate bitterness, clean finish
Med-light body, med carbonation
Refreshing beer, clean.  Nice hop character with malt balance.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2010 ~Pours a clear light amber color with nice looking creamy white head.
~Mild hoppy scent, woodsy, low caramel.
~A woodsy oat taste with slight hop bitterness and an caramel sweetness withs ome fruity esters. Not bad but a bit harsh in finish. 
~Med body, med CO2, dry finish. 
~I really dont see anything special about this beer. I wont turn it down if offered to me, but most likely wont buy again.

I’ve just poured this into a proper beer glass. It pours a clear amber, with good head retention. The aroma is a bit skunky, but the flavor really does this beer justice, just like the description of a california common says, it’s a pils, witht the heart of an ale. \Cheers!

12 oz bottle pours a light amber with big dense head.  Toasted and bready, caramel aroma.  Sweet caramel maltiness up front with hop bitterness following.  Slightly cloying hop flavor.  Crisp and clean, but I find this beer better on tap if you can find it.

this had a amber color, a nice steady white with head with what i thought was heavy carbonation. not a bad thing in my opinion. and i have to agree with other fellow raters, very crisp hop taste i had this in a bottle.
bottle 355ml  6e at Janoinen Lohi 090908 EXP Dec 08 Color:amber Taste: first sip fruity malty kick of hops. Pleasant steamy aftertaste
Nice head and lacing, malty aroma with crisp hops taste.  Long phlegmy aftertaste.  Unique.
Had a half glass at my neighbors.  Amber pour with a decent all white head.  Aromas are dominated by clean hops and good malt.  Flavor is crisp and hoppy with good malts.  Pretty well done brew.

355 ml bottle. Clear amber orange colour, nice and thick off-white head. Malty aroma with a hint of fruits and hops. Caramel malts & some fruits in the flavour, grassy-hoppy finish. Not the best Anchor product I’ve tasted, but a nice beer nevertheless.
On tap in San Fran.  Nice amber color with small white head.  Nice blend of hops, malt, and a bit of fruit.  Decent moutfheel.  Good reliable brew.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2008 12 oz. bottle purchased at Total Wine in Kennesaw, Georgia.

Appearance: Pours an orangey-amber body with an inch of frothy, white head.

Smell: Mild caramel, bready malts with a savory spicy, peppery note and teensy weensy hint of berry fruitiness.

Taste: Lightly bready, lightly caramel-coated maltiness. Not much sweetness. Tiniest bit of fruit -- watch out or youll miss it. Tiny touch of acidity. Spicy, peppery hops, maybe a small pinch of lemon zest, too. Medium-low bitterness. Finishes dry and quite crisp.

Mouthfeel: Medium-thin body. Medium carbonation.

Drinkability: Paired quite well with the film Karate Kid playing in the background. A fine, drinkable brew all around that appeals to my session beer sensibilities.

Pours a deep coppery colour with a very thin head, that’s practically non-existant.  Smells very thick and caramelly.  Taste is very sweet.  Not much hops, but a lot of sweet malts.  Carbonation is very low, in a very nice kinda way.  It’s actually pretty reasonably thick.

Color is deep golden amber with small, creamy and thick, off-white head. Fresh aroma is caramel malty and hoppy with a hint of berries. Flavor is bit smoky, hoppy, caramel malty with very obvious metallic hints in finish. Medium-bodied and very smooth, foamy carbonated palate.

Bottle 8JD. Long time drinker, first time rater. Slight rum aroma. Clear amber color. Considerable zing to it, mostly because of the overly assertive fizz, but also due to hops. Body is caramel or honey with some citrus at the end. Nowadays, I think it’s perhaps more interesting than good.

Pours bright deep amber into a shaker.  fluffy pancake head with excellent retention leaves spider lacing as it slowly recedes. Clean malt aromas.  Crisp with sweet caramel upfront and a dry, lasting sour hop finish.
Taste 9/8 Bottle(8JK).  Looks Copper, off white head. Aroma: Very mild fruit and grain. Taste: Clean and dry, with a neat chewy body. Nice dry grassy and fruit  finish. Interesting.
Pours a clear amber with a shiny white head. Smell is sweet and nutty. Taste is similar to smell, well-rounded, with a slight bitter hoppy finish.

Pours a nice copper with a solid dense white head.  Aroma is somewhat hoppy with a malt backbone.  Flavor has a certain nuttiness about it but caramel & toffee are slightly more dominant.  Very refreshing...good session drinker.
How have Never rated this?  Anyways It was nice to re-visit a true classic  Clean crisp and refreshing beer.  Slightly fruity, citrus. and a light hop presence

12 oz. bottle. 35 years ago this was it, the best there was.  Pours a nice creamy head, pleasant golden brown color, mild non-spicy, non floral nose, crisp, clean palate with finishing moderate hop[ bitterness. Still a pleasant beer but no longer uniquely outstanding.
a very crisp refreshing beer.. a slight nutty citrusy flavor with a very smooth finish... no bitter dry aftertastes.. a definitely drinkable new found favorite
(Bottle).   Decidedly malty aroma.  Beautiful amber color with a decent white head.  Flavor is pleasing if ultimately underwhelming.  A bit nutty, and with some slight hoppy bite.  Mild dry finish.
Anchor steam beer is a great refreshing summer beer, but doesn’t cut corners on flavor either. Light orange with a smallish head, citrussy flavor. good to enjoy on a summer’s evening
Pours a dark shade of amber with a medium, foamy, white head. Tastes of malt, caramel, with noticeable but very balanced presence of hops. Very light body and drinkable. Good beer.

Light copper color, fading white head turns into just white film on top.  No carbonation in the glass.  Even malt and hop aroma that is somewhat floral.  Nothing unusual to the aroma.  The palate tends to the watery side.  Bitter flavor dominates the tongue.  There is an amount of malt in the beer but mainly its the hops that makes a biting IPA type Ale.  Just an average ale, perhpas this beer’s reputation was forged before the proliferation of craft beer in America.

UPDATED: NOV 13, 2009 Enormous white head pouring with a dark orange color. Not too clear in the glass but certainly not cloudy. The hops are powerful for a lager- could be a pale ale. Overall the body is rich but not filling like an IPA- very smooth and wickedly light. Overall tastes like melted butter. Aftertaste is dry. I really think that this is one of the great American brews and will recommend again and again. Keep it up guys!
Thanks to ghawener.  Pours a nice copper color with white head.  Light bodied, off balanced between malts and hops.  Bitter, hops are extemely predominant, long dry finish.

Bottle.  Mildly sweet malty aroma, nice copper color with a foamy off-white head.  The flavor and palate was dominated by the hops.  It’s pretty good, but something I would need to be in the mood for.  I’m thinking maybe a cool fall day.

12oz bottle.  Surprised I havent rated this yet, I picked one up to fulfill my California Common brew on the stats page.  Pours a clear medium amber a 2 finger foamy beige head.  Nose is caramel malt and mild citrus.  Taste is sweet caramel, toffee and bitter hops.  Medium mouth feel.  I remember trying this beer in the early 90s and thinking it was great, but really heavy and strong. HA!  It was compared to Keystone Light.  Good gateway beer and sometimes the best beer available.

Off white head. Dark amber colour. Aroma is malty, fruity (nuts) with caramel and light spicy notes. Flavor is moderately malty with dried fruits, light wooden and hoppy tones, ending in a prolongued, dry, hoppy finish. Medium bodied.
