UPDATED: AUG 29, 2010 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Kitchen, Helsinki. Slightly cloudy amber color, off-white head. Resiny hop aroma. Well-balanced bitterness with a touch of caramel. Wickedly smooth mouthfeel, light body. Very drinkable!

EDIT: sampled as a bottle. Malts seemed a bit more resiny, but the general experience was the same. Still a great beer.

12 oz bottle. Pours amber with a decent looking fine head. Smell and flavour are roundly hopped and roasted. Yes, I had it at a noisey ballpark from a plastic cup but it fell well short of it’s reputation.

Bottle. Aroma of yellow, orange, red fruits, pale/caramel malt, floral hops that blend in nicely. Flavor has a rich toasted character mingling with all the fruitiness and light hop bitterness. Full bodied but easy drinking and refreshing. Very nice beer.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2008 355ml Bottle. Light clear bubbly amber with large foamy off-white head. Light malt aroma. Pleasantly clean, crisp, dry taste with clean, dry aftertaste. Good maintenance beer for a hot thirsty summer day. Not as bitter as the Liberty.
Brown color white head.  Slight malt aroma.  Sweet malt taste with slight hop finish.  Good smooth beer.

Faint clean pale malt aroma. Clear light amber with small white head. Clean pale malt flavor with touch of caramel and slight bitterness. Light body and mouthfeel. Nice dry finish with low bitterness.

Darker color than I expected, not sure why because this is my first California Common . . . possibly my last if this is representative of the style.  Flavor is wet cardboard and the kind of sweet malt you might find in a bad Begian Dubbel.  Drinkable, but not by much.
bottle: a great gateway beer for the mass comercial lovers. try it; if this is not for you, stay away from the strong stuff. clean, strong and complex yet very drinkable a real session brew.
Thin white head atop a darker golden color.  Citrusy aroma goes well with the almost orange peel taste.  Sharp bitterness up front, almost smooth in the middle with bitter finished that hangs around.
Very enjoyable bottle from Super Tesco. Nice amber deep gold colour.  Good malty taste, slight citrus notes.  Good stuff.

Bottle.  Pours a clear amber with a nice frothy head with persistence.  Aroma is light and sweet, with some floral hops and bit of honey-ish sweetness.  Flavour is slightly bitter, with a slightly sweet finish reminiscent of apricots.  Overall, not as enjoyable or unique as the Liberty ale, but good nonetheless.

Tasted somewhere along my trip through the States.
Orange, amber colored brew. Enjoyable, but not very complex. Malty flavor. Nice hoppiness.
An outstanding bottle of suds.  Strong start with a clean finish.  It’s expensive, but worth every drop.
Draught @ the Yard House in Orange County with Mark and Beth.  Softy and Malty with grassy hops and complex flavours coming through.  Session beer all the way.

draught, Zeke’s. Orange, small white head that lasts fairly long, hazy. Layered aroma: grass, fresh grain, tree bark. Soft mouthfeel. Crisp, dry, refreshing, fresh-tasting, long hoppy finish, enough fruitiness to enhance body and character. Reliable.

I had a bottle of this at Phillips restaurant in Ocean City Maryland.  It poured a dark copper color with a small off white head.  To me it drank like a yuengling lager with just a touch more hops.  I really enjoyed this beer, but not near as much as the all u can eat seafood buffet.
Draft sample offered after the Anchor Brewery tour.  Pours a copper/amber color with a foamy off-white head.  Nice malt flavor with a hint of bitterness.
A very satisfying, drinkable beer with a good balance between flavor and thickness.  The unique bottle, depending on present company, will make you look either suspiciously festive or middle-aged.

Bottle.  Dark honey-gold pour, medium off-whtie head with good lacing.  Nose - soft malt, muscadine, pear.  Much more robust flavor than I expected.  Dark hops, smoky malt, and baker’s yeast.  Wonderful mouthfeel.  I love the soft yet heavy carbonation.

Copper body with a thin dissipating head.  Interesting aroma with some fruitiness and caramel.  It may sound odd, but when I opened this up, I thought I’d grabbed an Anchor Porter by accident.  Maybe it’s a character of the ingredients or something.  I wouldn’t think the yeast since this is supposedly done with a lager yeast.  Anyways, flavor is crisp, but with a kick of astringency that makes me recoil just a tad.  Goes down smoothly and cleanly with a dry finish.  Overall, an enjoyable beer.

A nice coppery orange color with a small but tight white head that has long lasting retention.  Sort of metallic hoppiness in the aroma.  Taste is nice and bready malts with that same noticeable metallic taste.  Good earthy hop finish doesn’t overpower.  I do like this beer, it drinks easy, but I’m let down by that macro-esque metallic flavor profile.
Deep orange with a nice off-white head. Malt and Grain, with a touch of caramel. Clean, ever so slightly bitter finish. Nice and refreshing.
Amber beer with a small head. Notes of caramel in taste and flavour. Nice long lasting aftertaste. Very balanced beer and very full bodied.

22 oz bottle.  One of the classics.  Faint malty aroma.  Pours a nice amber color with a somewhat persistant light tan head.  Rich, but muddled flavor of light roasted malt, a little nuttiness, some toffee, and a little grapefruit hop bitterness.
Malty aroma.  Deep amber color with a decent head.  Touch of bitterness in the taste.  Distinctive taste of California common beer.
UPDATED: NOV 11, 2012 Amber color with a nice malt taste. Starts and finishes fresh. A good, drinkable beer.

Bottle. Light notes of grain and caramel for the malt, herbs and pine for the hops, soap for the yeast, with faint smells of toffee and pepper. Head is creamy, slightly off white, with good lacing and is mostly lasting. Color is clear amber orange. Flavor starts lightly acidic and finishes lightly acidic and moderately bitter. Palate is light to medium, watery and has a carbonation betweenlively and fizzy. It finishes lightly astringent. Light in aromas and flavors, but what was there was pretty good.

In a bottle at Bazbeaux downtown. Poured into a tiny glass, fun! Deep gold color, minimal head that collapsed quickly. Smells and tastes like "beer."  A little more bitter than the usual but very smooth. Good choice if you feel like a plain old "beer" but want something tastier than a macro.

Incidentally, the pizza place has a decent selection of bottles including all sorts of domestic macros and imports. Surveying the tables, Anchor Steam was easily the most popular. A good sign for society, I think.

UPDATED: OCT 20, 2008 Solid but unspectacular beer. Good nose, mouthfeel is good, flavor is a bit bland but crisp and refreshing without tasting too watery. Some citrusy notes with a little bit of bitterness. Balanced beer.

Barley malt lager aroma.
Cereal, slight citrus (lemon peel).

Light lager flavor with hints of sweet fruit (apple, nectarine).   
Minor bitter hops in there as well.  Has a sweet nutty finish.

There is a roughness to the palate that I dig.   A full and tasty lager.

Beautiful copper color in the glass.  This is a great summer beer, it’s got a slightly sweet flavor with a hint of fruitiness, but it’s far from being overpowering in either dimension.  Medium body with a refreshing crispness and moderate to lively carbonation.  A  slight bitter astringency in the aftertaste balances the sweet attack wonderfully.
Bottle. Amber with off white head. Nice lacing. Malty aroma, bread, yeast and some fruity freshness.Taste malty and sweet, some caramel.
Poured to a thick head with aromas of hops. Initial flavor of hops and ended with a slight bitterness that reminds me of vegetables.
on tap at san fran airport. Golden with minimal head.  Aroma is hops with some underlying malt sweetness.  Balanced but unremarkeable flavor, but very drinkable.
Smell of hops/bread, two finger head that dissapears quickly, bitterness at the end that makes you want more, great summer beer. smooth finish
Pours light gold with a medium head.  Aroma is hoppy with a bit of malt.  flavor is the same as the aroma.  Not one of my favorites, but very drinkable.
From bottle. Bitter malt with caramel in the aroma.. Clear thin head. amber in colour. Great bitterness, honey and wood. Bitter tangy finish. Decent beer.
Nothing special, but certainly not bad by any stretch. A little bitter, a little malty.  Just a beer.

Maybe it’s different in the pouring rain of England as you Americans seem to like it, I was not impressed. Labelled as a Californian Common? A new one on me, showing my lack of geekiness. Will try it again and give it a chance. And I’ll try to get more of this style to make a decent comparison.
Decent beer. This was different but in a good way. Nice little brown color and lasting white head. Would probably drink again
Great!  Pours a super thick white foamy head, color is nice, deep and clear bronze.  Hints of orange and lemon in the flavor, finishes smooth, cleanly, and lasting.  Give this to me any day.  Thanks.

Pours a light copper color with a medium off-white head.  Aroma is sweet fruits and light hops.  Flavor is a nice balance of malt, hops and fruits.  Light to medium body with a very smooth mouthfeel.  Nothing particularly outstanding, but very good and easy-drinking.  A very nice summer or lawnmower beer.
Poors a clear amber with a tan head. Aroma of malts, sweet slightly hoppy flavor with brown sugar, vanilla & clove undertones. Refreshing flavor for a thin body beer.

Bottle. Had to try this one because of the name. Definitely an American classic. Pours an orange color with a light white head.  Light aroma, some citrus hops.  Has a simple flavor of malt and some fruit.  Light clean finish with mild bitterness.

Bottle. Orange amber color with tight head. Aroma of dried apricots, oranges, plums and slightly sulphury like burnt matches. Medium to thin body. Sulphury and a hint of burnt sugar. Fruit preserve. Clean dry bitterness in the end.

UPDATED: JUN 27, 2008 Appearance: Golden, good head.
Aroma: Nutty, honey and fruity.
Taste: Complex, loads of different tastes. Malty, citric.
Info: 355ml bottle, 16/9-2005, 14/300

Perfume/fruity/floral aroma. clear with a nice vanilla flavored head. Taste is okay but nothing out of the ordinary. could be the style in itself is boring, not sure ive tasted this style. Whatever they did, they did it quite okay, but far from what id expect for a microbrew/special brew.

UPDATED: SEP 25, 2008 Bottle. Orange/amber color with an off-white head. Aroma of sweet malt, caramel, fruitiness and a bit of bitter/earthy hops. Taste of toasted malt, frutiness, nuts, caramel, grain, citrus and some hop bitterness. Nice and highly drinkable.
amber color with large frothy head with srtong vanilla tones. Finished very smoothly. Not much of an aroma but a solid taste and finish.
Poured a nice amber color with a thin tan head. The taste has a little sweetness to it, but the malt really comes through as the dominate flavor.

A very nice beer for such wide distribution. The aroma was very muted because of over chilling, but did not seem bad or off. The appearance was a darker body with a very active head. The flavor was fine - a bit deeper than your average American pils. The palate seemed nice - it hangs on for a minute. Over all, not a bad beer, and a good alternative to many macros.

A brew that I have had dozens of times but now for an official review- 22 oz. bottle served in shaker- poured transparent brownish tan, low carbonation, white head after initial poured than transformed itself into a white ring around the glass after a few minutes.  Weak aroma of malt, bread, and charcoal.  Hits the mouth with a light-medium body, malt comes through cleanly, sweet note towards the backend, finish glides away nicely.  An American micro staple and classic.

Bottle and tap. You really can still find a surprise or two in California. It reminds me of the train that could, with or without the steam. An ale that might gets you "across the pond!" A slow finish.

THOUGHTS: California commons arent really my thing, but I liked this one. Nice and malty. A nice surprise in a California beer. Nice sweet aroma.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a clear, light to medium amber with a large, ever so slightly off-white head that mostly lasted and left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate Caramel malt and light citrus (lemon and lime) hops. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and acidic; while the finish was moderately  to heavily sweet, moderately bitter and sour with an average duration. There was nice caramel malt then slight citrus (lemon) and more herbal hops. Nice balance. The medium body was sort of creamy, slightly syrupy and a little dry with fizzy carbonation and a moderate astringent finish.

The beer pours a copper amber color with a thin off white head that doesnt hang around long. The nose is light with a slightly acidic malty flavor. The taste is clean with acidic malts and a very light hop bitterness. The finish is short but acidic and malty.
UPDATED: JAN 9, 2009 This beer is simply a delight. A great sipper as the Americans like to say. The flavour is everything one could wish for: delicate, classy; flawless. A great American beer.
Bottle. Malty in the beginning with hops in the background followed by a decent bitterness. An okay beer.
Pours dark amber with rocky off white head. Aroma of bread and some hops. Flavor is lighlty sweet maltls and some hop bitterness. Medium body with average carbonation. A decent session beer.

Pours a clear brown with some reddish amber notes. Aroma is sweet and malty and seems like it has a creaminess to it. Some hops are apparent as well. Flavor starts out with a malt crispiness, with some mild fruit that follows. Very creamy and smooth in the finish. Medium-full body and quite rich, this beer has a nice mouth feel and is pretty tasty.

12oz bott;e: pours a amber brown with a one finger off white head, aroma of onkly a hint of malt, flavor is what i would think an oak aged lager would taste like, good amount of malt with lots of wood flavor and a slight ale like fuity touch. decent beer but wouldnt buy again.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2008 Smelled like poop out of the bottle.  Nice color.  Malty malty malty with a Budweiser aftertaste.  Honkeybra tells me we got a bad bottle, got it on tap later on that night but Heineken skunked up my tastebuds, aight, and I couldnt tell.

Nice looking pour with moderate head medium bubbles. Tastes to me a bit thin short and bitter on the finish. Interesting beer but Im perplexed. as it warms a little there is some malt character. A very light beer I will try to get to know better but not an immediate favorite.
UPDATED: JUL 2, 2008 Pours amber with lasting head, bitter hops, malt, and a little frut, very balanced.

UPDATED: AUG 7, 2010 Reddish orange pour with a frothy off white head. Aroma  of light sweet malts and earthy perfumey hops. Flavors of light pine and citrus rind, dry...lightly sweet somewhat bready malt all pretty balanced. Medium body, lively carbonation, crisp, bitter, dry, malty with a malty finish that has a bitter kick  before its all said and done.

Update 08/10
This beer truly combines a nuance of flavor that I seem to see less and less of as hop-bombs, sours and high abv beers that continue to capture the interest of the craft beer world. Dont get me wrong, i love that stuff too, but this brew is something that falls few and far between: a brew that is delicious in its delicacy and balance. It tastes great on a hot summer evening or a cold winter night. It is the quintessential session beer.
Probably one of the best widely available beers.  Pours a dark tan, with a dense head and little carbonation. Tastes kinda like a stout watered down with a brown ale. Definitely one to pick up.

UPDATED: SEP 4, 2008 Nice pour with tall white head that disappears within a minute or two.  
This is a very clean and flowing drink.  Just a good solid beer.

[355ml bottle from Tescos, Reading] A remarkably large and lasting beige head belies the fact that this beer only has slight carbonation.  Theres a hint of malt, a hint of orangea hint of bitterness, a hint of sweetness, but overall not a great deal of flavour - feels rather weak and watery.  That said, the flavour that is there is well balanced and works well, its just that it leaves you feeling a little short-changed.
355mL bottle from the LCBO.  Pours dark amber with a thick cream-coloured head.  Strong malt backbone with moderate but balanced hopping.  Ill be sessioning this this summer.

Bright, clear, dark amber.  Light aroma of bread dough and fruity hops.  Wonderful, full flavor of grasses, malt and citrus, a small amount of sweet with a terrific bitter bite after.  A nice treat for a regular priced beer.

Pours a amber orange with a moderate fizzy head that slowly disolves. The aroma is at first a tad metallic but that gives way to a lightly hoppy floral aroma that is mostly dominated by a toffee malty aroma. The flavour is good, with some good toffee malty notes, and a bitter citrus hoppy finish. Nice foamy mouthfeel. All around a top notch beer, with decent drinkability.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2008 Lovely amber colour.  Mostly malt in the aroma with a slight hint of hops.  Lovely balance of body and bitterness with slightly burnt overtones.  Well rounded finish with a superb dry edge.  A classic.

Pours copper color with abundant pillowy off-white head. Has a malty aroma with hints of toffee. Flavor is toasty malts with a bready finish and distinguishable smoky aftertaste. Very enjoyable malty beer.
Bottle from Whole Foods Charlottesville. Reddish brown pour with a large head and decent retention. Grainy aroma with stone fruit notes. Taste is very much the same, but with some bitterness.

355ml beer, 4.8% a/v. Excited to try this, as I loved Liberty Ale.

Pours a rich coppery fire colour with a nice tan head. Smell is a bit hoppy but mainly malt and a bit of grassy notes. The taste is malty and bready at the start which then slowly graduates into a tasty hoppy finish. The mouthfeel is very full and the finish hoppy and delicious.  Not as good as liberty ale, but still a tasty brew.

bottle.  Aroma is very faint, maybe of grass and hops.  Palate is medium and smooth.  Flavor is initially bitter, of grass, yeast/grains, and some malt.  Towards finish, mellows out with some sweetness and bark.  Not my favorite, and certainly inferior to Anchors Liberty Ale.

355 ml bottle - pours a dark gold with some reddish hues in there as well.  Lets say strawberry blonde.  Nice sweet malt and good grains on the nose, and a touch of booze as well.  Flavour is bread and cereals with a good malt body that is kind of toasty.  Some mild twiggy hops as well.  Carbonation is aggressive, but it seems naturally occurring.  A fine, clean beer.  Reminds me a bit of the locally available St. Andre Vienna lager and, of course, the similarly-styled Stratford Common.

355 ml bottle from LCBO, served cold in a tulip glass.
App.:  Clear, medium-copper, fair off-white foam.
  
Aroma: Light maltiness, medium-roasted malts, dark bread crust, a touch of leafy hops, hints of coffee and toffee. 
  
Palate:  Medium body and moderate effervescence
  
Flav.:  A bit nutty and woody, austere malts, a bit of leafy hops, a bit of toffee; dry with a bit of bitterness.

Reminds me of a British or Scottish bitter.  Meh.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a nice light amber with a very substantial offwhite head that dies down to a thinner layer fairly quickly. Aromas of sweet darker malts, a light hoppiness, and a little beer stink. Initial taste is a strong bitterness balances by a slower moving malty sweet mellowness. Surprising taste compared to aroma. A very complex, in my book, taste progression but I like it.

355ml bottle 
4.9% ABV 
I tried this beer on May 23, 2008 at "The Beer Bistro" in Toronto, Ontario, Canada.  The beer poured a translucent medium reddish-brown with a thin off-white head.  The aroma was citrusy hops, and some sweetish malt.  The mouthfeel was medium-bodied, and well carbonated.  The flavour was very hoppy, leaving a bitterness on the tongue, as well as a little sour apple taste.

On tap.  Pours a dark amber color with an off white head.  Has a nice aroma, sweet and citrusy.  Flavor is outstanding, mildly sweet with a citrus presence and finishes with a strong dry piney hop taste.  An exceptional beer.

12 oz bottle from the LCBO. i was happy to see some american brews have finally started trickling into the LCBO. this one pours amber with a small tan head. malty aromas with a touch of hops. flavours are well balanced and malty with a little hop bitterness toward the end. very well put together and drinkable. a nice addition to the LCBO lineup.

Nice aroma with some malty aromas and some hops.  Its a very nice orangish color, with a light head.  Its taste takes on a dark lager quality, but with much more flavor, to include some tart fruit, some bite from the hops, and some malty flavor.  Its nice and biting, a little dry and very enjoyable.
Lovely in the glass, with a deep amber hue and a nice foamy head. Taste starts sweet but finishes slightly bitter. More body than most lagers. Goes great with summer foods off the grill.

Nice reddish copper color. Very macro aroma. Malty and slightly sweet almost a cherry flavor. but finishes very good and bitter. not a kick ass beer but great if you want to get your macro swillin freinds to drink something other than miller.
he probado varias de estas cervezas en CA pero casi siempre en draft.  se van bien, buen sabor y cuerpo.  nada fuera de lo ordinario pero valen la pena probarlas.

Deep copper/amber color with a good thick white head.  Complex bouquet of sweet roasted malts and aeromatic, citrusy hops.  Medium bodied with good carbonation and desent lace.  Malty, sweet taste that gives way to a well balanced and appetizing hop bitterness and an alcoholic pepperiness, with a long and warming finish.  Trademarking "steam beer" seems a bit selfish and oportunistic, especially considering no one really knows how "steam beer" was originally made.  None the less, this commercially successful brew, for good and bad reasons, remains a historically important brew and well deserves its place among the best american ales.  Try with a rich seafood soup, or a hearty grilled surf and turf platter.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2010 Amber pour with white head (bottle into pint glass).  Simple pale ale with mellow barely bitter hops.  Not much going on in the way of an aroma, just small traces of floral hops.  Medium bodied on the palate, fizzy without much bite or finish.  Overall, descent but very forgettable.

[RE-RATE] on tap.  I was naive when I rated this last.  This is a truly outstanding beer (though perhaps over-priced).  Bumping it from 3.1 to 3.8.  Very nice fruity malt profile and  agreat example of a rare style.

A beautiful, clear red-amber with a foamy off-white head that seemed to hold up pretty well and provided some unexpected lacing. Aroma is subtle, but hoppy and fruity. Taste is clean, crisp, slightly hoppy, but not necessarily watery. I give this pretty high marks for taking what at first seems to be an average beer and taking it up a level. Highly recommended to anyone used to macro-brews, but (foolishly) not interested in murky Belgians.
Fairly bitter initial taste but good aftertaste. Nice brown color with very light head. Better with food.

I like the color - clear golden brown. The head is small and fluffy, but it dissipates quickly. Smell is malty with some hops. Taste is about the same. Its too fizzy to feally taste anything anyway.

I am rating from a bottle. I have had this on tap before, and I think that it is a bit smoother and less fizzy that way.

Pours honey brown, with two finger gold head. Smells of toast, yeast, bitter notes. Initial taste is very bready, hoppy, and a little fruit. Medium bitterness that fades to a small aftertaste on the tongue. A very solid option from Anchor. I am usually a fan of more malt heavy brews, but this one is quite good. My favorite Anchor besides the porter.
Bottle. Nice copper color. Apricot can be found in the aroma along with some fruity notes. Taste is is a bit bitter. Really refreshing beer.

12 ounce shortneck into a mug.  Pours very nicely, with a blooming crown (although it dissipates quickly) and deep honey color.  Aroma of flowery hops and grasses.  The flavor is fairly straightforward, tasting mainly of wheat and unroasted barley.  A slight fizziness accentuates a slight bitterness.  The hops become more noticeable as an aftertaste.  The body is substantial, albeit a bit light compared to most ales.  Very solid brew, if nothing astounding, pairs well with most food, and would make the perfect accompaniment to a hot day, if one is looking for something like but with more defining character than your average light lager.

Flaske. Mørkorange øl med et pænt skumhoved. Duften er malt, smagen er malt med en smule gær. Minder meget om en bockøl, og det bedste der kan siges om denne pænt kedelige øl er at den har masser af smag procenterne taget i betragtning.

Pours a translucent copper with a thin white head.  Nothing really stands out about this beer, but it is solid nonetheless.  Refreshing and easy to drink.  This was one of the beers that got me drinking better stuff.
Ive only seen this in the bottle in Texas but it was everywhere in San Francisco.  Bitter taste but very good overall.

light amber pour very little head.  
little to no aroma.  Slight malt
Very bitter, enjoyable, but unusual and a bit spicy. Very refreshing
On tap at the Colgate Inn.  Pours a light amber with a small white head.  Initially sweet malt with a bitter finish, but as it warmed, the bitterness faded and it became sweeter.  A solid beer.

A nice looking beer that is exceptionally refreshing.  The flavor is clean and crisp but deviod of any standout elements...easy to drink and worth buying if there is nothing more interesting around...Ill be interested to try another steam beer to see how others compare

Poured from tap a darkish amber with medium sized white foam head.  Aromas of tart grasses and toasted hops.  Flavor is crisp sour apple tartness, dry light cooked caramel (no sweetness just the flavor).  The palate is very crisp and cleansing, running from tart to light bitter, and lingering in the end.  Easy to throw back a few of these and still have some nice round flavors to go with it.

Disappointed with this one. Waited ,long and hard to get it. It;s an okay beer, but not really suited to my palate. (would never knock back a beer though!). For me , smoke and burnt/roasted hops are really dominant on my palate.

Not a bad beer but not great either in my opinion. Strong flavour, yet devoid of any nuance or character. This is a good beer to have at a restaurant or bar that has a limited selection, considering this stuff is everywhere. What was once considered a great pioneering California beer now seems like a 90s fad. Im enjoying it, but its not blowing my mind like some people think it should be.
Interesting beer. Very clean, almost metal-like quality in the flavor. Somewhat thin body for an ale. I enjoyed the hop flavor but would have to say that their liberty ale is much better.

A lovely deep clear amber colour,with a fairly large tan head. Aroma is pleasent, with a mildly citrusy aroma. Hops are evident, but subtle and smooth. Taste is rich and pleasent. Midly acidic and well balanced.
Not a lot of hop aroma.  Slight malt aroma.  Nice head out of the bottle.  Bitter finish.

On tap...pours amber, little head on the glass I had, though I know you can produce one with this beer if you want to.  Aroma is pretty faint...some burnt/roasted malt and a lil bit of hops, but really not much here.  Flavor is a bit more bold.  Mostly burnt/roasted malt flavors with some light citrus and hop accents.  Palate is highly carbonated, and makes it a pretty slow drinker, though this is not necessarily a bad thing.  Good change-of-pace beer!

Anchor Steam Bear is a clear amber color with a small but decent head. The aroma is roasted and malty. The taste is also full of roasted malts and contains acidic qualities and hints of nutty flavor. This is a very nice beer. However, not nearly as good as Anchor Porter.

I used to really enjoy this beer, I have not had it in years.  It used to be a go to beer when I was in that neck of the woods, but it was something I could get all of the time I am sure that I would get tired of it.  I really respect this style, and wish there were more people experimenting with it.  Having said that, this is a nice and easy to drink beer on the lighter side, that still has a lot of flavor, some nice maltiness with some musty like hops flavors.
light aroma of roasted barley slight achohol fragance very drinkable brew i give it an a
draft- a lot of fruits thrown in there, some "noble" hop character, and a definite semi-sour malt taste. Not a go-to, and not one I would get again.

Good and tan. Tasted nice and hearty with some indentations of hops. Quick fading creamy head with a slightly cloudy body. Not a bad brew, was looking for a little more to taste, but it wasnt bad. Smooth going and refreshing.
Bottle. Pours crystal clear golden amber w/ thick lingering off white head. Slightly fruity initial taste with a bitter hop finish. Some sweet malts become more apparent the more I drink of the beer.
Light nose of roasted barley and faint hops.  Pours clean amber. Bitter taste with a dry, sour finish.  Light to medium bodied.
Bottle: Actually a lot better that I thought it would be.  Tastes kind of like a heiferwiezen.  Pours yellow with a thick fizzy head.  Strong aroma and flavor of yeast.

Pours a slightly hazy orange amber color with a small white head.  Subtle aroma, some light grain, mild hops, and a touch of burnt malt.  The flavor has that bitter maltiness that most steam beers have, but has sufficient body and even a sweet caramel character.  Some light grainy hops evens out the malt.  Just a simple and very drinkable steam beer.  Well done for the style.
Pours dark orange with light head. It have a faint smell of fruit, sugar and malt in the aroma. Flavor is great: hops and caramel malt. Medium bodied, nice mouthfeel. Overall, great beer.

12 oz bottle poured into glass. 
Poured good with a nice head that lasted only for a few drinks. Has a nice lager flavor, but doesnt stand out from much of the crowd. Good finish. This was the most expencive six pack at the store, almost 11.00 bucks! not really worth the money, better stuff is available for less.

12 ounce bottle-  poured out a unique golden amber with a short-lived light tan head that disappeared a little too fast.  Aroma was toasty.  Flavor was excellent with just the right amount of bitter bite at the end.  Competing against other moderately priced beers, this one is excellent.  Really enjoyed it.
Tap @ Faegans. Pours copper brown with small off white head. Cereal grain and malt in the aroma with some SN pale ale type hops as well. Citrus and bitter finish. Decent session ale.

UPDATED: MAY 10, 2008 Originally sampled from the bottle and now sampled on draft 5/9/08. Good beer, I like it better now than I did when I first sampled it. Amber colored with a nice khaki head which leaves some nice lacing. Some sweet caramel malts in the aroma with some fruity spice. The flavor starts off with carmel malts but it is also nicely hopped making it pretty well balanced. Id get it again.

UPDATED: AUG 29, 2008 Draft at a local pub. In agreement with the previous few posts, this is a pretty decent beer with really nothing that makes it stand out. Aroma is kind of sweet and roasty, and appearance is a dark amber haze. Flavor was moderately bitter and palate was average. Good option at a bar and wont disappoint but not outstanding.
12oz bottle. Really balanced beer. Really nothing too extraordinary about this beer; nothing to rave about, but still very drinkable and wouldnt mind having another.
12 0z. bottle, havent had this in many years and it is still pretty average, amber color with decent flavor and body, again has a bitter metallic finish
Pours to a dark golden color. Not much aroma. Very drinkable beer. Very palatable, slight bitterness/hops, some caramel notes. Good beer!

Dark ochre in color with a perfect 2 finger head.  As it settles to a nebulous cap, the foam leaves some really nice, solid lacing.

Hardly any aroma but I can pick up some caramel malt.

Flavor is quite simple but flavorful.  Sweet caramel notes are immediately apparent, along with some brown sugar, cookie dough, and even a hint of fruity esters.  Theres a tiny hop bitterness in the finish but this beer is all about toasty sweet grain.

Palate is good, with a very smooth mouthfeel that might be a touch high in carbonation.  Refreshing, infinitely drinkable.
tastes like a standard lager, kinda pabsty.  pretty drinkable, just nothing real special.

Well, what a enjoyable and drinkable beer.  I will say that it is not a "memorable" beer that I will tell all my friends about but it is really a solid brew.  nice looking, malty, goes down nice and easy.  It is one of those beers you should always have on hand.

I cant defend this as a great beer, but I can say I always find it quite drinkable and enjoyable.  Amber pour, small head.  Lager-ish, but a bit more malty and slightly more hops.  Dont know many beers to compare it to.
It looks and tastes like a lager to me...a bit too much bitterness (like when a lager has gone skunky) and not much else, wonder if my sample was past its prime.

Looks and smells like a decent ale, tastes like a sub-par lager.  Its also relatively bitter.  Bitter can be a very good thing, but its so overly dominant here that it takes away from the overall impression.

There isnt a whole lot of complexity here...the aroma is hops and malt, mabye some citrus dominate the aroma.  The taste is mostly hoppy and bitter.  Not enough malt, citrus, spice or anything else to balance out the bitter hoppiness. 
On the bright side, it is clean on the palate and the mouthfeel is absolutely perfect.

This bier has some nice points, but theyre all overpowered by one terrible error.  There is not enough of a malt backbone to support the bitterness of this beer.  Others have covered the details, Ill be brief.  Looks and smells similar to an APA.  Aroma very nice.  No-very little head.  Flavors absent the bitterness would be very nice.  Mouthfeel is awesome, but the palate is ruined with bitterness.  Overall just not enjoyable, and Ive tried it atleast 4 times.  For the record I dont dislike bitter bears, love british bitters, porters, stouts, and IPAs with much higher IBU than this.  This bier is just poorly crafted... odd considering my love for Anchors other products!
This beer has got just the right amount of everything. Perfectly balanced and easily drinkable. A toast to one of americas oldest breweries.

Bottle, 12 fl. oz. Pours a amber colored beer with an off-white head. The aroma is malty and slightly hops. The flavor is slightly hops with notes of malts. The mouthfeel is a little boring and is either refreshing or especially tasty. Overall an average beer, but a little boring.
Light copper colour. Thin lacy head. Very dry beer with strong, biscuity grains and plenty of hop. Overall a bit too dry, not pleasant in the mouth.

Draught at Rosies in Santa Cruz.   Clear amber with a creamy head.   Malty aroma with some caramel.   Fruity and malty, biscuity  taste with just enough bitterness from the hops to balance the malt.   Nice smooth, medium body.   An interesting beer, with a unique flavor, but still uneventful and a little bland.
Body is a little disappointing and its missing something there.  Nice head and appearance.  Good beer that just lacks the quality.
Bottle. Pours orange with an off white head. Malt dominated aroma with notes of caramel. Medium body. Balanced flavor with caramel notes. Pretty good.

Bottle at home. Pours very clear amber colour with plenty of thick yellowish head. Hops, citrus and red berries in a sweet and deep aroma. Mild mouthfeel, sweet and fruity. Could use some more bitterness in my opinion, but a pleasant drink altogether.

This one is tough.  Sometimes I get a really nice fresh version of this beer, served at almost cellar temperatures (which the waiter apologizes for!?), and its serene.  Other times, I get one from the Bottom of the Hill and it tastes like its just about to turn.  Not a great beer when it has age on it or when the lines havent been cleaned (obviously).  When its fresh, it has a great, apricot/peach note in the nose, has a nice sweet flavor, finishes slightly dry and is exceptionally drinkable.  I wish Fritz would put a little more quality control into his supply chain, but who the hell am I to criticize them.  I would recommend getting at a place with very high turnover on their beers.  Had at Grant & Greens in San Francisco once and it was a sour apple...
On draft- Neds Montana with Dad.  Light amber, no head.  Mouthfeel was a bit light, thin.  Taste of spice more so than hops or malt.  Pretty good, but not my favorite.

Bottle. Meidium high off-white creamy and lasting head. Hazy dark orange bodyLovely Lovely fruity, apples, pears and abricot,  and spicy aroma. Fruity dry and bitter. Low carbonation and a long bitter afteertaste. Quite tasty for such a low alcohol beer. Well done.

Poured a very lively slightly hazy orange with a good size off-white head, nice lacing. Aroma very mild, slight hops, orange juice malt. Taste more hoppy, a little minerally harsh, the orange juice malt is there at the start but very muted and has faded by the finish, which is a little too bitter for a little too long. Mouthfeel nondescript. Very easy to drink though.

The beer that started it all for craft brewing.  This is a true classic and begin with amber color and an aroma that has hints of biscuit and caramel in it.  The head is white and the lace on the side of the glasses stays with you all the way down to the last sip.  Hops arent overly dominant, and it is the malt that take center stage in the taste.  Clean and crisp in mouthfeel.  Very good beer.

Nice color, nice head.  Light body is disappointing, yet I see how it can work well with the sweet malty taste.  Flavor is toffee, cereal, and caramel with a dry, spicy aftertaste.  Pleasant all around.

Brilliant golden amber, creamy white thin head.
Very clean aroma, some malty notes, some esters.
Dry, bitter flavor.  Bitterness bordering on astringent fades to a clean dry aftertaste.

12oz bottle. Semi-cloudy Amber 1/2 inch head slowly fading.  Butterscotch aroma. Malty finish.  Tough to put my finger on this one.  Its not bad, it goes down kind of easy, though alcohol is somewhat noticeable.
(USA) Nice Amber color beer with a Med-White Head. The Brew has a Tangy/Carmel Aroma with a Sweet Robust mouthfeel. There is something different about this one? (Charcoal)

This is a California Common, one of very few.  This is a good beer.  It is smooth on the tongue with a mellow flavor, great color, and yeasty aroma.  I cant wait to have one of these in the summer.  Then I will rate again.
Sweet and sour aroma. Golden pour. Flavor has a strong malt character and a bit of  grain. Smooth finish though.  A slight amount of brown sugar  coming through on the finish.
An American classic so maybe it gets a tiny boost.  Amberish color with a decent head.  Hop and malt both in there but in balance but not too much of them either.

Pretty nice looking beer.  The head doesnt last too long.  Kind of hoppy but balanced.  Tastes pretty nice with creamy malt and hops.  Very bubbly too.  Not a bad beer.  Not my favorite, but I can drink a lot of it.

355ml bottle from Tesco. Hazy amber colour with a thin cream head; rich burnt toffee aroma; strong burnt carmel flavour with some butter and an underlying malt body and a sharp, strong biting bitterness; but the overall aftertaste has the burnt caramel to the fore. Warming, but disappointing.
I thought this was one of the easier beers to drink.  It was a little carbonated but still easy.  It was a well balenced brew.  The flavors were a little too subtle.

Bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with a good sized light tan head that lasts.  Aroma is of malt, hops and caramel.  Taste mostly of roasted malts, but is slightly sweet and has a hoppy (almost bitter) finish.  Goes down pretty smooth and tends to leave a hoppy aftertaste that left me wanting another sip.  Much better than what I expected.  Overall, this is an excellent beer that is very enjoyable and easy to drink.
UPDATED: OCT 18, 2008 Hazy amber with a creamy head. Malty aroma with ntes of nuts and butter. Dry bitter flavour with some nuts here also.

Poured a hazy amber with a one-finger head that reduced to a thin layer and left a nice lacing. Subtle hops aroma up front, the noticeable malts with some charcoal. Flavors were similar but stronger. Well-balanced hops and malts - hops up front and malts to finish, with a crisp finish and great aftertaste. Lots of texture - almost chewable - and carbonation make this a very enjoyable beer in all aspects.
Nice dark golden color. White head. Malty aroma.  The flavor is a nice creamy maltiness with a nice hoppiness to balance. Lively body, bitter finish, all in all a really drinkable beer.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2008 Bottle. Dark amber colour with an off white head- Malty aroma with hints of caramel. Flavour is a bit tangy and quite malty. Not much bitterness. Did not really like this one all that much.

Copper colored body with a medium slightly beige foam.  Aroma is  and a bit of fruit.  Flavor is an interesting mix of a pale lager, and an ale.  There is a good balance of hop and malt and a surprising bitter aftertaste.  Mouthfeel is more robust and effervescent than expected but the beer itself is thin.

Pours a nice amber with a good sized head that dissipates quickly and doesnt leave much lacing.. Smells of any cheap beer, reminds me a little of vomit... Taste is a little better, slight fruity notes that fade quickly with just a small hoppy finish. Easy to drink but Im not sure how long Id enjoy it.
Beautiful creamy head. Nice reddish amber color. Pleasant malty aroma. There is a nice fruit flavor at first but it disappears quickly. Some hop flavor too. Mild bitterness on the finish. Enjoyable.
draught in Poughkeepsie. amber and smooth, a little sweet for me, lacking in hop somewhat. but a clean crisp flavour makes it easy to drink, with a very slightly spicy finish
always a favorite.  Nice smooth and drinkable. Every element in its place. Pours with a fluffy head and a medium amber.tastes like beer  with a slight sweetness ballanced by hops and malt.
a solid, drinkable beer.  i drank t a long time ago and cant remember all the details.  I do remember that I liked it.
Anchor Steam has a nice copper colour, a fruity aroma and a flavour with lots of malt but a pleasant hop finish. Another moreish one.

UPDATED: MAR 15, 2010 Not too bad a brew, but certainly not worth the price that is charged.  It has a clean finish, and a hearty body with a good dose of hops. A little bit of harshness and chunkiness on the palate. Not an all day drinker.  Good in combination with food.
Bottle. Nice red brown body. Small off white head. Sweet spicy malty aroma. Sweet malty christmas beer flavour. Ok. (Blå Rock, 04.01.08)

I thought this stuff was pretty amazing.  I had it on tap at a local bar.  Great color, milky brown.  Crisp flavor with just the right amount of bitterness and carbonation.  Settled on the palate nicely. Great aftertaste.
Floral, metallic aroma with a huge head. Very light flavor, thin with weak spice and light fruit ester and some bitter metallic notes. Not impressed.
Amber color.  Not much head out of the bottle.  Smell is nice, malty, little carmel?.  Hops make it a medium bitter beer.  Carbonation.    Not in my top ten.  But not in the bottom ten either.
deep amber, thick creamy head, rich flavor, seems to be harder to find nowadays.
this stuff is good. so tasty and satisfying. suck it down out of the bottle and you are chillen.
Just solid.  Light-medium body with a steady and well-balanced flavor.   Finishes a little dry, but really easy to drink.

Bottle. Pours a hazy brown. Offwhite head that dissipates quickly. No lacing. Aroma was hops and earth. Flavor was hops and earth with the dirt peeking through more than the hops. Ok aftertaste, mouthfeel was medium. Not too bad and not great either. A little less than I expected.

One of the few American-made beers I will drink.  Nice to have a pint with a big plate of calamari on Pier 39 in SF.  Bold flavor and has a bit of a bite to it, but not in a bad way.  I love the smell and taste as you slowly drink it down.

bottle. smells a tad malty with a small hint of fruit. smells more like ginger ale than beer. small off white head. amber body with tons of carbonation. no lacing to speak of. tastes kind of malty and very high on yeast with a touch of a fruity after thought. kind of tates like a skunky lager. it is a tad hoppy but not over the top. lost some of its skunkyness as it warmed up a bit but still flat.
Pours a dark golden color.  Nice, fine head that dissipates quickly.  Malty aroma.  Flavor is malt with some hops and mild charcoal.  A hint of citrus.  Not bad.
Sampled at the Arizona Craft Brewers Guild 2008 Strong Beer Fest, on February 17, at the Mesa Amphitheatre.

On tap at Teds Montana Grill. Poured a nice, deep, bright red with a medium-sized off-white (light tan) head. The aroma is full of malts - particularly bready and toasty. The flavor is also malty - lots of bready and toasty flavors. There is a subtle touch of caramel malts, but not much - the residual sweetness is pretty low. The flavor is quite clean - which is a little surprising given that this "hybrid" lager is supposed to be distinguished from other lagers by a touch of fruity esters. By mid-palate, the balancing bitterness of hops grows. This beer is supposed to be characterized by Northern Brewer hops - but the hopping level is lower than I expected, so I couldnt really pick out any particular variety (except that I already know its Northern Brewer). The finish is somewhat dry and bitter. The mouthfeel is medium-full in body and the carbonation is low (its probably much more effervescent in a bottle than the draft I had). Overall, a clean, easy-to-drink lager that is more full-flavored than other mass-produced lagers, but still bland compared to other full-flavored beers (especially bland next to Anchors other products, which are for the most part fantastic).
Aroma is malty, but also sour like a pilsner. The colour is copper red with a nice lasting head. The flavor is malty with metal, but its also bitter.

I think this is actually a pretty damn good beer. The hops grab your palate and the malt to hop ratio is pretty balanced. Pours amber with some good frothy white head. Flavors are the bitter part that seizes your tongue. It has bite - I like this.

Had in San Fran, sadly not at the brewery.  Pours a toasted golden color with a small white head.  A hint of sweet and bitter in the aroma, but I couldnt really get much in the bar.  Very light flavor, some brown sugar or caramel and just a little touch of yeast.  A very drinkable beer, but not one of my favorites.

12 oz bottle. Pours a deep golden straw color with a 1/2" rapidly dissapating head. Ragged lace coats my glass. Hoppy, grassy nose with average mouthfeel.  Tastes of malts and yeast and some mild hops. As the beer warms you get some mild toffee flavors. A nice, but average brew. Be a great session beer.

I dont believe there is a single long-time American brewed beer that better represents the microbrew tradition than Anchor Steam.  Unique please aroma, appealing looks, and a smooth, light body contribute towards its appeal.
For those whove never tried it, I recommend.

12 ounce bottle. Pours a nice golden color with a .5 finger width white head. Aroma was fairly interesting with hops and a slight toffee smell. I have never smelled a beer quite like this one. The taste was very refreshing with hints of yeast and hops. Also had a very light mouthfeel. This beer was tasty but average in a lot of respects...

Ahhhhh! I love this beer! It is so light and crisp and still has the flavor to keep you interested! Its pleasant aroma is inviting and while in your mouth you will get a succession of interesting flavors. Its really quite a good one!
good cali common widely available in my neck of the woods. nice and balanced, easy drinking, give it to my "light-beer" friends as an introduction to craft. not much for the connosieur.
On tap at Boise Flying Pie Pours out a amber topped with a off white head. A nice aroma of bitter and a touch of hops. Tast of a nice mix of grain and malt. Ok brew

Good but not great.  I wish I would have tried this before I read all of the hype, because I expected alot from this.  It did have a great golden amber color with a nice head.  Aroma was weak as was taste.  Definitely above average, but not what it is hyped up to be.  I have had so many better beers lately that this just barely ranked above a Yuengling to me.

amber, decent head. Some mild biscuity hop aroma, with a hint of herb. Well balanced, a little bit of bitter herb tastiness - nothing thatll knock your socks off. A respectable brew thats better than most you can find on tap at your everyday bar/restaurant.

From bottle, pours an amber color with a decent cream head.  Aroma is tinge of sweet and hops.  What a nice blend of yeast, hops and malts that gives a bit of a biter bite and that little taste of dry sweetness.  Im glade I finally tried this, will be having more!

From bottle. Aroma was bitterly hoppy. Not much other than that. Flavor was...underwhelming. I was expecting more, I guess. Well, essentially the flavor is bitter, and not very smooth. Not a whole lot of malt flavor, or yeast. Really not a floral hop flavor, just a bit of bitterness. Thats pretty much it really. I wouldnt try again.
Very nice beer to start off the evening. Rich flavor with slight bite to it. Nice aftertaste. Tastes good a few minutes after pulling it from the fridge.
pours a dark copper with a thick off white head.  Hops and sweet malt aroma.  Flavor adds some caramel and a bit of funk,  but in a good way.  Finishes slightly bitter,  mmm.

12 oz. bottle - Poured transparent dark amber color with medium head that faded quickly. This is my first Anchor brew and I am mildly impressed. Tastes similar to a Sam Adams Boston Lager but not as good.
Tasted 2007-12-28. Fresh bottle. Pours semi hazy orange with beige head. Fruity and malty aroma. Fresh taste. Light bitterness. Quite accessible, but not impressing.
UPDATED: MAY 22, 2008 ok beer. definite nice citrus taste, but bitter and unremarkable, especially compared to anchors other works. not bad, not great.

Bottle. Sweet hop nose. Clear light amber color with minimal head. Flavor is wonderfullly balanced citrus hops and a touch of sweetness. Drinkable, light and smooth. One of the great American session beers.

Bottle. Light amber color with a small fading head. Nothing much in the aroma, some malts come through. A bit dry and somewhat sour flavor with a terrible aftertaste. Doesnt have character at all. Dry bitter palate and not in a good way.

Brassy color on the red side of orange and clear.  Aroma of generous malt and the very faintest reminder of orange liquor; clean tasting, says the commercial description, meaning you cant taste dirt or toxic waste; gee, thats no help.  Fortunately, its not clean like a hospital floor but rather has rich, ginger-like spiciness and a bitter finish.

Bottle. Pours rich amber with moderate, slightly off-white head. Aroma is nutty, toasted grain with hints of fruity hops. Flavor is bready, slightly sweet upfront, some light ester fruitiness -  esp. peaches, apples -  with strains of resiny bitterness throughout. Bitterness lingers in the finish. Full palate.

drought. my first taste of California common and color me impressed. nose is very fruity with hints of banana, tangerine, and pineapple. taste is lighter than the smell but still fruity. very refreshing. must drink again.

UPDATED: NOV 30, 2008 Bottle: Light biscuit flavor with a hint of hops at the finish.  Had a nice nutty flavor with hints of toffee and chocolate. Had a medium to light body with a very well blended taste and texture.  Definitely a session beer.
UPDATED: AUG 14, 2009 12 oz. Clear, copper with a small head that flits away. Caramel aroma. Caramel flavor turns to nutty, slightly bitter herbs. Light-medium body is slightly dry.
Good aroma. Grains and malts. Light amber appearance, with light head. Well balanced flavor. Malty with some hop characteristics. Kind of dry palate but smooth.

Poured from a bottle into a lager glass. Initial nose was of banana and evened out to more of a grain/bread. Fairly palatable, but a little harsh towards the middle. Nice, smooth hoppy finish. Great grocery store beer...

UPDATED: AUG 18, 2008 Poured amber from 12 ounce bottle . Good white head, fairly good lacings. Not much aroma but nothing bad either. Taste is some sweet maltiness with a euro- hop bitterness.  A tasty session beer.
Draught. Amber with a whitish head. Quite bland but not bad, a bit malt and low on the hops. Dry aftertaste. Nice standard beer.

UPDATED: MAY 28, 2008 When speaking of American classics... When the subject of American craft breweries is brought to the table, few bring up Anchor. However if there is a classic in american brewing Achor Steam is the one. Scent is very british. Almost as if it were a bitter. Slightly hoppy with nice sweet carectaristics. This brew always satisfies.

12oz bottle. For a traditional brewing method, it really lacks character. The initial reaction is tempting, but once at the end of the bottle, its something you wish had a little more style. Ive had some steam beers before and this is definitely the most bland of all.

Bottle. Nice looking beer with a good head.  Aroma is lacking and pretty standard.  Flavor is good, but nothing extraordinary.  Has a bit of a bite to the palate, but nothing too bad.  Overall its just so-so.

Bottle.  Poured amber with creamy head.  Aroma of fresh bread.  Malty flavour with an unfortunate yeasty  tang. Bready finish.  I admit Im not used to steam beers, this is the only one Ive had and this is the first time in years.
user_location: Munchen an der Willamette, Oregon, USA

text:
Man, I really wanted this be better.  This is such a famous beer and brewery and this is my first experience with it.

Looks pretty good.  Nice head.  

Not so crazy about the smell.  Sort of smells like bread.  Nothing I couldnt get down at the local gas station.

Yep.. tastes pretty much like I thought it would after smelling it.  Really close to the macros.  Biting carbonation and all.

Little disappointing but Im still glad I got to try this.
Pours a copper amber with a thick creamy tan head. The aroma is light, grassy, amber malt. The flavor is crisp and dry, a bit chalky, grassy, light malt and hop.

I remember having this with my brother-in-law a long time ago.  He recently passed, so I picked some up.  Although it looks like an ale, it has the mouthfeel of a lager.  It brings me back a bit, but this beer will be for reminiscing, not because it has superior flavor.  Im glad I trid it because now I have discovered California Common.

Clear chestnut color with fast-fading thin white head. Aroma is sweet and nutty with a bit of biscuit. Taste is same with minor skunky notes, and a bit of caramel.and fleeting hop bitterness.  Well carbonated with a clean finish. $2/12 oz

I gave this a try and was surprised..I agree with the caramel aftertaste which I liked. I actually liked the color if it sttin in my glass more than usual.. Kinda copper but not quite. Nutty like me so maybe that was why I liked it..Not much smell but smooth overall.

355ml bottle at Microbar, Clapham, 8th Jan 08, with tashi. Pours orange amber with not too much head. Very malty aroma that carries over to the flavour. Not very complex, but certainly different from most beers I have tried. Smooth, with an average weight - very drinkable.
It has a butterscotch note wich supprises me a bit, also I found some burnt notes... Remeber it tasted different last time...

Bottle.  Pours amber color with whitish long lasting frothy head.  Aroma is like a lager.  It is sweet and grainy, with spice dimension.  Flavor is largely what you would expect from the aroma, a little musty with some citrus and a decent amount of hops.  Well balanced and very drinkable.
A very well-designed label. Its a crisp amber-colored beer with just the right amount of hops.

1/10/2008:  Anchor Steam has a clear, shiny copper color with a dense, somewhat creamy, and lasting off-white head.  The aroma and flavor have a nice toffee maltiness, some delicate fruitiness, and a soft hoppiness that includes some citrus and a light bitterness.  I also pick up I bit of creme brulee or something similar in the flavor.  This beer has a nice, somewhat creamy palate.  It it medium-bodied and goes down smoothly.  In general, this is a decent beer and quite drinkable and sessionable.  However, while I can appreciate the heritage of the "Steam"/California Common beer, it is more of a technique than an actual style (in my opinion).  I highly doubt that one could identify a beer as being a California Common based on its solely on its aroma and flavor like can be done with every other style of beer...
12 fl. oz. bottle at Winking Lizard Tavern (Crosswoods) in Columbus, Ohio.  Rating #1573 for this beer...
Amber with tiny off white head. Aroma has plums, caramel and hops. Sweet flavor with caramel and hops in the end.

Pours a clear copper color with a big off white head. 
Spicy sweet , grainy yeasty smell, like a nice german Lagar. 
Light-medium bodied with light carbonation. 
Nice malty grain flavor with spicy yeast. 
Finishes with a medium bitter taste on the tongue. 

One of the first micros I quaffed back at the start of the micro revolution. 
Still pretty tasty today.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Pours a really nice amber with a nice fluffy white head.  Pleasent aroma, but nothing really stands out.  Nice bitterness.  A bit musty with some underlying lemon notes especially on the finish.  A bit thinner body than I would like, but still a good beer.

Had trouble pinpointing aromas & flavors in this, but heres my best approximation. Aroma: Grainy, hay, barnyard, musty sweetness; all this borders on fruity, but only teases. Taste: Barnyard, musty. Got a bit of a tangy zip to it as well. Finishes slightly dry w/ some acidity. Hops in the finish are lemony. Body is a bit thin.
Tap.  Amber pour with nice head. does offer rich flavor and aroma.  Some fruity aroma, but not overpowering.  Just a hint to keep you asking, what was that....I liken this to a great Session beer.
Poured from a bottle an amber color. There was nothing which really stood out in the aroma. Beer had a crisp taste of malts and bitter hops.

Flavorful yet subtle and quaffable, this sort of beer is still a rare gem these days. And in many U.S. bars, it might just save you from a short list of otherwise corporate beers. Bottle pours orange-copper with a thin, white head. Nose of fresh hops, biscuit, and a little must. Mild, easy-drinking bitterness with lemon and dusty notes. Refreshing. Good.

pours a pale amber with  a short lived white head. aroma is sweet malt, caramel, lager yeast and some fruit. flavor is much the same with a nice acidity and a dry finish. light to medium bodied with high carbonation.

I had a sixer of this down in Florida over the X-Mas break when I was in Orlando for a swim team training camp. It was a pretty enjoyable beer to have after a long day of those incredibly hard practices. Its a solid lager, but with some ale like elements, like some yeastiness on the nose, as well as some fruity elements in the aroma and flavour (peach, cherry, etc.). The only thing it looses points on is the strange way that the alcohol becomes more evident in the flavour as it warms. Weird seeing as its only 4.9%. Good over-all though. I could drink it casually and as a party beer!
Nice first taste. Noticeably dry as beer progressed. Nice head and presentable color. Overall, an average beer.

From bottle : Pours a clear dark amber color with a very nice finger and a half head of smooth foamy thick white head that has wonderful staying power.  Nose is big time toasted grains and some hints of hops.  Taste is mainly malty, citrus notes pop up, and a little grassy hopness.  Medium bodied and a tart palate, aftertaste is enjoyable.  Very drinkable, pretty good.
Light white head and amber body. Excellent balanced flavor, hops are there but not overwhelming. A very satisfying beer indeed.
Bottle: Poured a copper with a thin off white head. The aroma is sweet with barely presence. The taste is sweet malts with grain.

Tap. Green Mill Uptown. Faint aroma of toasted grain and bread dough. Pours bright clear copper with little head. Flavor is fairly grainy, Some light grassy hops. Toasted caramel malt. Medium bodied. A tad watery but doesnt distract form the overall flavor. Finishes with some lingering light grassy hops. An all day drinker for sure.
Decent beer. Had a bottle at a bar after drinking a pitcher of crap beer so this tasted much better in comparison. Wouldnt go out of my way to buy again but wouldnt turn one down
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Poured a clear amber with limited head.  I couldnt tell if they were going for a lager or ale here, but it tasted like an ale with limited flavor (similar to a lager), although it was fairly smooth and light on the palate.  It was refreshing, but lacking full flavor.

Bottle.  Pours a clear amber color with a 2 finger head.  Aroma of lightly roasted malts, some yeast and a little light citrus.  Flavor is light malts, some citrus notes, a touch of tartness.  Rather refreshing and quite drinkable.

Poured a light brown color. Nice head when it was poured but didnt stay around long. Left a lace on my glass. Serve at about 50 degress. Nice palate, not too carbonated, just enough. Hoppy and bitter, nice job.

Pours a nice amber, with an average head. Lacing is minimal to none. Malty, with some fruitiness in the background. The sweetness seemed a bit out of place in the context of the rest of the beer, it was unremarkable.

UPDATED: FEB 11, 2010 Nice looking amber with off-white head. Aroma of malt, some nice hop floral . Flavor has nice maltiness to it, nice hop flavor with small hop bitter, also has a faint nuttiness. Mouth feel is medium body with high carbonation. Very enjoyable beer!
Bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with a thin head that diminishes quickly.  Has a good balance of hops and bitterness.  Very refreshing and tasty.

A classic, of course.  The beer pours a beautiful amber with a bountiful, creamy head.  Flavors of citrus, yeast, and cider are plentiful.  A well balanced flavor without lots of carbonation.  Perfectly refreshing by itself or with a meal.
Bottle. Pours a reddish amber, thin white head. Aroma is slight malt, maybe a touch of fruit. Flavor is subdued hops, malt and a touch of caramel.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2009 Pours with small initial head, creamy with ever so slight off-white tinge. Mostly diminishes, but has good lacing. Very aromatic when poured. Citrus jumped out of the glass at me, a little yeast and very slight malt. A few fruity esters and some honey. Had a scent of sweet apples or cider. Very clear amber appearance. By the looks of things, actively carbonated. Taste, or lack of it, is a dissapointment. Crisp bitter apple skind. Medium duration with a mildly bitter finish, just a really watery taste (much more so than I remember, maybe I have been drinking too many taste-filled ales recently). The mouth is a creamy feel, soft but yet lively carbonation. Lack of taste is the biggest let down for this brew.

Light amber colour with a medium head. Aroma is subdued - some spice. Flavour is mildly nutty, a little orange and spice with a short finish. Above average and refreshing but not one I would seek out.

Bottle. Pours an amber colour with a fine white head. Malty aromas with some softly acidic hints. The flavours are also a touch acidic with maybe the occassional hint of metal in the otherwise rather bitter finish. Smooth and very tasty.
Bottle. Orange pour with a long lasting white head. Nice well balanced flavor with alot of carbonation. Not bad
Sweet corn malt aroma. Clear fizzy orange color with a medium lasting white head.  Strong lager flavor with a carbonation tang.

Light color.  Kinda of a musty, earthy aroma to it.  Tastes sort of like banana.  A very dry beer, but smooth and easy to drink.

On tap/12 oz. bottle.
A smooth drinking beer with a light amber coloring. Taste is that on banana nut bread.

Bottled, consumed 12/14/07. Pours clear light copper with nice little off-white head that quickly dissipates.  Toasty  nose with notes of spicy hop.  A little thin on the palate, but flavorful nonetheless.  Rich maltiness is quickly upstaged by bitterness, but the whole affair is rather milder than is typical of many west coast brews.  A little of the Bass Ale type flavor is going on, and the clean finish with a hint of astringency reminds me a little of that British brew as well.  A very easy drinking beer with some flavor.  Might be a good gateway beer to get from macrobrew lager swill to the good stuff.

12 oz bottle pours a clear amber body with a modest offwhite head. Aroma and taste have a nice toasted caramel maltiness and earthy hop bitterness. Very well balanced and an excellent session brew. For some reason this classic always reminds me of a topnotch German Ofest.

Pours a smokin hot ruby amberish pour with minimal if any head, but it truly looks good.   Nose really doesnt bring much to the table small hoppage even smaller malt little bit of that cheapy beer aroma that doesnt turn anybody on.  Flavor while descent isnt anything to write home about.  Its good it really is, just not a standout beer by any means.
Bottle:  Poured a light amber color with a off white head.  Goes down quite easily but has a mild aftertaste.

UPDATED: JUN 8, 2013 Nice crisp looking beer. Kind of lite on the aromas. I cant really pick anything out. Flavor is the saving grace for this one. Slightly spicy and kind of coats the walls of the mouth. Theres a nuttiness to this as well. Maybe just maybe step the alc% up to 5.5%.

Poured from a bottle. Pours a rich amber/copper color. Has a pleasant aroma not overstated. The flavor is a very well balanced barley/hoppes flavor. Balance is what I look for in what is called a session beer. I could and have drank several of these at a sitting. Good balance beer. I like it and it is priced decently in my area. It is a staple.
Very promising aroma of bananas, sour apples, bubble gum and even some dark fruit somewhere. Very subtle malt flavour with the citrusy esters dominating. not amazing. I expected more.
This is great beer. right in the middle weight wise and delicious, you can get it fresh on tap on the west coast
Bottle. Pours amber caramel color with a thick white head. Light hop and malt aroma. Malty taste with a nice tinge of hops in the finish. A classic.
Amber appearance, citrus-y aroma, shades of raisins almost. Smooth taste of hops and malts, kinda bitter. Good but not remarkable.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 A gorgeous golden, large headed brew.  Nose of California fruit orchard: flowers, plum skins, golden raisins. Very smooth & dry.  Easy drinking. Some biscuity malts. Way floral hops, which I enjoy.
Deep amber pour, big white head. slight citrus aroma. went down easy, flavor of mostly malt with a little citrus. a nice beer with a light meal
A bit too light for me.  A huge head, that took forever to go down.  When I finally got to the drinking part, the beer didnt excite me that much, but it is okay.
Huge foamy head. Nice copper color. Sort of like a creamier, maltier pilsner. I had it directly after a Harpoon Winter Warmer, and this beer was its perfect compliment. Cleansed the ole palate.

12oz had @ Winking lizard, to me the definition of Session beer. this is easy drinking and just great to have around.. so easy to put down lots of it and easily found around town.. a great trademark for any brewery

A well-carbonated clear golden-brownish color Nice sweet malty, almost honey-like yeasty/bready aroma.  Flavors were mostly sweet and malty, slightly fruity, and a very light nuttiness.  Then a bit of the hops come through, but its very slight.  Medium-light body, pretty good stuff overall, a respectable brew.

why does this beer have a twist off cap?  One of the nicer looking beers Ive poured out of a bottle lately.  The taste is pretty big, and definitely original and recognizable.    Body feels pretty big, the malt is roasty tasting and the hops tail that flavor seamlessly.  All and all a different beer from a different place.  I could do this at the wharf with a clam chowder bread bowl and a dirty sport coat.  72 overall is higher than i thought!

12 oz bottle  Pours with a slight tan head, dissipating to a nice ring throughout consumption; only slight lacing.  Brilliantly clear, medium amber in color.  Aroma says malt with little hop aroma.  Taste certainly leans toward sweet malts, but its offset, especially in the end, with a nice hop bitterness
Pours a deep amber color with a huge tan foamy head. Aroma is yeasty. Taste of hops and citrus. A nice solid brew. I think its a little over rated......
Pours with a light reddish, amber color and a resilient off-white head of medium size.  Taste is light but pronounced with slight hops and a welcomed bitterness.

12oz bottle. Light reddish/rust colored body with an incredibly long lasting, creamy white head. Looks like a root beer float from the top of the glass. Impressive lacing as well. Nose of floral and light citrus hops, sweet toffee malts, some biscuit dough. Pretty muted all around. Maybe some hints at lemon but tough to tell. Flavor is sweet malts and dough to the front, fading to bitter drying hops at the back of the tongue and into the swallow. Lively carbonation, heavily astringent. Medium bodied, slick mouthfeel. Finish is medium length, bitter and then fading into a residual toffee sweetness. Easy drinking, clean, and non offensive. Nothing really stands out, but this is a solid, sessionable beer.

Pours a coppery red with a relatively thick creamy white head.  slight odor of honey with a dominance of malts.  The taste starts off with malt, and ends with a nice hoppy aftertaste.  Very crisp, refreshing beer.

Pours light copper. White head. Smells of carmel and malts, Taste is of malts, carmel and honey. Could be better if they added more hops. I love this beer as it I started with. Perfet on a warm summer day.

Pours a clear copper honey tone with a cream coloured foamy head that sticks around and leaves a little bit of lacing. Aroma is sweet with some molasses hay and  fruit. Taste is bready with a grainy white wine flavour and citrus hops. Medium light feel with a sweet and sticky finish. Not bad, but could be cleaned up and balanced a bit more maybe.

pours clear copper with thick off white head, rich bready malt aroma. rich malty flavour, toasted with hints of toffee and nuts. slightly spicy on the swallow, lingering dry finish. different and very pleasant, somewhat like a bock.
12oz bottle. Poured a medium and hazy orange color with an averged sized off white head. Lacing left on the glass. Aromas of caramel and sweet malts with some corn. Tastes of the same. Thinner body.

I popped open the bottle and got slammed by a ton of malty goodness.  Pours an amber-red color with a thin white head with little lacing.  Taste is very malty up front with a strong bite at the end.  Very enjoyable brew.
very hoppy aroma and taste i loved it... head was medium and finish was smooth

Bright orange in colour with medium white head. Smokey woody flavour with hint of citrus, malty aroma, harsh mouthfeel.
Good to know that there alternatives to drink in SFO!!!!
This beer is very crisp. Highly carbonated, but has a good bit of flavor to back it up for being a light beer.
Bottle. Amber color.  Nice well rounded and refreshing beer with a clean taste and finish.
Attractive amber beer.  Has a somewhat rough hop aroma and flavor.  Dry but with some rounder caramel , malty notes.

pours a dark amber with a three finger off-white creamy head that seems to last a good long while, much carbonation, 
smell is quite faint, roasted malt, bit of citrus, 
taste is grain, hops, some dark fruit, dandelion, little bit sweet, leaves the mouth oily and sticky.
swell drew!!

355ml bottle. 
Pours a clear copper honey tone with a cream coloured foamy head that sticks around and leaves a little bit of lacing. Aroma is sweet with some molasses and fruit. Taste is bready with a grainy white wine flavour and citrus hops. Medium thick feel with a sweet and sticky finish. Not bad, but could be cleaned up and balanced a bit more maybe.

I went conservative for my 100th rating; Anchor Steam (bottle) never lets me down. It had the same amber hue and same white head, but I noticed that it wasnt as aromatic this time around, only a slight hint of a citrus/floral smell. The taste provided a little caramel sweetness underneath the malt and grain tastes, rounded out by a soft bitterness and a bit of a tangy bite. The Anchor Steam also seemed to have a slightly heavier, creamier mouthfeel than most pale ale-types.
Now I get a lil kings hat by my name.

pours a solid amber with a yellow-white head.  aroma is a malty with a smidge of citrus and pine.  taste is pretty much ratebeers definition of a california common; a lager with a nice rounded fruitiness.  fizzy mouthfeel & medium-light bodied.  would be a great session-type beer.  IMO its not as good as their APA, but its plenty yummy.

Orange color, creamy but thin head. Malty, citrusy (a bit).   Finish is somwhat alkaline. Very drinkable, nothing really bothersome, not heavy.  Decent session beer, but Im just biased against lagers...

This is one of the best pale ales that Ive tried. An uncharacteristic thick head, and very smooth texture. Just a hint of bitterness, but not enough to be distracting. This one will probably become a regular in my fridge.
Orangish brown colored pour with little to no head.  Malty, citrusy aroma with a little hops.  Bitter, tart finish with hints of pine.  Not too bad.

Nice looking beer but all in all a dissapointment.  Watery mouthfeel.  A descent amount of hops in the aftertaste.  I was really looking forward to this beer and sadly it didnt live up to my expectations.  I wont buy again.

(35.5cl bottle) Hazy, copper colour with a mid-sized off-white foamy head. Light-sweet aroma with an aromatic toasty malt-character with caramel and woody hops. Initially slightly sweet and toasty taste, drying out towards the end; light to medium bodied; bitter and well-hopped finish with a fruity tinge (apricot) and a lasting aftertaste.

(Draught at MacKinlays Inn, Stockholm, 31 Oct 2007) Dark amber colour, slightly hazy, with creamy, beige head. Fruity, slightly roasted nose with dark fruit, orange marmalade, apricots and toffee. Sweetish. Malty taste with notes of dark fruit, bread, toffee, oranges, marmalade and a hint of chocolate. Nice, rounded, spicy hop caharacter in the finish. Very balanced and very refreshing.

12 oz bottle via Capital market. Pours a clear dark copper with a huge beige head. Nose is malty, almost honeyish. Taste is grainy, toasty, with some subtle grassy hoppiness in the finish. A bit of an astringant aftertaste. Body is light, carbonation is moderate to high. THis reminds me of many brown ales. An ok backyard beer.
So sorry to all who like this crap, too hoppy, left bitter after taste and not worth trying again. YUCK!!!

Pours a medium amber with an orange tinted head.  A bit one dimentional and alkaline.  A thin line of crispness runs from beginning to end.  Balanced?  The calvalcade of beers last night may have drowned this one out a bit.  worth another try on a historical perspective.

Had this one on tap.Came out a sort of brownish color without much body.  Kind of a dry gritty flavor with pleasant aftertaste.  Like some of the previous posts say, this is a nice beer but its nothing memorable.  It does have a cool bottle though.

I am neither for or against this beer, to me it was rather unremarkable. Not bad by any stretch of the imagination but also not anything good that would make me try it again. Unremarkable I think is the word of the day.

Sampled on Flashys tour of LA, New Zealand and Hong Kong of September/October 2007 - This was pretty good.  Quite hoppy and bitter, but had a distinctive sweet, fruity taste.  No bad thing - pretty quaffable.

[Bottle] Pours amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is inoffensive, but weak--mostly just malt.  Taste is also mainly malt, but it comes through very nicely and is quite pleasant.  Pretty good mouthfeel.  Aside from the aroma this was quite nice, I think it would make a good session beer.

Bottle @ Sushi-Thai restaurant. Pours amber with sporadic lacing. A fingernail of white head appears and dissipates within 30 seconds to a white rim. Nose is apple, grains, some oats. More light fruits upfront with layers of malty grains, banana, and a crisp finish. Very minute hop presence. Medium carbonation and thin body. Decent.

Draught at Captains Corner, Viking Line Amorella.  Amber color with small head. Nutty and caramelly aroma with fruity hops and hint of fruity esters. Caramelly and sligtly toasty flavor with medium bitterness and clearly detectable minty/fruity hop flavor. Easy drinking and pleasant.

12oz bottle. deep copper color. thick foamy beige head that disolves slowly. unique flavor due to it being a "steam" beer. rich slightly sweet flovor. good hops, but not obnoxious. been a favorite for 20 years. excellent cold weather brew-ha!
pours a chestnut brown with decent head, flavour reminds me of warm ripe bananas. Big bodied malty with a good hop finish, very pleasant beer

Pours dark amber forming nice frothy beige head of foam.  Aroma of malts, faint hops, and dirty wet forest.  Flavor is full bodied, malts, caramel.  Easy drinking, sessionable beer. Not what I would call a knock out brew, but certainly its not grog/piss.
user_location: The Crystal Coast, North Carolina, USA

text: 12oz bottle.  Aroma is sweet and fruity hops with that distinct lager note.  Large off-white head that mostly diminished and left good lacing.  Clear with a medium amber hue.  Flavor is smooth and light with a slight bitterness on the short finish.  Palate is medium bodied and watery with lively carbonation.  A refreshing brew like its liberty ale sibling.
