Good on a hot day when served cold.
12 ounce bottle available at Total Wine Fort Lauderdale, FL at $1.49 Very good.

12 oz. bottle.  Poured a rich gold with a small slightly brown head.  Sweet and malty aroma.  Fresh caramelized and roasted peanuts, peach, and overripe bananacomplex but the overripe fruit isnt pleasant.  Taste is bitter and dry.  Bitter almonds that have been roasted.  Hardly any sweet flavors.  The hops is evident in the taste.  Palate is acerbic and finish is dry and bitter.  Disappointing given the beers reputation.

Bottle, bought @ Wohlenbergs, Sønderborg. Pretty darkish cobber amber with a medium creamy off white head. Lots of bubbles in the liquid. Aroma is malty, some barn and rye bread. Wonderful spritzy carbonation with lots of small bubbles. Flavour is sweet, caramel malty with a slight peppery bitterness. Nice and fresh - wonderful summer beer!
Probably the best of your "theres nothing on tap but..." choices. A straight up beer. Decent taste. Nothing complex, but better than Sam Adams.

I was pleasantly surprised by this one.  Fairly clear, amber body with an off-white head that persists through the glass pour.  Mostly malt in the body, but an unprecidented carbonation that gives a great mouthfeel and a perfect palate for me.  Maybe someday Ill come back to this one.
Nice rich and deep beer. The taste lingers, perhaps a bit too long. I particularly enjoy the hints of sweetness that creep through the bitterness. Overall a great beer and a fall favorite of mine!

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2008 This is a dark coppery amber colour with an off-white, thick, long-lasting foamy head and good, long-lasting lacing.  It has a fairly mild but pleasant aroma that is a little fruity and malty with a hint of a citrusy bite and a yeasty element.  The flavour also is kind of on the mild side, but very nice. It is still quite flavourful, somewhat full-bodied, and very well balanced, with a definite malt, slightly sweet caramel element, toasty flavour, and an offsetting mild hoppy bitterness.  The result is a brink that is very smooth and drinkable, but still satisfyingly flavourful and pleasantly, thiough mildly, crisp.

UPDATED: JUL 22, 2009 enjoyable beer. sort of unique flavor with a really creamy mouthfeel that isnt all artificial creamy like that nitro crap. very balanced and pleasant.  honey in the flavor, kind of bland for a west coast beer though.i would like to have a dry hopped version of this!
Good all-around beer. Smooth rich amber with light head and body. Refreshing!
Copper colour with small head.High carbonation,and light tosted taste note of honey and corn.Not my type of beer.

Pours amber with medium head. I was quite excited to try this as I had heard good things. As a california common, this is a very unique beer as it uses lager yeasts but ferments at ale temperatures. It tasted more like an ale to me, but there was definitely something a bit different. The yeast was more pronounced than I expected, though not in a bad way. The aroma wasnt great; malt and some hops. The flavour was very tasty, with notes of malts, sweetness, hops, and a pronounced smooth caramel. Medium body with medium carbonation. Overall very smooth, tastey and enjoyable. I would definitely have this beer again.
Bottled.  Pours a clear amber color with a creamy white head.  Good lacing.  Really just an average bier; nice but nothing exciting.
Bottle. Very little aroma. Great appearance and lacing. Unfortunately its just a very bland beer. Nice start but nothing after. Seems like a nice example for the style though.
Bottle. Pours a brownish amber with a white head. Matly aroma with a little hops. Full bodied caramel flavor.

Bottle from Waitrose. Amber coloured with a short-lived off-white head. Slightly sweet malt aroma with some grassy hops. Easy drinking with some sweet biscuit malt and honey flavours. Not much of a finish. Ok.

Bottle. Pours a light copper color with a large frothy off white head. The aroma is a deep caramel and honey. Decent lacing on this one. The taste is a honey malt with a smooth finish. The signature beer from anchor, love this beer.
Best in class.  Not too many good california commons out there.  Not my favorit but good and drinkable.
By far the best in its class... All hail the steam beer! If you like a rich malty and hoppy beer... look no further. This is it boys and girls so dont give it a miss.

From the bottle, not a bad beer. Nice caramel color, descent aroma, and above average flavor. More malt than hop, quite easy to drink. You can get this all over, so it is a good beer at bars or restaurants  that dont sell "craft" beer.

Bottle:  Pours a crystal clear copper color with a medium-sized white, foamy head.  Very earthy initially on the nose.  Some light malt notes apparent as well as a yeasty funk, but not necessarily bad or good.  Im just not that overwhelmed by the aroma on this like I typically enjoy with other brews.  Fairly smooth mouth feel leads to a malt dominated flavor along with that earthiness that I cant put my finger on.  Not bad, decent session brew.

The beer pours a rich amber color. It is fairly clear with very little head. The beer smells like a traditional lager with a little bit of hay in the background. Strangely, the beer seems to have a little bit of a wheat flavor in the background. It has a fairly clean taste, but is a little skunky and has a hint of sweetness.
On tap at Fishermans Wharf Pizza. Deep copper. Taking the first sip of this beer is like diving into a barrel of barley. I can never get enough of its malty goodness.
Tasty, I always enjoy this beer, its very hard to go wrong here. I enjoy the lack of bitterness. A great beer with a variety of dinners. Never disappointing. It has a quiet refined flavor elegance.
whiffs of raspberry and almond.  honey brown in the glass, poured a great 2 finger head.  tastes skunky like boiled cabbage.  finishes crisp and sweet, yet largely poor

355 ml bottle (4.8% abv).  Near-clear light amber colored body. Mostly diminishing coarse, slightly tanned head. Caramel and malt aroma with some nutty notes. Scents of dark fruits, bread, ash and candysugar. Light sweet malty and medium bitter taste. Fruity and smokey notes. Light to medium body. Quite mouthfilling. A tasty classic.

12oz bottle.  Pours a hazy, flat amber with a good but fleeting head.  Aroma is crisp and tart with smells of hops, spice, earth, and a slight sweet note of honey.  Taste is flat and malty with some somewhat more bitter flavors of hops occasionally emerging.  A pleasant session beer otherwise lacking in complexity or uniqueness.

A cloudy amber pour with a frothy, but thin head with  sweet, crisp aroma of apricots, caramel, and earthiness - rather complex. The flavor is a great deal more tart and nutty than I expected with an unfortunate skunky after taste, probably from being in the bottle too long. Would be ideal as an accompaniment to ribs or other hearty cut of pork along side of sweet corn and green beans.

Had beer on 1/21/2000.  Color is rich golden brown with good carbonation and head.  Taste is crisp and bitter.  Starting with a light crisp body that goes down bubbly with a lightly sweet malt feel.  Finish is this malt flavor with a smooth bitterness and faint hop flavor.
Erg lekker smaakvol bier.
On tap at YardHouse in San Diego. Average ale. Deep amber color with an initial scent of hops followed by rich malts. Taste is more malty then hoppy. Not bad.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2010 im not going to be able to tell you anything new about this beer that hasnt already been written on the previous 146 pages. it was pretty good, tough. malty and sweet with a slightly hoppy finish. its anchor steam. its tasty.
small white head on a amber beer. smell was hops and some malt. taste was malty, sweet ale with a heavy hop backbone.

The head quickly faded away. I attempted to do well on the pour, but I couldnt get it to stay. The beer has a nice caramel color to it. I also cannot say how much I enjoy the unique style of the bottle. Very fruity aroma! The fermenting process, with the lager yeasts at ales temperatures, must have produced some unique fruit flavors. I really dont smell the aroma hops at all. I am trying to pick them out with my nose, but the fruit smell just dominates. The malts are coming out as well. Having a hard time picking the malts out over the fruit smell. The flavor hop is nice and crisp, and the bittering hop is very mild. The malts are noticeable in the taste, but in my opinion not much more noticeable in the taste than in the smell. The malts get extremely noticeable as the beer warms. I believe they are crystal malts for the beer which gives it this great color. I am starting to pick up on a nutty taste, which is great. I like to complexity of the beer, and enjoy it very much. Very carbonated, and somewhat smooth. Love this Anchor Steam.
A classic.  I like this beer just for the story behind it...and for the unique brewing process.  I would call it a solid body ale thats heavy on the hops.
Pours amber with light head.  The aroma is roasted and fruity.  Taste of grains and nuts with some hops.

12 oz bottle. Poured an orange/amber with a fizzy off white head that quickly disappeared and left no lacing or trace of faom what so ever. Strong malt aroma that has some hint of nutts and flowers. Flavor is similar and has a thin palate with lively carbonation. Although not super complex this beer is highly sessionable and I could see knowcking several of these back while watching some football or at a BBQ.

Head is very small and slightly tan. The color is deep amber color. The smell is floral and toasted malt.  The taste is slightly bitter, floral, hoppy, and toasted malt. The finish is bitter but smooth.

Date: 01/06/1996
Mode: Draft
Source: Taco Mac, Sandy Springs

amber color, slight fruity aroma, hop flavor with a bite, bitter finish
-------- />
Date: 04/15/2007
Mode: bottle
Source: tasting
Score: 2.7 to 3.2

clear amber, lasting fine beige head, streaks of lace, sweet caramel malt aroma with earthy hops, lots of mild earthy hop flavor on a dry caramel malt base, fair amount of spicy hop bitterness in the finish, overall a good earthy character dominates the beer

Aroma: 6/10; Appearance: 7/10; Flavor: 6/10; Palate: 6/10; Overall: 13/20
Rating: 3.2/5.0Drinkability: 7/10
Score: **+/4

Draft at Coney.  I remember having this back in my college days and thinking it was interestingly different, but not for me.  I regret the time that has passed since my first experience.  Light amber in color with a thick white head, foamy.  Little nose available.  A nice malt character with carmel undertones, also notes of fruits and floral hops leading to a crisp finish.  An interesting style that I am now becoming fond of.

Red amber with lacy froth. Boiled sweet caramelised nose with more and more resinous hop mustiness coming across as it warms. Rounded and nuttily malty with a firm bite of hop bitterness to finish. Lingeringly bready after the swallow. Reminds me of Sam Smiths Nut Brown Ale or one of the maltier Dusseldorf Alts. Very pleasant.
Pours amber with a small head. The taste is a bitter hoppy bite with a nutty roasted malt. Gets more smooth as you drink it, but retains a good flavor.

Bottle. Golden pour. Nice white head. Lots of lacing left behind. Not a lot in the nose, some hoppy smell with light grains. Taste is pretty light, some hops, good for a lager. Palate is watery.  Not great, not terrible.

Bottle. Copper color, thick head for most of the drink. Good clean lacing. Mild hoppy nose with sweet malts. Flavor of roasted nuts and black pepper blend nicely with the clean hoppiness. The taste runs right down the middle of a pale ale and lager for me, which makes it taste like a great, hoppy lager or a very smooth, but thin ale. Id put this in the catagory of perfect session beer that wont bored me with a lack of flavor.
Malty aroma, subtle flavor with light hops. Decent beer, better than most domestics. While I understand this to be a classic SF beer, it reminds me of German lagers more than anything else.
Amber color small head. light hops aroma. Taste is a little week. Not much body. I used to get excited about this but now feel it is just slightly above average.

Poured from a bottle.  Has a bit of a head with minimal retention.  Aroma was lightly malt and sweet.  Not much flavor - finishes with a slight bitter taste.  I could drink this but its not my favorite beer.

8/15/07 From the bottle.  Aroma is a blended sweet/sour malt forward with light caramel followed by light citrus and grassy hops.  Appearance is light amber, clear, with a good off-white head.  Flavor is minty/grassy hops forward, followed by musty/earthy tones, then some malt graininess and sweetness.  Mouthfeel is medium/low bodied with a medium carb feel and a dry finish.  Overall, a lot better than I recall, simple, earthy, the definition of the California Common style, could just use more flavor.
Nice amber color, clear, average head, thick. Malty corn syrup aroma, sharp bitteness in the flavor, fizzy then heavy feel. OK brew.
Amber with a thick white head. Grassy and hoppy tones. Malty with some bitterness. Medium body with a dry finish.
My first california common and going to be my last. Pours a reddish amber orange cvolor with a small soapy head. Smells very sour and yeasty. Tastes of sour hops and a little bit of skunk. No thanks!
Straw colored beer with rocky white head.  Maybe amber colored.  Slightly metallic grainy aroma.  Light bitter hops, an almost orange citrus flavor, and light malts iin the flavor.  Smooth finish.
i would like to buy a vowel. i drank this beer at room temp. maybe 65 degrees. i liked it. im sure it would be better a little more chilled but it was totally acceptable this way.

I really enjoyed this beer. Poured a nice beautiful brown color with a bubbly head. This beer has a really nice balance of malty goodness with a little hop bite. As eaglefan noted, it kinda reminded me of Bass as well (do great minds think alike?), but with a fuller malty taste and much more hop presence. A very distinctive sweet malty backbone to this beer. I will have this one again.

Bottle.  Pours almost true amber coloring with a short, white head, which leaves little if no lacing.  Taste is not bad, yet not exciting.  Malts are definitely present, in taste and in aroma.  I dont mind the palate being light, but would like a little more of something to be apparent afterwards.  I would have this again, but wont be running out to the store any time soon.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a light amber color with a very small white head and minimal lacing.  The scent was clean with hints of carmel and malt.  The flavor is crisp with some honey, malt, barley and some yeast.  A very thin mouthfeel makes this a forgetable beer.  Not a bad session, but not one that I was overly excited about either.
UPDATED: JAN 3, 2008 335 ml bottle. 4,8% ABV. Amber color.Off-white head. Malt, hops and fruit. Bitter finish. Very nice low-alcohol-beer.
amber color.. hints of sweet grains.  is really identifiable due to  a unique taste.  a swig of it on the east coast and i can taste the west coast... only way i can describe the uniqueness
I dont how their uber brewing methods hasnt made this the worlds most superior beer, but it a fine beer indeed

Subtle hop aroma. Light malt aroma some sulphitic notes. Possible lactobacillus contamination.  Clear amber color with off white, moderately persistent head. Mild malt flavor hop bitterness dominates the balance. Medium body. Finish is harsh bitter. Definite off flavor. Stale taste is not sour but reminds me of a sour mash in aroma. No astringency. Carbonation is medium high. Im not sure Im drinking a representative beer.

Bought in 12oz bottles at Puffs Six Pack in Lock Haven, PA. Nice coppery colour, thin head dissipates very quickly. NO aroma? Did I buy broken beer? Oh, no, its there but faint. First sip, tastes like its missing something. No mouthfeel to speak of... is this beer or beer-flavoured seltzer water?

Better than mass-market beers, but pretty bland for all that. When I try a small brand, I expect to be awesomed or insulted. This just bores me...

Slightly sour aftertaste, watery finish. I think I wasted my time here.

500 ml bottle. Pours a rich copper-amber color with an off white head that dissapates slowly. Some lacing noted. Light aroma of barley malts, hops and some yeast.  Flavor mirrors the aroma with the hops slightly dominating. Mouthfeel is a bit thin, but come across very clean. Finish is moderate hops, walnuts, and a touch of sweet barley. This beer goes very well with my jambalaya.

Bottle.  Pours a clear, orange-amber color; off-white head with excellent lacing.  Light, wet and toasted malts in the aroma; some cola.  Medium mouthfeel: cola and toasted malts and bread, but errs on the side of sweetness; slightly watery with average carbonation.  Medium, wet malt finish.

on tap. pours clear copper with thin white head. nose is pretty hoppy and biscuity. flavor is pretty fresh and hoppy with toasted biscuit and nuts. pretty nice actually. wow ive never had this beer this fresh and i was really impressed this time. thanks mr. wehrmann.
I really liked this beer, amber colour, medium head, malty aroma with a caramel-honey flavour with a lasting palate, very nice

Pours a medium amber with a large frothy head. Very nice carbonation. Aroma is light bitter hops, malts, detergent, grains. Flavor is mildly sour malts, bitter hops, light spice. Pretty decent overall.

Nice Hoppy aroma,  poured a nice amber color, with a BIG white head that was creamy, head stayed big much of the way down, left a nice lacing,  nice 
malt flavor which is semi-sweet, nice balance, after semi-sweetness passes a very mild bitter which is pleasant, a medium body with a creamy, slightly oily texture, after the initial heavy carbonation it settles into a soft carbonation, very smooth, has a nice medium bitter finish, overall a very enjoyable beer! I would definitely drink again.  I am impressed.  Great job by Anchor.  Served in a stein.

UPDATED: OCT 26, 2009 Decent beer.  Nice amber color.  The aroma is malty, very bread-like, floral and citrus hops.  Nice.  The flavor is bread and butter, malts, honey.  Astrigent piney hoppy finish, lingering.  Medium to medium/thin mouthfeel.  Decent, unique, enjoyable.

I guess this one sets the standard for the steam style: a nice gold tint, highly carbonated, well hopped on the nose and palate, and the clean crisp finish associated with lager yeast.  pretty tasty, certainly not mindblowing but a nice change of pace.
bottle.amber, clear, white foam, light sweetness, medium bitterness, lightly sour, light body, thin feel, average carbonation, long finish, bitter, I did not like this beer at all.
An attractive orange colour with a small head. Decent nutty palate balanced by a modest hop character. Pretty nice.
Bottel.33cl. The head dissipated quickly leaving only a ring of bubbles around the rim of the glass and no lacing. Pale with light hoppy aroma. Solid firm bittering with decent hop aroma/flavor.
Copper colour, almost no head. Lots of malts in the aroma. Flavour: malty, going into a bitter-sweet aftertaste. A bit watery also. Ok beer.

Pours a clear yellowish-copper with a small beige head.  Aroma is largely fruity hops.  Taste is fruity hops, with a bit of a malt characteristic as well.  A bit of a metallic aftertaste, and very carbonated.  Many people I know like this beer, but Im not the biggest fan of it.

Clear copper body with a small beige head.  Stinks a little on the nose, something like moisture, sweat and wet leather.  Light but not very pleasant (the beer was fresh).  Dry crusty grainy malts, some roastiness with faint burnt caramel, a little rust and metal and a hint of vegetable soup.  The carbonation was aggressive and was helpful in masking some of the ferrous taste.  I understand this is a beer made using old-fashion brewing technique.  Didnt do it to me.  Maybe you had to be around back then to enjoy this beer nowadays.  If youre old enough that you hear your favourite songs in the elevators, then give it a try.
Very nice beer.  Enjoyed in a bar in S.F.  Nothing wrong with this flagship.  Enjoy it with friends. Dont care about what you are drinking.  Its fine.
Bottle.Dark amber,White head.Caramel aroma with some floral highlights.Malt sweetness and plenty of hop bitterness for a nice balance.Long finish,medium body.Good.

My husband has been trying to get me to try this for quite some time. I have a bottle in the cellar, but had an opportunity to have it last night on draft. So I gave it a shot. Very uniqe beer, I thought! Poured a very light amber color, slight head. Very light malt sweetness up front. Another flavor or "something" I just couldnt place, followed by the hoppy bitterness in the finish. I liked this one.
355 ml bottle.  Pours a nice amber with a course off-white head.  Subtle, rather malty nose.  Medium body with an initial sweetness quickly balanced by an appropriate hop bitterness.  Quaffable.

bottle.  nice dark amber with off white foamy head.  caramel aroma.  first sip is malty with an element of hops and a not unpleasant alcohol flavor.  ends with a nice bitter.  initially the boozey element pushed out the other flavors but as it warmed things balanced out. its a tastey beer for sure.  not one of my favorites but good.
picked up a 6 pack and i really enjoyed it.  i finished this 6 pack within the working week.

12 oz bottle for lunch at Zebbs.  Ive had Anchor before, I believe one of the darker brews, and liked it alot.  This was also a very enjoyable amber ale.  Dark amber color,  Nice and firm, though nothing that marked it as particularly distinctive.  Was a good beer to go with the meal, and frankly it was nice to see something other than Sam Adam & the other usual suspects in a chain restaurant.
Had on draft-amber color,small white head.Taste of malt,hops,slight yeast and floral notes.Good and easy drinking brew.
Easy and drinkable.  Everything is fairly mild from the hop aroma to the comlexity and texture of the taste.  Probably would make a good backyard BBQ beer.
UPDATED: JUN 5, 2008 This is a very good beer. Perfect for a summertime session. Nice color, nice and easy to drink. Aroma couldve been better, but it doesnt hurt the beer that badly overall.
My god this was the worst beer ever. It was horrible. god awful too. Stay clear
Had this at The Flying Saucer in Raleigh.  Had a nice amber color with a creamy head.  Better enjoyed in a glass than in the bottle.

Clear amber color with small creamy head. Subtle malty aroma. Strong malty flavor and hopps, som small notes of citrus and anise or licorice . Aftertaste is malty and hoppy, small notes of yeast. Very high carbonition, nice for this kind of beer.Medium body. Finish is very much of licorice.

Rated 6/30/07.  Slightly cloudy gold color.  Small head with no lacing.  Mild aroma and flavor.  Picked up some malt, hops, and flowers.  Decent beer, but I expected more after trying the Porter.  Just kind of boring.
Amber colour, great thick rocky head.  Nice mix of hops and malt.  Finish can be a bit pungent near the end.  Sparkling palate with a decent amount of power between the nose and tongue.
xxx  Had at State College 2006 Beer expo.  It was a long day but from what I recall it was pretty good.

Yeah! My 100th rating... This beer had a nice head, with a very nice light amber colour, mice malt and hop balance with some nice bitterness to it, almost tasted like a Sam Adams Boston lager but with out as much bite. Will drink again.

UPDATED: JUL 23, 2007 Drank this one in the dark in at the Almamo Drafthouse movie theatre, so I didnt see the color, but it had a decent head to it.  Very nice and fragrant hoppiness, but not overly so.  Taste is good, with a good bitter kick and hoppy floraly citrusy taste but with some definite maltiness in there too.  I was expecting more hoppy bitterness from what I remember of the first time I had this beer, but was pleased at the amount it had, and the reasonable lasting hoppy aftertaste.  I liked this beer, and especially the Anchor Porter these guys make, which is one of my favorites. I look forward to trying more from them.
bottle.  nice, nice amber color in the glass.  A comendable effort but the finish was somewhat soapy.  It kind of wore on me as I went but..... a good beer overall.
Slight malty aroma, amber beer with nice hoppiness, bitter finish that could be longer; Ill have it again, if only for the history
A fair quality not too expensive daily drinker, easy drinking but with some flavor.
Pours a nice caramel color...scents of the malt..this is a very nice beer that reminds me of college days.  Cant go wrong with this one.
Cereal aroma. syrupy with hints of pine. Pours golden blonde.  Smooth and crisp, light and very easy to drink.
Bottle.  Very malty aroma. Moderate lacing.  Caramel color with slight murkiness.
A slightly bitter beer, good color, fairly easy to drink. Not something that I would drink more than a few at a time

12 oz bottle with a factory date code on the label. 
Clear copper, with a two finger off white head. Moderate lacing.
Aroma is malty, caramel mostly with a touch of nuttiness.
Flavor is caramel, nutty with a spicy hop finish.

It had been nearly a decade since Id last had this beer, and I found it to be much better than I had remembered it to be. It pours a clear orange with a rocky, off-white head. The nose is fairly muted but with notes of caramel malts and light earthy hops. Light to medium-bodied, slick and soft with a lightly bitter finish, this is a very drinkable beer. The flavor is a sweet, effervescent caramel front with a lightly woody and bitter finish. I can see why this one is a "gateway" beer for many.

Bottle. Moderate hoppy, moderate malty, light bread. An average white creamy head, mostly lacing. Orange body, a little bit cloudy. Bitter flavor, not much sweetness, average duration. On the palate the beer has a medium body, dry texture and a soft carbonation. The finish is slightly metallic. Nice one, nicer than the Liberty Ale.
Clear amber body with white head.  Head quickly dissipates.  Not much aroma.  Tastes of malt and hops blend.  Bit bitter at the end.  Decent beer.

Light ale with a carmel/hops finish.  Not much aroma to savor, but it looks good, pours well and goes down easy without a bitter aftertaste.  Ive had better beers at this price, but it was worth trying.

12oz bottles.  6pack split with brie.  The third one I poured into a pint glass.  This is a copper, dry, reddish ale.  The hops work very well with the dry, crisp finish.  It is light, hoppy, and refreshing.  The unique bottle makes it the perfect summer grilling session beer.

Shared 12 oz. bottle with Pat. Pours a fizzy light orange color.  No strong aromas were noticed.  Nice blend of malt and hoppy flavors.  Light and refreshing for the summer and erfect with salmon ka-bobs.  Mild but tasty.
bottle.  avg., fizzy, white head into clear lightly sparkling amber body.  hops are noticed as well as light malts.  thin body.  fizzy carboation.  very drinkable beer.

Pours a sparkling orange with a loose but decent head and minimal lace. Aroma of light fruit and hops. Great hops right off the bat, then slowly transforms into fruity, nutty taste. Sweet amber malt, lager-like roundness to the aftertaste, some lingering peppery-spicy hops. Slightly creamy body due to the everpresent head mixing with each sip, slightly thin but high in carbonation (seems to be common with Anchor beers). A real "table" beer - good with anything, very drinkable and complex enough to keep me interested. Not bad!

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2017 355ml bottle. (6:4:6:3:11=3.0)
Orangy-red, clear, lightly fizzy to keep the light head alive. Nutty and malty aroma, some raisins. At one rating: Huge bitter smack in the mouth with a woody nutty malt taste. Aftertaste is nutty, and lasts for ages. At another tasting a year later: Sweet alcoholic taste, some caramel, some rubber. Rather sweet. Not much finish. Drinkable, but nothing too exciting. Rating is an average of those two.
Rerate: 330ml bottle (Nimeta, Tallinn) (6:3:6:3:12=3.0)
Woh, 9 years on. Fruity malty aroma, almost like a northern brown ale. Taste also malty, woody, and nutty. Again, quite like an ale in many respects. Palate moderate, carbonation a bit high. Nice characterful brew.

Pours a nice dark golden color. Hint of a reddish tint. Small, but long lasting foam head. Not much aroma to speak of, mainly malts and caramel. Has a nice lightly bitter, malty taste. Ill be damned if I dont taste a hint of apple and grapefruit. Yeah, definatly grapefruit. And light spaice. Pehaps a tinge of cinnamon? Strange spice for such a beer. Nice dry aftertaste. Overall, an American Classic. Great tasting easy to drink, worth the $10.50 I pay for a friggen 6 pack. Cheers!

Colour is redish amber with a nice white head. The aroma is sweet malt without any hops but with hints of alcohol. Flavor is a bit bitter with lots of maltyness. Has a dry finish with a semi long aftertaste.
sweet smell, pours a thin, light brown. strong malt taste,fruit and spice. decent hop finish.

The beer has a deep amber color, thick creamy head, and rich flavor.   The smell is predominately caramel all-malt mash with some herbal nutty aromas floating around too.  From my impressions it was halfway between a English Brown Ale and an American Pale Ale.  After my eleventh, I was wasted.

Bottle. the beer that launched the craft revoluation. Once a dud, now a landmark. Nice amber color, off-white head...stays well developed and holds aroma. Scents of spice?, fruit, grain.  May detect some sweetness, but overall hops is the sensation. For some-too much, but does have a nice drinkable finish. Must try if on the beer history tour.
bottle. 2 finger head, dark  amber with a great swallow but too bitter a finish for me.  This reminded me too much a the typical big brew. hoppy beers.  This ones just not for me.

On tap and bottles in various places.  A nice beer on a warm day.  Very balanced-- no dominant hop, malt, or yeast flavor.  It definitely has a unique flavor-- I just cant put my finger on it.  Probably the yeast from the warm fermentation.

Nice amber colour with a big head. Smells like an ale with all the fruitiness. The taste itself is not too hoppy, but a little bit on the bitter side of things. Some sweetness comes around while drinking, but really sticks in the mouth afterwards. It is either sippable or swigable, so good times.

somewhat disappointed.  reminded me of a watered down version of the far superior liberty ale by the same.  bitter almost medicinal quality to hops w/out quite enough malt balance IMO.  quick, slippery, eel like quality on palate that was somewhat displeasing.  very little lacing and quick disappearing head.  stick w/ their liberty ale - much better.

12 Oz bottle poured into a pint.  Light amber in color with 2 fingers of creamy eggshell head, looks pretty tasty!  I smell barley and hops with a hint of Apple.  A bit hoppy at first run but the hoppiness soon subsides and whats left is a very drinkable beer.  It left me wanting another one, a very decent American brew.

Strong barley aroma. It has the color of apple juice and a thin light orange head which does not coat the glass at all. The taste is moderately strong, but only of grain. Its only slightly bitter and decidedly not sweet, more unsweet than actually bitter. Decent brief apple finish. Average, yet enjoyable.

Try though they may, other breweries cant quite duplicate, or make better this true American classic! 
Fairly strong hop aroma. Appearence a cross between a German dunkles and an English bitter. Matter of fact, tastes like a cross between the two! Hops initially dominate the nose and palate, giving way to the sweet - yet not cloying - malt. A real treat when fresh, but it doesnt seem to stand up well on the shelves, so buyer beware!

Bottle.  I liked the taste of this beer, but wasnt too impressed with the appearance and aroma.  I had very light head at the pour with no lacing.  It smelled prominently of CO2 and caramel.
The flavor however was fruity, light hop character, and had a hint of caramel.  The finish was average (and dry) that left a bitter taste in my mouth.
12 ounce bottle at Old Chicago in Eden Prairie. Amber with a good-sized head. Hoppy aroma. Taste had a nice balance of grassy hops and malt. Some bitterness.

Dark brown colored, cloudy appearance. Little yellow head. Sweetness, fruits, toffee and some British flowery hops in aroma, mild banana there too. Medium bodied. Flavor has more toffee with sweet caramel, some cardboardy hops also there. Aftertaste dries with lemon, apple and biting carbonation.

This beer is a typical California style steam beer.  Pours the typical light brown/tan color with a reddish hue.  The malt was a little overdone, as it overwhelmed the hops, especially in the bitterness factor...even though it had outstanding balance and depth with malt/hops taste, the hops had no role in aroma as compared with the malt.  The barley used is absolutely great in this beer, but I really wish it had more sweet/bitter hit to it....Great beer though, not terribly exciting to me though....for a hopshead.  Solid, however.

Bottle. Reddish amber, nice creamy light tan head that was very persistent. Looks like what I think beer should look like. Aroma of malt, yeast, hops, lots of things going on, but not overpowering. Well balanced flavor, leans toward the hops, but still with good sweetness. Good, smooth mouthfeel. A winner.

Picked up 12-oz bottle from Cellars Wine & Spirits in St Paul, MN. Pours a burnt penny copper amber brew with a thick lumpy off white head that slowly diminishes. Nice lacing. Aroma of fruity barley malt, flowery hops, caramel and a touch of toffee. A medium body brew. Taste is all barley malt with a crisp hop aftertaste. A pleasant, and enjoyable Californian Common.

Color is a beautiful dark brownish amber, while head is thin but fine. Aroma is weak but pleasant, decidedly malty. (However, my allergy was acting up some when I tried this.) Flavor is rich, malty and bitter with a snipped of fruit undertone. Jazzy, zingy, nice and rough, it is a pleasant and refreshing, if not spectacular, lager.
UPDATED: JUL 8, 2007 350 mL bottle.  Clear brownish amber color with thin white head, bready aroma, taste malty and tangy, crisp finish.

Pours a nice amber color into the glass with a white head.  The aroma has a sweet malty smell with minimal hopping.  The flavor is really a nice malty brew with some caramel and just enough hops to cut through.  I really like this beer and it is one of the best/most drinkable beers out there.

Rated 3/1/06:  Didnt know what to expect when I bought this therefore I had no expectations. Pours a nice orange/amber with a creamy head that sticks around for the duration. Minimal lacing clings to the glass and a slow but steady stream of carbonation is present. This beer is extremely aromatic primarily consisting of sweet malts. The aroma is absolutely wonderful. The taste is very malty, sweet, and even a bit hoppy. There is a good balance present in this beer and makes for an enjoyable experience. The more I try this the more I like it. Creamy and full on the palate with a smooth finish. Overall this is a great beer that I could easily enjoy in any setting.
Thin head, mild flavor and aroma with plenty of hops.  Smooth on the palate.

This is a very good amber ale-style beer. It is unique in its creation, but overall extremely well-balanced. The nose is a little mild, but the tast and finish are loaded with mild sweet notes and a decent hop balance.

a golden amber with small and unlasting head. nutty orange peel aroma with mild floral notes. medium, oily body. honey and cream jumped out on first taste hay and light citrus with some bitterness. well balance and very acceptable for its availability
Bottle.  Pours a nice amber color with a quickily diminishing tan head.  Has an aroma of honey and fruits, light hops.  Taste is light hops and slightly sweet.  Drinks very smooth.  A good beer.

An enjoyable beer.  Crisp and refreshing.  Attractive amber/orange color.  Small head that diminishes to virtually no head quite quickly.  Im not that talented at picking out a half dozen hints of flavors from beers, but orange peel is the one that jumps out at me with this one.  Overall quite good.

Gifted to me from my co-worker, Jeff. Thanks!  Lightly hopped aroma of mint, an earthy mint with some bready, brown-sugar malt.  Amber in color, clear with a thin, off-white head that fades.  Fairly well balanced, sweet and malty with a subtle hop presence and a hint of grains.  Other flavors include: honey, mint, caramel, a tiny hint of bubblegum and a grainy/earthy finish.  Surprisingly full bodied, but with a nice, almost oily texture.  It feels very satisfying.  Overall, it is just a little too sweet.  Id like to try this with just a bit more bitterness.

This one didnt quite meet my 3.5 benchmark...meaning I wont go out of my way to buy it in the future....it gets the old, "will buy if I have to cause Im fiending for a Beer away from home, and this is the best that store or restaurant has to offer.."...
Somewhat dark orange in color.  Respectable and easy to drink.  Not as great as its reputation.

draught version.  Light amber/golden in color with a medium off white head.  Aroma is lightly fruity, floral, and some light malty notes.  Taste is also lightly fruity, some floral hops as well as light malts, and grains.  Finishes lightly bitter.  About time I tried this one!

Poured into a Pint glass from a bottle. Light white fizzy off-white head with a amber colour. Toasted-nut hop aroma. Initial Taste is similiar  to a whole grain toasted bread. Interesting. Finising with a malty, slight hop bitterness, ending with a diminishing head.

Light amber beer from a botle, average off-white head that fades away quickly.  Sparkling clear.  Wonderful aroma of nutty toasted grain, sprucy hops, some grass, cola and apple.  Flavor crisp, very clean, smooth and toasty.  Low fruitiness, just clean toasty malt with a soft bitterness, balanced toward the malt.  Nice tangy hop flavor finishes it up.  Moderately dry.  A fantastic, underrated ale.  Kudos to Mr. Maytag and his team.
Tap at Lemmys, Leiden, Netherlands: Deep amber coloured beer thats have a well balanced bitterness an d some nutty taste.

Thin aroma, rather wheat-like. Reminds me of German beers with a moderately musky smell. Pours brown, clear, with a bubbly head. Thick, creamy mouth feel. Thin in the flavor department with a mild sweetness at the end.
From a bottle pours golden with a little bit of head, leaving a little lacing.  Good flavor, good aftertaste.

Bottle, 355ml. A golden colour with a small head. Aroma of floral hops and a little nuttiness. Taste is hoppy and nutty, with a little caramel and a touch of malt. A fairly bitter and slightly acidic, sweet finish. Moderate carbonation. I could drink this all day.

pours sparkling medium amber with a rocky off-white head.  Aroma is moderatly malty, with grapefruit hop aroma.  the aroma is dominated by yeast yesters of leather, earth, cobwebs and apples.  Flavoris balanced twards the bitter side, with a lingering aftertaste.  light bodied and watery.
TOO MUCH OF A CHORE TO RE-WRITE MY COMMENTS REGARDING MANY YEARS OF ANCHOR BEER ENJOYMENT. IT ENDS WITH I LIKED IT BETTER WHEN I WAS IN MY 20S

This beer pours a nice head and then fades away very quickly. There is not much of a smell to it. As you drink it you pick up carmel malt and bitter hops. There is not much of a flavor that sticks around after you drink it.

Pours a slightly hazy amber with a micro-bubble off-white head. Smells of caramel malt and floral hops. The flavor is bitter hops, countered by mild malty flavors. The finish is dry and short. The body is thin, but the carbonation is smooth and pleasant. Great for straight up kickin it.
12oz bottle. Tastes like  stout/porter without any bitterness or off-notes. No aftertaste, refreshing, overall great beer.
Bottle. 12 FL. OZ. Clear amber color with frothy white head.  Hoppy, floral aroma with some apple.  Smooth, balanced palate.  Bitter flavor with long, dry finish.  Affordable and drinkable.
bottle... poures a nice amber with a slightly off white frothy head.  Malty aroma, flavors of malt, hops, caramel, brisk finish.

UPDATED: AUG 4, 2007 Malts with slight toffee in the aroma and backed by some hop freshness. Balanced flavour, but not a lot going on really. OK session but nothing mindblowing.

Ok, a quick re-rate. I said OK session but nothing mindblowing? Sure, it isnt mindblowing but its a pretty good session. I mean, its one of the beers Ive bought most of since they started selling it here. So I gave it a higher rating.
Really feel bad... Vin and John love.. Julie... I just thought it was rotten!!

Draft: Pours a nice light amber color with a 1 finger white head. Nice malt aroma with a litte floral hops. Flavor is at once light and crisp with nice smooth maltiness Minty hop flavor comes through with nice subtlety. Ends crisply with a little herbal floral bitterness.
This is not an exceptional beer. It has a strangely bitter taste and a very light body. Not a whole lot of flavor either.

Pours clear light red-orange in color.  Good white foamy head.  Light roasted malt flavor with a slight fruity ending.  A little watery mouth feel.  Not as carbonated as it looks.  Feels like Im drinking a lite beer.  The Steam is not as flavorful as other Anchor brews.
good malty flavor, actually quite bitter, but that is what is indicated in the style.  VERY DRINKABLE one of my favorite session beers

Very sweet aroma of some caramel malts. Appearance is a nice bright amber orange. Flavor is dominated by sweetness of malt with a small hop backbone that is relatively crisp.. It was pretty easy to drink, light to medium bodied. A very nice beer.

Sweet caramel malt aroma with some lemon and orange zest and a hint of plum.  Flavor is a solid caramel malt body with light citrus and bit sweet dark fruit with a crisp lager finish.  Body is medium to light with a fair bit of carbonation.  A really flavorful yet perfectly drinkable.  This is a great session beer.
Pours golden amber with a large white head. Light citric hop aroma, but not much else. Roasted malt, and light lemony zest flavor.

Rich amber and deep burnt sienna hue with a silky white head. Yeasty malty and bready full bodied nose.  This is an old standby but in todays beer world is might appear a little outdated. Unique and unexceptional lager.  Very interesting beer.  Perhaps not a beer geeks prime pick, but still mighty tasty.

Rather unique shaped 12 oz bottle with a twist off cap. Date code 1896, survived well. Aroma of uncooked leavened bread dough. Beautiful pour, darkish brown orange and creamy. Ring for a tea froth head. Head is certainly off white leaning towards very light brown orange.  Gentle carbo streams rising within. Hey, nice short story on the label!  Smells like a stronger ale, sweet candy and all. Taste impacts citrus rind.  Bitter hops or is that raosted malts?  Pretty hard personality. Apparent high alky content by flavor. Medium low tingly back of tongue gentle fizz. Not worse tasting than an imp stout or IPA. Finish hovers around for a while during the time you contemplate it; is that too bitter?  Seems to be much more stronger than the 4.9 would indicate.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Light amber pour with medium head.  Malty aroma.  Flavor is mild malt balanced with mild hops.  Very drinkable.
Wow, surprisingly unique, Im not too sure how to describe it.  Theres just a hint of hops at the end, and you can taste the malt, but its not overpowering.

Pours a nice copper color with little to no head. Aroma is a mild yeast with some malts. Taste is refreshing with some sweet malts and a mild bitter finish. I drank the bottle in less than 10 minutes, so very drinkable and very sessionable. Excellent beer.
this one doesnt attack the palate, but isnt bad-tasting either. nice amber color, mild head, not too thick.

I hadnt had this beer in 10 years, and a lots happened to me and the world of beer since then.  It is a substantial lager, lightly sweet and heavily malted.  Not bad, but hardly an assault on the senses.  Id give it a weak recommendation.

The beer is a pleasing golden amber with decent had that rapidly dissipates.  Aroma is lightly sweet and just a bit hoppy.  There is very little hoppiness in the flavor, which is rather malty and very sweet which was OK.  Mouthfeel is lightly carbonated, smooth, and pleasant.

Gigin alone at the bottom of the hill
Our protagonist named Bill
Sets his sights on an anchor steam pint
All he, needs is thirteen quarters
Congregated in his hat.
Draft: Plain, but still quality.  lightly sweet and moderately bitter.  nice dark gold.  lively on the tongue with a moderate bitter finish.

Poured into a pint, color is a deep clear amber , with an inch of creamy , off white foam that dissipates to quarter inch; well sustained by a constant rising carbonation. A fair amount of lacing left on the glass. Taken to the nose ,aromas are of grain , earthy , some fruity notes and slightly bready qualities. Raw , grainy flavors come first ( and quickly) , then some bitter earthiness and a slighty citric and bitter hop finish. Interesting floral flavor here and there. This is a very unique and neat beer. An in yo face , grainy-raw ride , full of character and intrigue. Just a great beer.
amber with a firm head. Citrus hops and spices in the aroma. Nice bitterness with a hoppy finish. Nice brew and well balanced

Transparant amber with a small head & good lacing. A rounded aroma, instantly recognizable as Anchor, with some citric hoppiness and a peculiar highlands-whiskey style malt profile. Taste was slighty hoppy upfront and finished with that characteristic malt. Gave the impression of strong alcohol content (even though this is one is relatively low on alcohol). Large mouthfeel, medium/low carbonation. Not at all what I expected, decent brew though.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2008 Bottle. Copper/gold color, small white head. Hop aroma, pine? Somewhat bitter on the tongue, a crisp bite. Mild caramel flavor, hop bite, Average. Needs more flavor; well made beer in its own right but a bit too much bite for me.
Nice copper hue, but almost no head. Light malty aroma, nice crisp flavor of hops and malt balanced well. Light mouth feel, dry finish. one fo the best session beers ever.

Pours copper w/ a medium semi creamy froth. Residual lacing is full and thick. Aroma of brisk malts and mild biscuits. Medium nectar w/ ample residual effers. A malty brew w/ a twitch of bicuits. Theres a mild bitterness from start to finish. No off flavors. A tasty brew w/ a perfectly bittered finish.

Bottle.  Dark coppery amber.  Head decent, minimal lacing.  Nose is a bit hoppy but not too exciting.  The taste is more of the same, crisp and ending bitter.  Mouthfeel leaves a bit to be desired.  Decent beer overall, though.
this beer is just interesting enough to keep me coming back, but never hooks me or astounds.  the yeast strain is very unique, but the beer could use a bit heavier malt and hop backbone
I havent had this beer in years until today.  Pours a nice dark amber, almost orange.  Aroma of sweet malt.  Taste is crisp, a bit sour, with a bitter aftertaste.  A good beer.
Bottle.  Aroma of dark fruit and bready malt.  Flavor was initially of sweet malt, but then kind of like medicine with a crisp / bitter finish.

Poured a pretty pure orange; a little dark.  Some visible carbonation.  ARoma was a little medicinal; a lot of bready malt and maybe some dark fruit tones.  Was very crisp flavor; some roasted malt with some hops; not a very good flavored hop taste.  Some nuttiness.  Not overly bad, but nothing great about it.
Started drinking this a long time ago and always respected its subtle flavoring and aroma.  Nowadays, I find it to be a little light for my tastes however.

Bottle.  One of the first beers I had that started me down the craft beer path.  Pours amber with a decent head.  Aroma is sweet malts.  Flavor is a balanced mix of roasted malts and hop bitterness.  Dry finish.  Medium bodied.
Amber beer with pleasant light aroma. A slightly sweet malt flavor and a crisp hop bitterness that is about right for this weight of beer. Pretty smooth with a light hop finish. Nice beer.
aroma i smalty and sweet just a little hops.  color is a nice orange. taste is pretty solid.  good full flavor, nothing spectacular but not a lot to say against it either.
dark amber color.  malty aroma.  roasted nut malt flavor with hops for a bitter finish
On tap. Nice dark amber color with diminishing head. Aroma is malty and the flavor is a nice roasted, nutty malt with the hops appearing for a nice bitter finish. A good standard.
From the tap.  Poured a orange-amber color.   Smelled of hops/spices with a veeerrrrryyy faint smell of fruit.  Sharp hop notes with a bisharp, clean, and bitter finish.  Dry palate with medium body.
Anchorsteam is a great california beer.  Unbelievably smooth like a lager but a little more fullbodied.

I dont smell anything. It is, however and extremely pretty copper color. What little of a head there was disappeared rather quickly.  Hoppy and alittle maltly. A bit of pine needles. Very carbonated and feels like a common lager. Nice beer all around. Like it alot.
I didnt enjoy it. Too carbonated.  Malty aroma, light taste.  Strong feel.

UPDATED: MAR 24, 2007 Bottle. Pours brownish golden with an off-withe head. Wonderful roasted malt aroma with a creamy butter-scotch touch, and floral hops. Medium bodied and very smooth. A slightly malt sweetness is overthrown by a pleasant and lingering bitterness. Delicious brew.

Pours an amber color with an off white head.  Aroma is of sweet malts, grassy tones, and a slight hint of floral hops.  Flavor is the same and doesnt linger very long and doesnt have much of an after taste.  There are other Anchor brews I would take over this one.
The creamy mouthfeel and caramel corn body are the two standout attributes of this beer.  Drinks easy but in the end is a bit one dimensional - but the style isnt exactly wild either.
I would consider this to be more of a lager than an ale. Dark color with a roasted coffee aroma. Leaves an herb-like after taste. Not a bad beer to have every once in a while.

12oz bottle.  Aroma:  Lager-ish malt aroma, floral, grapes, light metallic, toasted nuts.  Appearance:  Dark amber in color and hazy.  Off white head was full and foamy with good retention.  Good lacing.  Flavor:  Cereal malt, light fruitiness (grapes and pears), floral and earthy hops, toasted nuts.  Medium low bitterness.  Fairly clean finish.  Palate:  Medium bodied.  Medium carbonation.  Overall:  Been a long time since Ive had one of these.  Not bad, but certainly not great.  Unoffensive and easy to drink.
This has never been one of my favorites.  It comes off as uninspiring.  The deep color is nice and the palate seems to leave a lot to be dsired...I would think this would have more complexity.

UPDATED: MAR 11, 2007 Whether you compare this California Common to Ales or Lager, I dont think it is good for either catagory.  Absolutely nothing stands out with this one.  Sour, skunky, carbonated... Keep it in San Fran.
Bottle. Clear, deep amber colour, good offwhite head. Grassy hops aroma, hints of wet cardboard? Fruity and grassy flavours, quite bitter. Had expected more.

(Bottle 355ml) Amber beer. Very pronounced hopiness. Flavours of a nice combination between black chocolate and oranges. Maybe some crystal malt character? Bitter finish. It surely isnt an outstanding beer.
UPDATED: MAY 17, 2007 This amber beer had a solid aroma of malt and tasted a bit bitter. Smooth swallow despite the bitter taste, not bad - not great.
nice offering. some sweet malt in the flavour, and some nice hops, but not as upfront as i would expect. decent flavour, nothing outstading, and overall nice product.

355 ml bottle, courtesy of Cardinal pub, Stavanger. Imported to Europe by www.bierenco.nl . ABV is 4.8%. The beer starts gushing out of the bottle when opening. Deep golden to amber colour, decent head. Nice aroma of fruity hops, malt and raisins, hints of bakery and oak. Low carbonation in the glass, soft mouthfeel. The flavour is malty sweet with caramel and some crisp hops. Decent hoppy bitterness in the aftertaste. Uncomplicated, but okay.

Aroma: yummy, appropriately caramely malt, chunky hops, raisiny sweetish and natural.
Appearance: yellowish, appetizing foam, brass/winegum orange, clear.
Flavour: like a good lager, nice bitterness, simple, crispy, some funkiness á la märzen, some sourishness.
Palate: alot of co2...some slimyness, refreshing.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2009 Draft from rake. Whats a California Common? Amber with thin white malt head. Nose of hops and barnyard. Taste to match. Short dry finish. One dimensional. Its ok I guess.
*Re-rate - What an odd end to a most amazing evening... Bottle @ my local thats been around since the 1700s, by the way, longer than the US has been founded...Probably a haunt of that "ripper guy" back in the day given the area but yeah, the beer...Copper with a white head. Nose of malt, wheat and hops. Taste is orange and barley with some slight spice, yeast and malt notes also. Slightly watery with some hops in the finish. Not awful but not great either, unfortunately a step down in the re-rate dept... *Re-re-rate -  Copper coloured with a thin off white head. Nose of sweet bready malts, ginger and hints of berries. Taste much the same, again sweet bready malt, caramel and a gingery, slightly bitter hop finish. Although, it does seem to vary I found it quite nice this time. Looking back, I can sure write some tripe, lol. Oh well, back up it goes. (previously 5, 3, 5, 3, 13)

355 ml bottle. Light copper colour. Clear, and with a small off-white head. Not that high carbonation level. Piney and nutty aroma. Nutty from darker malts and pine from the hops. Crisp flavours with a nice refreshing dose of hops, both flavouring hops and bittering hops. Light-bodied, but lots of flavour. Smooth aftertaste with some hops bitterness and remnants of carbonation. Nice, and something special without being too complex and challenging.

UPDATED: OCT 3, 2008 Very nice brilliant orange under a not so-lasting beige thin head. Not that aromatic in the nose but fantastic in the mouth.Perfectly balanced, with a very nice bitter finish. Dangerously hi-drinkable.
Had my first Anchor Steam at Fishermans Warf. Good longevity on the head; good mix of moderate hops and grainy malts. Slightly bitter and dry--but overall very good.
A good solid beer.  Pours a hazy reddish-amber, with a quickly fading head.  The aroma hints at malts and a hint of chocolate.  Good solid flavor, but with a short finish.  A very nice session beer.
Golden red. Dull aroma.  Tastes like cardboard with a bite. It is thin and dry on the palate. But hey, it is a classic.

For some odd reason, this reminds me of what I thought beer tasted and smelled like as a child.  All that aside, it is quite pleasant to drink with a subtle fruityness and would make a nice session beer.
good blend of malt and yeast heavier on the hops, flavor is evident pours a pretty red color with a light beige head. tasty beer.

Bottle. Pours a clear amber color with a frothy tan head.  Light aroma with malt and fruit accents.  Flavor is well balanced between bitter hops and a malty sweetness with light fruity overtones.  Palate is light and somewhat watery with ok carbonation.  Duration in light maltiness. Good and very drinkable.

Clear  amber color with small creamy head.
Subtle malty aroma.
Strong malty flavor and hopps, som small notes of citrus and anise or licorice .
Aftertaste is malty and hoppy, small notes of yeast.
Very high carbonition, nice for this kind of beer.Medium body.
Finish is very much of licorice.

I was actually very fond of this brew. I had it on Draught about 2 hours ago...actually, I have a total of 50 Oz. It was very reminiscent of a Lager (Yeungling, perhaps) but with that very hoppy finish, a la a good ole IPA. I would definitely drink this again.
an amber colour with a  malty nose, and a bitter strong malt with a light hint of honey.

A nice beer. Honestly I find the taste to be a little strong and not smooth to the mouth. A great original beer and if you are in San Francisco you have to try it, however I understand why some people dont care for it, it takes a while to adjust to.
Bottle. Pleasant aroma. Good balance of hops and malt. Has a very smooth finish. Good Beer!
This is a great beer.  Good clean taste.  Ive picked up a couple of sixers that tasted weird, but Its pretty much one of my staples.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo NY. One of my original so called micros. Amber color with decent head. Medium & creamy body. Well done but sort of bland

Its a good beer, yeah, time to review the stuff that usually gets passed over because its good, solid brew, but not one that I would not normally pick up a sixer of, but you know its on tap at my favorite BBQ restaurant. 

Copper, white head,sightly tart first taste that pops out into a great malty. Easy to drink, tasty and like I said, a solid great brew.
wishing i had some more of these, really good session beer. served in schooner Glass, really enjoyed the malt rich flavour kept a nice head and was happy with carbonation, looking forward to more

Copper pour with a cloudy white head.  Musty carpet hops and doughy pale malts dominate the aroma.  The lemon pissiness I get in a lot of pale malt brews is obvious in the flavor alongside the decently thick malts.  Citrus sourness and white bread, essentially, with a little sweat.  Forgettable.
Reminded me of drinking Aussie beer. Quite a heavy body and certainly refreshing, but nothing distinct about it

Reddish beer with ok head. Quite bubbly.
The aroma is malty with nice fruity esters. The taste is initially full, with malt dominating and the esters making it rather fat and full. As the malt gives way to a medium c-hop flavour, the palate dries out and ends with a nice, crisp bitterness.
Nothing special but quite nice.

Decent beer, interesting in that it got worse the more I consumed.
Butter, almost rubbery nose.  Decent flavor, but there isnt a lot of it.
Average bitter finish.
If this beer would kick it up a notch, it would be a contender.

On draft and in bottles at various places throughout CA:  This could be my favorite session beer of all time.  Having just spent a weekend in S.F., where this beer is EVERYWHERE, I had my share of this stuff.  It was born and bred to be a session beer, and it has not changed one bit.  Anchor is a true American gem of a brewery that has done a lot of the craft brew industry.   Good stuff.

A mid copper brown coloured beer with a thick white head. A light, malty aroma, with a touch of zesty citrus fruit, then a utty maltiness. A fizzy mouthfeel. Dry hoppy taste to start, biscuity, that then comes through as a light, malty flavour. A little weak in the finish. (Bottle - purchased from The Beers of Europe, Setchey, Norfolk for £1.45 a bottle)

Bottled(355ml). -at the Pianeta Birra, Rimini
Rating No. 1500
Pale amber/bronze coloured, medium sized thick head. Mild roasted malt and pronounced hoppiness. Also nutty and fruit notes. Pleasant dry hoppy finish. Smooth, complex and tasty brew.
Bottle. Poured a golden color. Has an aroma of malt and some hops. Taste is plain kinda with a very little hop finish.

Bottle.  Clear amber with a frothy white head.  Grass and grain aromas.  Toasted bread malt flavor with grassy hops.  Light to medium body with some fizziness.  Strange thing is, when poured into a lager glass, this beer tastes like a very plain and grassy lager, but when sampled straight from the bottle it somehow tastes a little more complex and fruity.

This copper beer poured with a thin off-white head that didnt last long. There is a musty malt aroma and a thin creamy malt taste with a slightly bitter finish. Ive been drinking this for years and discovered that I hadnt rated it.
35.5 cL bottle. Pours copper brown with light brown head. Distinct malty and spicy aroma. Taste is spicy with notes of corn. Sweet and bitter with a spicy-bitter finish
I bought it a store saying it had a rating of 100. I was surprised because it was no where near that good. That being said it is an alright beer, better for an afternoon bbqing.

Moderate-light malt character--doesnt last, tastewise. Strong hops aroma, little ester. Metallic aroma/taste. Creamy mouthfeel...different, but good. Hop alphas make for a slightly astringent aftertaste...not really good or bad. Slightly skunked....not the beers fault. Overall decent, but not whats expected of a classic style example.

skunky, amber, aminimal head, light sweetness, very bitter, heavily sour, soft carbonation, long finish, 

I found this beer to be very difficult to drink, no enjoyment at all

Reddish slightly hazy colour. Small head with some lacing. Quite fruity aroma with a musty touch. Dry watery feeling in the mouth. Slight bubblegum taste on a bitter background. Im not too fond of the flavor, but its an interesting beer nonetherless.

Bottle. Initially this beer reminded me a bit in appearance and aroma in nose of there Old Foghorn Ale or thought in a very thin version. Head as small white and quickly goon. Left some lacing in glass. Body was clear, sparkling with an amber colour. Aroma in nose was sweet malt, with notes of rye bread, caramel, light roasted and burned candies, brown sugar. With this heavy aroma in nose, it was a bit thin in texture and body, but also purses some dryness and crispiness. I was expecting some more. Still overall this is a pretty good beer for 4, 9 %. Flavour is sweet with some of that burned candies bitterness mixed in there. Very drinkable.
Draft - nice reddish color with offwhite head.  Aroma of nutty grain with hint of citrus. Good balance of malt and hops.  Decent beer.
A towering monument to brewing perfection.  Its the Jupiter of our beer solar system, the sequoia semper-virens of our froth-filled forests.
UPDATED: JUN 14, 2007 Orange with light orange froth.  Not much aroma.  Smooth, but tastes very lagery.  Lot of yeast and a bit of hops, but overall not very interesting.

[106-20061118] Tap @ Point Brugge (Pittsburgh, PA). Aroma has notes of bubblegum mixed with something deep and slightly musty. Clear, red amber body with a few tiny central bubbles and a quick white head. Light yeasty, beery, forgettable flavour. Medium body, slightly astringent but comes together in the aftertaste, which is long. Like the aftertastes resolution, the rest was kind of muddled.
Malty aroma, with some evident hopping.  The flavor was mostly malt, with a nice roasty kick.  Not complex, but very pleasant flavor.  Mouthfeel was a bit fizzy, but other than that a good beer.

UPDATED: NOV 14, 2007 Copper with big, foamy head / Sweet, caramel, grape nose /  Light to medium body, with lively carbonation and good finish /  Bright spun sugar flavor with undertones of grape and pine which carries through to finish.

Bottle, marked best before AUG08. Imported from the USA to Europe by Bier & Co, Amsterdam.
Some faint mushrooms in the nose. Flavor dry with a subdued lingering bitterness. Not as good as I remember it to have been.
Beautiful smoky red, off-white head disappears quickly. Slightly fruity aroma. Flavor also fruity and soft, a little smoky. No real finish to speak of, very smooth.

355 bottle at The White Horse, Parsons Green an hour before watching the match between Chelsea and Blackburn. Dark orange coloured body. Low level of foam. Rich aroma of dark fruits. The taste has got some tartness on a malty backbone. Refeshing and crispy. Quite active carbonation (31.01.2007).

This is on of my earliest ratings. The color and head is nice on the stem beer, that is the first in its class that I taste. It is nice, round and well balanced with notes of hops and a nice bitterness.
A  really good beer, a wonderful aroma, with a real caramel flavour.  A really good balanced beer.
On tap at my home.  Was a decent brew to satisfy most tastes during the holidays.

This may be the first beer that really left a bad taste in my mouth. Im sure im like the 5th or 6th person to use that phrase. It just had a funny taste and after taste. The appearance was good. Smell was good. But the damn thing tasted a little creamy, and being from SF thats not god. :yuk:

Bottle. Amber colour with a white head. Havent had a lot of Anchor beers but the few Ive drunk all had a smell which I cant quite describe but it makes me do faces. Apart from that, the aroma is mostly malty. A nice flavour, better than expected when I smelled the beer. A bit fruity roasted taste. Short finish, soft mouthfeel.
Crisp and refreshing.  Tastes like a lager with some ale esters sprinkled in.  Hops make their presence known in the finish.  Decent session beer, but nothing spectacular.
Gotta support the locals here in the USA.  Nice color, easy beer with a great taste.
UPDATED: FEB 10, 2007 Eh.  Not a huge fan of this one.  Has a creamy texture/taste to it, smoothe.  Not my kind of bra.
Bottle: Clear copper color with a white head. Aroma, pale malts, some bready notes, herbal hops, a bit of yeast. Flavor, biscuity malts, caramel, some light bitterness. Pretty good.

Ehh, enjoyable and refreshing is what I can say about it.  Ill follow suit and say slightly hoppy with more malt in the balance.  A sweet aroma to this one.  Cool bottles from anchor brewing.  Yup, thats all I got.
Golden/amber color.  Smooth, dry, refreshing taste that is slightly hoppy.  Overall a good beer but nothing exceptional.

Orange/light brown appearance with a short lasting white head. Has a pretty regular aroma with some fruit, like orange or grape. At first the taste is great, with hobs like a pale ale. But after awhile a somewhat sharp acidic aftertate reveals itself and leaves a long bitter finish that will give you a bad breath like when you are drinking a mainstreem pilsner.

12oz - batch 600 - Aroma is sweet and malty with a slight hop back.  Pours transparent amber with a big head and great lacing.  Flavor is also malty, toasty and sweet with a little hops in the background.  Palate is sticky and sweet.  Non-offensive, but nothing special.
Pours amber/orange with a quickly diminishing head. aroma is malty with grassy hops. the taste is of light malts and hops, and I swear I taste something spicy, like black peper. The finish is watery.
Dark Orange pour. Small head doesnt last long.  Taste of mild hops. Finish is watery.

Clear orange with small head. Aroma is malty (caramel), nutty with some grass hops. Light to medium body. Tasted a little apricot. Flavor was lightly sweet with some bitterness. Pretty good.
Again, you feel like your tasting history. But, you have to wonder whether theyve kept up in more modern times.

UPDATED: AUG 5, 2008 I definitely must say I LOVE this beer.It pours a beautiful amber, orange color with lots of bubbles and a small, but nicely foaming head. The smell is very remniscent of the bitters style, with malt, caramel, and a slight hop bittersweetness to the fore.  And the taste is wonderfully bitter, malty sweet, just perfect as a session beer or a serious sit-downer.  Overall, it reminds me a lot of Redhook ESB, which is not at all a bad thing.
Clear, golden amber with little white head. Apples, hay, grapefruit and a bit of hoppyness. Straight forward beer.

12 oz. bottle. Typical malty lager scent, slightly metallic, pear fruitiness. Pours a sparkling copper with a moderate amount of short-lasting beige head. A touch of American-pale-lager-like grossness mars the first sips. Further sips, however, reveal a welcome hoppy bitterness, saving the flavor. The hops bitter taste remains in the finish. Smooth yet crisp texture and mouthfeel. Full body. A pleasure on the palate. I can tell Anchor Steam would hold up well to multiple tastings, as it improves as one drinks it. In fact, it would make a fine session beer. I remember being blown away by this beer when I first had it in my early days of drinking. I still like it, but lets just say Im a little less enthusiastic these days. Regardless, this is an historically important beer in a rare style that any serious beer aficionado must sample.

Honestly, I wasnt thrilled by this one.  No head, slightly spicy aroma, and a look like a copper still.  The taste was nothing to write home about--it seemed like an average American ale.  Its not bad, but its not worth $9 a 6-er.
Sweet malt and some spice in the aroma.Pours orange/copper with a medium white head.Sweet malt and some light hops in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with a bitter finish.

It is an amber colored pour, with a creamy white head that leaves lots of lace in the pint glass. It smells a little bit bready and malty, but not overly discernable. It might be poured a little too cold. 

The maltiness comes through in the first sip, followed by an almost tangy, floral hoppiness. The “lager” characteristics from the yeast come through in the aftertaste. It is not overly complex, but very balanced. A smooth and drinkable beer, with a pleasant soft carbonation
Bottle.  Caramel color, white head with some lacing.  Balanced taste with weak to moderate hops and malt, a little metallic at the finish.
Bottle-Memphis. Golden body with brilliant white head. Hoppy nose. Taste starts bitter and rounds off with a nice crisp sweetness.

Bottle. Well carbonated, dark brown california common style lager with a quickly disappearing head. Aroma is dominated by crystal malt rather than the signature Northern Brewer hops. Simlarly the taste is clean with slight fruitiness and predominantly caramel with some rustic hop notes. Finishes dry, and slightly thin with a well balanced bitterness.
Pours a nice looking reddy orange body with a healthy white head and some lace. Well balanced bitter hoppiness throughout.  A basic but enjoyable brew.
Wanted to have it because of the reputation.  Solid ale, but nothing extraordinary.  Good, but dont know if I will go out of my way to get it again.

Amber-copper pour with finger-sized white head.  Aromatic fruits and grains.  The flavor is complex, but short lived.  Flowery with a sharp bite.  Medium bodied, great balance.  A grassy hopiness lingers.
Bottle. Amber colour with a big off-white head. Aroma and flavour of malt, caramel and hops.

A 12 oz bottle with no freshness or best buy date on it. The beer pours a yellow and red mix with a big off white head. The smell is a nice blend of malts and hops. A taste of malt and hints of carmel will fill your mouth, good carbonation.  This is a good beer any day.

Malty and hoppy in only the way Anchor Steam is, with a proper mix between malt sweetness and hops.   Ive approximated the same thing homebrewing with german pils malt, crystal 80, flaked rice, and chinook hops.. so I am guessing that is what they use or close to.  Definitely worth tasting.

Bottle Carmel color, full off-white head.  Very hoppy (pine, thyme, grassy) aroma.  Slight malty sweetness followed by stong dry hops, then even stonger spicy hops.  Some inconsistent notes of metal, carmel, and water.  Very full body, not much finish, but lots of lingering spicyness.  More interesting for its history and brewing procedures than as a drink.
Dark amber colour with an average head. Nice little roasty malty aroma and some fruitiness. Flavour is crispy, nice hoppiness and a bit sweet. Little bitter aftertaste.

The aroma is malty with some light fruitiness and woody notes.Amber with a creamy head. The flavor has a maltiness, a little caramel, a pronounced bitterness and some woodiness in the finish. The body is medium.

12oz bottle.  Filtered and a clear copper hue.  Spotty off-white head.  Bready caramel aroma.  Soggy malts.  Slightly spicy aromas.  Full and dry palate.  Lively and effervescent.  Bready flavor.  Bitter yet smooth.  Caramel malts and a great bitter spicy peppery hop flavor.  This is a cornerstone in beerdom!  Buttery smoothness.  But in no way bad.  Slightly sticky.  Cloying.  Is there a touch of vanilla?  Fruity sweet flavors intermingle with the lively bitter finish.  Juxtaposition at all points on the palate.  Sweet to bitter.  Crisp tp smooth.  Blended and deep.  This is a standard!

Bottle poured a solid amber orange, with moderate tan head that settled into a thinnish white ring. Aroma of bright floral hops and maybe even strawberry(?), with a malty backbone. Its got a great medium palate with crisp bitters, and notes of sweetcorn. Good stuff.

Poured clear amber with a thin white head.  The aroma was yeasty and hoppy with the thinnest hint of fruit.  Taste was crisp, the body thin and the carbonation lively.  Hoppy bite leaving a bitter finish.
Not much aroma, but nice lingering hop flavor. Medium amber color. Good solid body.
Aroma was skunked, may have to re-rate.  Taste of corn and cardboard.  Deep golden pour.  Dissapointed.

An aroma of fruit with a soupçon of yeast. Nice apricot amber color with an enthusiastic white head. Sort of hits with hops and malt all at once. Good mouthfeel. The finish is significant, though not harsh, hoppy bitterness. Theres a bit of lacing on the glass.

Truly great when fresh, this beer does not hold up well to age. Brewed in big, open vats, do not miss a chance to visit the brewery if you can. With age, the woody character from the Northern Brewer hops can become harsh. Likewise, oxidation makes this beer caramelly and unpleasant. Decode the date if you are not sure: http://anchor.kimbo.org/
Pours amber with a decent head.  The aroma is malty with some fruitiness.  the taste is malty with some hoppy spiciimess..
A very good domestic drinker. Nice amber color with a rich head. Very good balance between the hops and malt make it incredibly smooth and well rounded.

Bottle.   Pours a golden amber color with a decent sized white head.   Aroma of  light malt, some floral.   Flavor is light malt, some hops, toast.   Palate is light to medium, medium carbonation, bitter finish.   Beer

Bottle.  Pours amber with a surprisingly thick head just like the label says.  Flavor is malty and hoppy.  A slightly bitter smooth flavor with rusty overtones.  Aroma is ever so slight, but crisp. Not to much there as far as smell goes, but the taste more than makes up for it.  It leaves the tongue slightly dry, yielding less time between sips.  This is a good beer.
Bottle.  Decent beer, quite malty.  Some hint of vanilla in it.  A bit more heavily carbonated than the average beer.  Pretty good value for its price.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 pours a gold copper with a one finger white head. nice carbonation with the aroma being a little hops and malt and barley. some lacing with a light body. flavor is hops, barley, and malt with a small dry hoppy aftertaste not bad.
For my money, the best beer in the world. Balanced hops and malt. If you ever see it "draught", do yourself a favor and order one!
Bottle. Nice amber color with a moderate head that didnt last. Nice malty flavor with just a bit of the hop at the end. I thought this was a very enjoyable beer.

This is a great tasting beer! This beer reminds me of the restaurant Red Lobster (the only place I tried this). I didnt know it was available outside of there. This beer is best in a frosted glass complimented by expensive seafood. Good all around.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Not a bad brew at all.  Hace a very nice smooth medium light copper nody with little head.  Aroma is nice and malty, and it has a nice hop crispness too.  An overall pretty nice brew.
Bottle poured deep dark amber with a vanilla looking head.  Quite frankly was better the first time around.  The taste was not as I remember.  I will say the palate was a pleasent experience.

Bottle 44F Lager Glass. llight sweet and sour aroma, a bit of malt and a bit of germanic  hops I believe.  LIght copper color, with light white head. Sweet and bitter tastes, nothing overly developed as should be the case in a classic beer, such as this. pretty decent though. Decent palate with good carbonation, yet still drinkable in session. Not a bad brew at all, and a great american classic.

12 oz bottle. Clear amber. Tangent: This beer is probably responsible for my first experience with true craft beer.  My parents drank this a lot when I was in high school and I always enjoyed stealing them and bringing them to parties while everyone else drank natty light. Bready, light citrus, sweet malts, a little smoke on the nostrils. Flabor is less interesting. Light hops, smooth palate, a little cream. Very grassy aftertaste. A unique beer and my #1 gateway beer from a great brewery!
Fairly decent beer. Nice creamy head, but it doesnt last that long. A slight aftertaste that to me I could do without.
Good beer, bottle, pours a hazy yellow.  Light malt and hop aroma.  Smooth taste.  Clean finish.  Good session beer, but nothing special.
user_location: The Land of Milk and Honey, Ohio, USA

text: not a bad beer, and welcomed to find amonst the bud light, heineken, mich ultra at the funky monkey in Morristown NJ. wouldnt choose it too often though.

Anchor Steam Beer
12 oz bottle
Medium pour in an English pint
Brewed 05/06, anchored 11/06

Poured amber orange with an average frothy quickly diminishing head with no lacing.

Smelt of moderate caramel, bananas, grass.

Taste was upfront moderate bitter grass and cobwebs with light sweet and slightly sour raisin fruit followed by a strong bitter grass hops with light sweet gelatin on a long finish.  Palate was light to medium bodied, dry, softly carbonated and moderately astringent.

Overall, this beer has a very rustic distinct character, and, as innovators of the style, a great benchmark.

Pours a yellow-orange to amber with a reasonable though waning white head with the occasional big bubble.  The nose is lively and fruity.  Rich carmel malt over a light floral hop background.  Also a bit of acidity.  The mouthfeel is really great for a session.  Creamy and mouthfilling while not heavy or chunky.  Really nice.  The flavor is solid as well.  Big creamy caramel malt with much more liberal floral hops that I could detect in the nose.  Really cream, the finish is creamy, which is a bit not so clean, but still nice I think.  The aftertaste is a bitter fruity hop.  Not a bad beer by any measure.

Clear orange color with a thin creamy head.  Both the aroma and flavor have lots of malt, thats the most noticeable component.  Beyond that, theres a bit of citrusy sweetness in the flavor, and a bitter finish.  Very drinkable, low to medium carbonation, no offensive flavors, full but not heavy.
This one is confusing.  Maybe its because I live in the South, or maybe because I prefer IPAs, but this beer doesnt cut it.  Odd, soy sauce-like taste.

Pours a clear amber-gld with a half-inch off-white head full of huge bubbles.  The nose is malty, slightly citrus, a tinge of resiny pine.  Taste is lacking, with a heavy emphasis on biscuity malt and a slight citrus tinge.  The finish is noticeably sour, with a bitter (but not bracingly so) aftertaste.
